number of helpful: 19 of 26 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												Ubisoft has done something truly special with Child of Light, a product that resulted not from trying to appeal to the widest audience or focus testers, but a product that genuinely conveys the heart of those involved in making it happen.You play the role of Aurora, an Austrian princess who is trapped in the strange land of Lemuria trying to return home to her father. Along her journey, you will find various landscapes to explore, with secrets and collectibles hidden in every nook and cranny, a few optional side missions and a cast of endearing characters to aid you.Gameplay is centred on the open exploration of the world, and a turn-based combat system. While not in battle, you will be flying around the various lands of Lemuria, manoeuvring through various terrain obstacles and simple environmental puzzles, searching for a way home (and treasure!) with your firefly helper Igniculus who serves to activate certain locks you can’t reach, light up dark caves and also to stun enemies with the blinding light he emits. Additionally, you will find various characters who will provide side quests or even join your party. There are roughly 8 different party members, who range from a cowardly wizard, to a pair of jester siblings and provide entertaining dialog that is curiously written entirely in rhyme. While this is entertaining and sometimes impressive, it does make it more difficult to become emotionally attached to any of the characters, as a Shakespearean script is far from natural-sounding. Regardless, their personalities are still differentiated enough for each one to shine and leave a lasting impression and this should be considered a feat of writing on its own merit.The combat system is an interesting take on the traditional turn-based JRPG-style combat. In a similar way to the ATB system in Final Fantasy games, your attacks are based on a timer. Once the timer nears the end, you prepare an attack, but if the enemy manages to spring their attack before you have launched yours, it causes your attack to be “interrupted” and sends your timer further back. Likewise, you can do the same thing to your opponents. Igniculus helps out here too, by slowing your opponents so their attack bar will fill slower, but also by healing you or your allies and grabbing health/mana when he can. It’s simple to learn, but feels very rewarding once you’ve managed to nail the fine art of timing your attacks. Other familiar RPG mechanics include elemental attributes, random loot and a variety of potions that restore health, mana and provide buffs.You will participate in each battle alongside a party member. You can swap between other party members when your turn to attack comes without wasting a turn, meaning it’s very easy to adjust your strategy by utilising the various skills of your different partners. Each has a unique skill tree that expands as you spend ability points for levelling up through experience in battle. Some characters focus on damage, some focus on buffs or working in elemental benefits.Each part of Lemuria is a hand-painted masterpiece. The Ubi-Art game engine works the same visual magic as it did for the previous Rayman games, with a combination of high-resolution, 2D artwork spread over a multitude of parallax layers that results in every screen appearing unique from all the rest, with very few assets re-used. The watercolour artwork itself is both warm in its choice of colours and at the same time often melancholy, with ruined buildings and overgrown monuments in both the background and foreground hinting at a more peaceful past. The audio also adds to the atmosphere, with exploration music consisting of a few slow-paced piano scores, jumping to more frantic, orchestrated pieces during battles.Child of Light is let down only by its short length and by the plethora of “cash grab” DLC’s that were released at launch. But do not be discouraged, the game is presented in a way that uses every artistic medium available to it to craft an elegant presentation from an already highly competent game. It may be a short adventure, clocking in at around 10-14 hours for the core game, but the pacing of the story and diamond-like polish of the gameplay mechanics ensure that every hour is enjoyable while at the same time never overstaying its welcome.Pros:~Beautiful eye-candy artwork from start to finish~Fantastic writing feels like you’re part of a storybook~Wonderful soundtrack~Perfectly balanced gameplay mechanics, challenging without being unfairCons:~Day-one DLC, including a locked party member~Animation on some characters appears cheap~Main game will be too short for some to justify the price

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												Played it on hard and beat it, Played New Game + on hard and beat it again. Took me roughly 36 hours. Got all the confessions, collected all the coffers and stardust twice and completed all the side missions twice. The only items I used were Stardust and Revive potions.The Good:- The artwork, if you’re into that look.- Combat, though at times it could be incredibly frustrating and it was basically just all about timing your attacks.The Okay:- The DLC is all purely cosmetic or stat boosting (The Golem is an awful character by the way).- Not too many launch day bugs (as compared to other titles released by UbiSoft)- The story is simple, but decent.The Bad:- In New Game + mode you couldn't speed past cutscenes. It drove me absolutely crazy that I had to listen to the dialogue over again.- The writing is just terrible. They force every sentence to a rhyming structure, and they don't even do that well.- The puzzles are simplistic in nature and few and far between, don’t expect anything that requires actual thought.- The crafting system, why does it even exist? It lacks any sort of depth, and the game is easily played on hard mode while ignoring it.The Ugly:- Uplay on launch day of course was acting up- Uplay on Watch_Dogs Launch day was acting up even worseExpect not to be able to play whenever Ubisoft launches a new titleOverall:I really wanted to like this game since I'm such a huge RPG fan, but this felt as if it was designed for children. They released a patch within the month after release to fix some of the launch day bugs, but I never got to experience the game with that patch.EDIT: Also, last time I buy anything from Ubisoft before its on sale, this game has been out less than 2 months and it's already 25% off, with all DLC being 40%. Its akin to a slap in the face to those who pre-ordered or bought it when it was released. I rarely pre-order or buy during opening month, forever Transistor gave me a hungering for RPGs that could not be satiated so that's why I picked this up.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												+ Very nice artwork+ Almost all dialogue rhymes+ Nice soundtrack, sound effects and narrative voice actor.+ Light-hearted "bedtime" story+ The beautiful gigantic maps are sprinkled with hidden paths and secrets rooms with great loot for adventurers to explore.+ Nice variety of characters with a unique skill tree for each of them.+ No grinding needed.+ Nice "gear" (Oculi) system with a decent amount of options to customize your characters.+ Timeline turn-based combat with an interesting twist: everyone shares the same timeline where its possible to "interrupt" and bump back enemies. If done right, the enemy won't ever be able to execute his turn. Of course, same applies to your party as well. Another interesting mechanic is the firefly (your mouse pointer). You can use it to slow down a single enemy or heal your a party member which depletes a seperate "light meter". All this combined makes for an interesting combat system.+/- The game has 2 difficulty modes: Casual (super easy mode) and Expert. Expert isn't very challenging, especially for veterans of the genre, but it does keep you on your toes as ♥♥♥♥-ups are less forgiving. This can be a good or bad thing, as the game is not intended to be an intense strategic challenge but rather a "light" game where you can sit back and enjoy the story and visual aesthetics.+/- Decent amount of side-quests (8-10?).+/- Decent length of around 20 hours playtime (my first playthrough was 24 hours and second playthrough was 15 hours = 39 hours in total).+/- Uplay. As much as I dislike having Uplay on my computer, it doesn't really bother you as all it does is have a second (automatic) login screen when starting the game. It has an offline mode option now as well so you can play without internet. If you do decide to keep it online though, Uplay will reward you with some Uplay points for every achievement which you can trade in for bonus items such as stat boosting "stardusts". Do note, however, that Uplay doesn't keep track of your achievements. If an achievement is "Meet X" and you've met X in offline mode, turning it back to online won't fetch you the achievement. The only way to get the achievement is to start over and meet X again.- Linear game- Not much replay value. New Game+ resets the story and you get to keep your character progression, your items and your "confessions". All it does is buff the stats of all monsters and EXP as well as better drops after battle. It still doesn't pose a challenge however. Then again, I might've been a little overleveled because I've equiped all my characters with Diamonds (+% EXP) throughout the whole game and haven't skipped any battles.- DLC Oculi Packs are a waste of money. Don't bother.For what it is, it's a very good game. Beautiful art. Easy to get into.9/10PS. All the treasure locations for those who don't like to backtrack:https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/70352935/CoL/index.html

number of helpful: 11 of 13 people (85%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												Funshine Bear was hurtling towards my screen with sniper precision. My 7-year old daughter is a stuffed toy-throwing expert. She *really* fell in love with the lead heroine, Aurora, and each dramatic encounter would leave her aghast as the story unfolded. In this case a plushie bear attack was warranted as Child of Light got real right there. Funshine Bear might have lost a bit of stuffing too. The game was my choice for our daddy-daughter gaming nights and we enjoyed it so much, it warranted two playthroughs.	Upon first firing up the game, what immediately hits you will be the gorgeous artwork and orchestral music.  It grabs you by the arm and just fills your senses with a massive serotonin hit. Backgrounds are exquisitely crafted with several motifs ranging from grey-blue ghostly forests to lava-filled mountain passageways in the belly of a giant colossus.  Scene by scene, level by level, you will experience lush hand-drawn imagery and meticulously crafted character art design. Each level has it's own art tone, much like a watercolor painting that conveys emotion and depth.  Also, the characters you encounter have an amazing originality and natural warmth in their faces.  You'll easily be able to recall them even months after you complete the game.  Honestly, Child of Light has some of the most beautiful art direction I have ever seen.  At no point in the game does this attention to detail falter. It is consistently gorgeous with an air of childhood fantasy accentuated by it's unforgettable theme song.	 Then there is the story and dialogue, done entirely in iambic pentameter.  Which to some may be annoying, but I personally found it to be an amazing surprise.  My 7-year old followed it a bit more easily than some other games and the rhyming conveyed that fairytale vibe you'd expect.  I will say that after awhile, you do encounter some odd dialogue that either barely makes sense or doesn't seem to rhyme as well as other passages.  While it's not a major issue, sometimes I didn't quite follow what was being explained.  Doing an entire game in iambic pentameter is no easy task, so having a few odd bits here and there didn't really affect my enjoyment.	The story follows a little princess from a kingdom in Austria that either died or mysteriously ended up in a mystical land called Lemuria.  I couldn't really follow how in the world she got to Lemuria, but almost all the story takes place there except for a few cut scenes of her father.  You explore and fight, gaining skills and friends who join your party along the way.  Each character is from a chapter in the story such as wizard villagers, giant mice with superb financial skills, an acrobat circus girl and her whiney missing brother, a giant soldier dude who seriously needs a manicure, and a young fish girl who probably has the coolest attack of all by knocking her opponents backwards to gain an attack advantage.  Boss battles tend to be tentacled monstrosities or evil villains turned into aquatic-looking baddies with minions.  You attack the tentacles or minions, but it's best to get the head as much as possible and don't bother to use any potions or life saves until the last few bosses because you will seriously need them then and only then.  	Gameplay consists of a really interesting blend of crafting gems for skill points, a time limited RPG attack system, and a very nice method of switching party members to change up the strategy.  It works quite well.  The fighting occurs along a time line, giving you some unique methods of attack and defending.  The gems can be used to help against evil monsters by bolstering your character powers with skill against certain elements such as fire, earth, water, or lightning.  However, if you are familiar with turn based combat, I'd suggest playing on the hardest level.  Eventually, you'll fall in a groove of picking the right set of persons to attack and the right partner to heal them regularly.  I'm not particularly good at turn based combat, but I didn't die until the last few boss battles.  Even my 7 year old girl was able to handle the majority of fights after she saw the way I beat them, and pretty much only asked for help with the bosses when she played by herself on the second playthrough.  It's a little too easy on the normal setting.  You'll have to play with the character selection a bit to figure out which one has the best attack, but other than that it's fairly straightforward.	It's quite hard for me to critique this game, it has so many positives going for it.  Could it be a little less fairytale-ish? Um, yeah.  It could, but in doing so it loses some of that charm it's shooting for.  Was the combat boring? Not at all, occasionally tedious at worst.  With all the options given to you there is a lot to play around with in attacks and strategy.  Knock an enemy back in the timeline, defend until the right moment, switch out a character at the last moment, use the little firefly to slow down the enemy attack.  I could go on and on.  Do I really want to play a game about a little girl?  At first, not really.  Then as I played on I began to enjoy it quite a bit.  Child of Light has some of the best style, art, story, music, characters, and combat for such a small title.  I think the only weak link were some of the puzzles which were all on the easy side.  There were a few side quests to do, but I only did half of them.  It was preferable to enjoy the game story and combat rather look around for quests to complete.  This game shines brightly and is well worth the time to finish to the end. I highly recommend it

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												A charming game with beautiful visuals, fun combat, and a decent story.This isn't the best game I've played, far from it, but it was well made and enjoyable enough. After my saunter through the main story and a few side quests (8-9 hours), I was ready to be done. I left a few side quests unfinished. After you beat the game you are given the option to keep playing and finish what you started, but I was ready to be done. Also, the first time I tried to play it didn't really take with me. Not sure if the beginning is very boring or if I was in the wrong mood.If you're unfamiliar with the game, it's a sidescrolling RPG with a turn based combat system similar to maybe an old Final Fantasy game. The entire game is presented as a children's story, and everyone rhymes everything they say. This leads to a few funny moments but can get pretty old. The story is a children's story cliche, but it's done well enough.There is a good value for the asking price (even not on sale, 15 bucks isn't bad!). It's really nice to see a AAA studio take a chance and do something that isn't another iteration of their tried and true franchises and make a game like this. So although not perfect, I'm glad this game exists, and I recommend you play it if the subject matter interests you.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												This is one of the games in my library which have a really awesome artwork. All the backgrounds and characters are nice drawn.


Child of Light 
A Screenshot of Child of Light
By: Daerphen




The story itself is not new. You are the little princess of light "Aurora", who has to save the world (she is living in) from the dark. On your journey you will find many friends. Fighting takes place in a turn-based combat with realtime elements. Each character will influence the battle with other buffs, debuffs or special attacks. In realtime you can heal your characters or slow your enemies. Each character has a waiting period and a casting time. Depending on which cast you use, you may shorten the cast time or extending it. If you get hit while casting you get interrupted.All in all this is a very beautiful game. I really recommend every person who likes fantasy, rpg, turn-based combat to try this out. Only downside was the difficulty of the few last fights. Even on lowest setting it was pretty hard for me (a person who does not often play turn-based)DLC's may help you in your adventure, but you won't need it to finish it.

												Dá uma luz mesmo de satisfação, esse jogo. É lindo, tem músicas cativantes e tem uma história MUITO bacana.O jogo é muito gostosinho, eu tenho um tédio muito grande por RPG de TURNO mas esse me prendeu. Os personagens são divertidos e interessantes, os ambientes incríveis e fantasiosos e a protagonista tem uma personalidade que te convence a se passar por ela e enfrentar junto a ela tudo o que ela tem de enfrentar.Sobre o coop, não cheguei a jogar mas  acho que é uma opção até válida porém não tem a mesma emoção do que o single, porque são personagens diferentes e o player 2 vai ter ações minimizadas no jogo pois não joga com a protagonista.O jogo possui muitos bosses porém sem dificuldade para vencê-los, somente paciência. Talvez você pode se perder um pouco ou esquecer do que deve fazer mas basta abrir o menu (que tem indicação da sua próxima tarefa) e você ainda possui o recurso de "viagem-rápida" também através do menu para não ter que voltar tooooooodos aqueles caminhos, cidades, lugares, morros nos seus "próprios pés" - que encurta bastante seu tempo para caso precise ir a um local longe para fazer quests a parte.Eu sei que muita gente sempre reclamou da Uplay, mas para a minha primeira vez utilizando-a não tive um problema sequer (inclusive as "ações" de lá funcionavam muito bem). Sobre os saves, parece que há um erro, mas eu nunca executava o jogo por lá e sim somente pela Steam e nunca perdi nada.

												I thought it was fun. The RPG elements were cool and the gameplay was pretty decent. The battle system was stellar and certainly hearkened back to game days of old. The artwork was amazing. The game was truly beautiful. The story wasnt stellar in my opinion. It was decent but also forgettable. According to Steam, I put 11.6 hours into the game, and according to UPlay, I have 4 achievements left. I probably wont put any more time into the game to wrap up those loose ends unless I'm bored on day, especially since all that is tied to Uplay, which provides almost no motivation to try and wrap up challenges other than to feed the completionist in me, which is almost non-existent anyway.Overall, I think I would give it 8 out of 10 for gameplay, but probably 6 out of 10 for story, and 10 out of 10 for artwork. Recommend, but not at $15 price tag.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												Even in our darkest moments if we look hard enough theres a spark of light. Of all the games I played this year,  I think this one is my favorite. This game tells the story of a little princess who wakes up in a strange fantasy world that she must save. It's really refreshing to see a Princess saving herself and not the other way around! The world the artwork and the storytelling are BEAUTIFUL. Every line in the game is literally a verse of poetry. It's not always perfect but it's still awfully cute. Aurora is adorable and there are plenty of awesome characters you'll meet along the way.The combat is a pretty basic. It's Turned based like Final Fantasy with a couple twists. It's not very hard and if you have ever played a video game before I reccomend Expert difficulty otherwise the game might end up boring you. The fights get more challenging as the game progresses but aside from boss fights I never really had a problem.Oh and did I mention the music? The music in this game is incredible. When i first bought the game I listened to the title screen for a while before actually playing <3 Here's a link to the OST if you end up enjoying it as much as me. http://musique.coeurdepirate.com/album/child-of-lightOverall I think this is a great game. I really enjoyed it and reccomend it to anyone who like turned based RPGs and wonderful stories!

content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												Child Of Light is a 2D turn-based RPG that has a gorgeous artstyle, in addition to a cute story that's told in nothing but rhymes.The combat mechanics are similar to the ones in Grandia 2 (another excellent turn-based RPG, by the way). Your character's portrait will move from left to right on a bar at the bottom of the screen and when it reaches about 75% you can pick an action. When it reaches 100% they will execute this action. But, if an enemy hits you in this last timeframe you will be set back somewhere on the bar and your enemy will probably have the advantage by then. Of course, this also works the other way so it requires tactics to defeat your enemies. Enemies are also vulnerable to certain elements (fire, water, lightning, light, physical) so you have to switch between actions and characters in order to beat them. It's pretty deep.Fortunately, you can usually select which enemies you want to engage, with the exception of bosses obviously. Battles can be a bit too long, and sometimes you have no other choice but to engage enemies because you really have to level up if you want to make those boss fights any easier. Exploring the world can be boring because except for a few sidequests there isn't much to do. Yes, you can open up chests or collect letters but they're usually 'hidden' in plain sight so the excitement of discovering things just isn't really there. Navigating through the world can also be a bit frustrating because it's not always clear where you have to go to, or what you have to do. Near the end I thought I was finishing up the story while in fact I had been completing a sidequest this entire time. But I guess that's a bit of the excitement part I was just talking about.The rhymes also feel forced sometimes. Whenever a part of the story is told it all feels very natural, but whenever characters talk with each other it just feels awkward and forced. I think it would've been better if nothing but the story was told in rhymes. You know, sometimes less actually is more. That doesn't take away the fact that some are the rhymes are really nice and/or cool.The game is long. Long enough actually. Any longer and it would've outstayed its welcome. I finished it in around 9-10 hours, but doing all of the sidequests and collecting everything there is to find will take you 3-5 hours extra if I would have to take a guess.I really enjoyed Child Of Light, especially halfway through but there's definitely room for improvement. Less rhyming, better navigation and exploration, and a bit more variety. If I had to rate it I'd give it a 7.5. In other words: a solid game.[Rating: 77/100]

number of helpful: 21 of 34 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20
												Yet another game for which I wished there was a "neutral" review option. Child of Light is not a bad game, however it has many little defects that prevent it from being the real gem it could have been. I'll briefly explain what are the pros and cons of the game in my opinion.PROs:+ Beautiful visual style and art direction.+ Simple but effective combat system, which is an interesting variation of the classic ATB-based system often seen in JRPGs like Final Fantasy; the player has the possibility to influence in real time the speed of his enemies, thus making combat more dynamic.+ Tactical boss battles; bosses are pretty smart and strong and you'll need to plan your moves carefully when facing them if you don't want to be defeated, especially when playing at the higher difficulty.+ Good variety of playable characters and skills.+ Nice soundtrack.CONs:- You can only deploy two characters in battle at a time, which limits a lot strategy and often makes you feel like you have too many characters and too little space. Most boss battles require a continuous change of formation in order to be able to use the proper skills at the proper time, which often leads to waste more turns than necessary.- Some characters are rarely useful and towards the end of the game you'll pretty much always use the same ones.- The game is fairly short for an RPG (the 20+ hours I've spent on it were way more than enough to finish it, and I lost a good amount of time trying to farm gems and exp until I got bored) and there's no real need to exp your characters to the full extent of their skill trees in order to progress. There's also no real need to craft all the perfect gems to be equipped, also because finding all the necessary ones would require a lot of grinding. The longevity can be extended by playing a New Game+ but since there's no real change or reward for doing it, most people won't bother.- The story is very basic, despite the interesting presentation and the peculiar rhymed narration, and that's just awful for a RPG like this. Yes, there is some lore (god I'm starting to hate this word) to be reconstructed by finding confessions, but it's nothing particularly detailed or deep. Most of the backstory is left to the imagination and all focus is on the simple main plot.- Not a defect of the game itself, but it requires a Uplay account to be played. It wasn't a problem for me to create one but I really find stupid to use two DRMs for a single game. If Ubisoft didn't want people to play this anywhere else than on their platform, they shouldn't have allowed Valve to sell it on Steam. Period.Considering all I think that Child of Light is a flawed little gem that could be worth a play but only if picked at sale price and only if you're not looking for deep gameplay or story. Otherwise you'll be very disappointed. I honestly expected much more from this title considering its fame and the enthusiastic reviews, but I guess that nowadays people are just too much inclined to see all the positive aspects of something they knee-jerk like and forget about objectivity.

												Beautiful game, really captures the feeling of a children's fairy tale.  Classic Final Fantasy style game play is familiar yet really smooth and just feels right.  The characters are really balanced.  I ended up relying on pretty much all of them and they complement each other really well.  It's fun flying everywhere.  I recommend skipping the DLC, however.  Most of it is BS in-game consumables.  The co-op mode is a bit weak with a second player able to control the "ball of light" helper, which a single player is perfectly capable of controlling as it is.  The second player is pretty limited.These are minor complaints though.  Overall it's a great game which I really enjoyed and felt it was worth it.  You will likely enjoy it if you're a fan of this type of turn based RPG.

												To be honest, this game possesses what so many other games lack.The strength of Child of Light is the combination of the brilliant music, a sweet story and amazing art and animation which creates a truly immersive and beautiful gameplay experience.The combat isn't anything complicated but requires a surprising amount of experience for optimal battles. I actually really liked how the action/casting bar functioned because it requires you to defend more than you would do perhaps in other games - I typically would never go near a defend button in a turn-based game.If I had a problem with the game, it would be that it didn't last as long as I wished it would, it was kinda short (full completion 12hrs on story-focus difficulty). Regardless, I really enjoyed it and found myself stopping to admire the setting more often than not.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												What a wonderful game child of light is.  Beautiful 2d water color graphics pop out at you constantly depicting a dreary forest, and ancient monastery, a mountain mouse village and many other vibrant story book places you will visit on your journey.  The combat is rather simplistic turn based affair, think old school final fantasy except you have a gauge at the bottom of the screen that determines your attack time and you can use a particular friendly ally and some various skills to manipulate it in your favor.  There are many magical and physical attack skills to learn as you level up, giving you some customization and control over your party.  There is also a deep crafting where you build magic stones and charms to power up your equipment.  Lots of interesting characters to meet and some will even join you on your journey to reunite your family.  Best of all every party member you get has a particular style of play so strategy comes in as to who you play when, and you can swap them in and out during battle.  Lots of side quests and nooks and crannies to explore, if you are a completionist or just like to peer in every corner of the world you will be rewarded.  Just enough of a challenge on normal, more experienced RPGers should skip to hard.  One of the better turn based rpgs in a long while, a must play for rpg fans and anyone seeking a whimsical adventure.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												A fairy tale of a game with wistful music and dreamlike environments, and an incredibly open feeling world due to being allowed to fly freeform through the entire thing.The game tells the story of an Austrian Princess, Aurora, who ends up in a mystical fantasy world called Lemuria, told that she must save the world from the evil Queen and recover the Sun and Moon, with the help of her magical crown, magical sword, and her friends. From there begins a rhyming journey across Lemuria, meeting jesters, gnomes, beasts, and more that join your party. The game is set up in JRPG fashion, with turn based battles that are reminiscient of Grandia with the use of the timeline, and interruption skills that let you halt and delay enemy attacks, and let them do the same to you. Your party levels up constantly, and while individual levels don't offer too much, over time you accure new skills, upgrade old ones, and get a steady feed of progress across your entire party (as even inactive party members get full XP!) Equipment is handled through the use of "Oculi", colored gems that can be combined with themselves to make bigger versions with new effects, or with other colors, entirely new versions with new powers.Party members are all useful in their own way, and I found myself using all of them except the final party member you get, a great deal. They tend to be split along usual lines, physical attackers, healers, tanks, magical attackers, and etc, along with a party member who specializes in manipulating the timelines. Each character has three separate skill trees they can go down that emphasizes particular skills and stats, and Stardust, found through the game, can be used to permanently increase  acharacter's stats, allowing you to customize them further (or just feed them all to Aurora because the main character should obviously be the best at everything.)The game feels just long enough to tell the story it wants to tell, and the world helps it every chance it gets. The music is immersive, the art and world are watercolored and move you across lots of different environments. Honestly the only thing I felt really detracted from the game was the forced rhyming scheme. It doesn't follow any real rhythm and just focuses on trying to rhyme lines regardless of length. One party member has recurring issues finishing rhymes and it's lampshaded by another party member constantly, which might actually be the best part of the whole rhyming gimmick.There's two major downsides to this game though:1: It's an Ubisoft game so it comes bundled with uPlay. This is your own thing to deal with, unfortunately. It didn't bother me.2: The DLC is straight cashgrab stuff. The Golem character's quest takes about two minutes and he is ultimately forgettable, but useful. The rest is complete cashgrab items that aren't even good - you can acquire them from the first few treasure chests to come across. To provide context: It takes dozens of lower gems to make the higher ones, in a 3 -> 1 ratio. Don't buy the DLCs unles you really want the other dresses for Aurora.... or the Heal skill unlocked for Aurora that comes from the Light Aurora pack. The healer you get in the game works perfectly fine though, and she's the first party member you meet.Wonderful game and absolutely worth the price of admission.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												I've played the entire game through twice now, and I feel comfortable in saying that, on the whole, I would recommend Child of Light to anyone who asked. But that doesn't mean it's without major flaws. As much as I enjoyed playing the game, the longer I did so, the more I became convinced of one thing: Child of Light is a decent game that could’ve been a GREAT game with better story and character development.Before I further explain that thought, let me leave you with a list of things I really, really liked about Child of Light (in no particular order):1. Aurora. Despite my (soon-to-be-explained) issues with the character development, I enjoyed playing her because she’s a character with real agency. Over the course of the game, she makes a series of tough decisions using her own intuition and courage, and the narrative never treats her with condescension, or undermines her ability to make those choices.2. The combat system. This is one of my favorite parts of the game. It’s a classic RPG turn-based system with nifty little twists. Your party members and the enemies appear on a single timeline at the bottom of the screen; the speed at which each character reaches the end of the timeline determines who attacks when. The nifty part is that the player can slow down the enemies’ progress on the timeline—and even interrupt their attacks—thus adding an extra layer of strategy.3. The variety in party members. There are a lot of characters who join your party over the course of the game, and they each have different strengths. This gives you plenty of options in battle, and you can customize your combat style to suit particular enemies. As an added bonus, you can easily swap out party members in the middle of a battle and still have the newly-swapped-in party member attack on the same turn. I was really thrilled about that. More skilled gamers than I might find it too easy, but I enjoyed it. It actually gives you a chance to try out all these characters that you otherwise might never play.4. This is rather an obvious point, but the art. The visuals are simply stunning in this game. There’s so much visual depth to appreciate--I wondered if the art-style would make the background look flat and obviously one-dimensional, but it doesn't at all. The artists and developers also did a good job of integrating the moving characters into the painted scenery. They don’t look disparate or disjointed. It’s all very cohesive and lovely. 5. Exploring the world. In large part because of the gorgeous art, it’s really fun to just fly around and look. I liked poking around all the areas of the game and soaking it in.6. (I'm sorry, I must all caps this because I WAS SO HAPPY ABOUT IT.) YOU CAN FLY FOR AS LONG AS YOU WANT WITH NO STUPID, HALF♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ IMPOSED LIMITS. 7. The hints and undertones of myth. This is another element I wish had been better developed, but what information we do get about the world’s history and legend is intriquing to me. It creates a nice ambiance, even if it isn't as prominent or developed as I would've liked.So, bearing in mind all the things this game does really well… I have to say, I was fairly disappointed in the storyline and the character development. Those are the two great weaknesses of Child of Light, and I think that's worth knowing before purchasing the game.The story’s greatest shortcoming is its pacing. It starts off interesting enough—the main character, Aurora, appears to die in “the real world” and then wakes up in Lemuria, a fairytale world—and she spends the rest of the game trying to get back home. The pacing is fine in the beginning of the game (central conflict is established), and stays fine toward the middle of the game (central conflict gets more complicated) … but then the “middle” of the game suddenly becomes the end of the game; in what I honest-to-goodness thought was the middle of the story, the end-stage of the story came hurtling at me, and I found myself fighting the final boss, and everything was wrapped up in ten to fifteen minutes. As a player, I was left wondering what the hell just happened (wasn’t I just in the middle of a quest? Shouldn’t there have been more conflict before THE FINAL CONFLICT?). The ending is very, very rushed and therefore feels very, very forced.  I seriously thought I was still in the middle of the story when I came to what was obviously the final dungeon—that’s the kind of rushed I’m talking about.If I had to break it down, I’d say 60% of the game is decently paced, but that last 40%—the part of the story that should feel EARNED, that should be a natural progression of what comes before it—is like a freaking whirlwind. There’s so much wasted potential in the narrative. And that’s the most disappointing part: if the writers/developers had invested more time in developing the middle-end and end of the story, it could’ve been so great. It had all the potential in the world, and then wham. Here’s your hat and coat, show’s over ladies and gentlemen. I think the poor character development goes hand-in-hand with the rushed story. If the narrative had been better-developed, I imagine the characters would’ve been better-developed too. As it is, they get left behind with the rest of the game's potential. The other major flaw with character development is that the writers told rather than showed. Most of what passed for development in the side characters—hints at personal back story and motives for joining the party—are all told rather baldly in dialogue, and that’s it. What you’re told is precisely and only what you get. There’s some cute dialogue between the various characters, but it’s all very surface-level and never leads anywhere significant. There’s no conflict or independent action or progression with them. This is the down side to an item on my pro list: because there are so many party members, none of them get the time and attention needed for real development.The most developed character is Aurora, but her character arc has a lot of the aforementioned problems. I will say, though, that she has more urgency in her story—she has something very real to lose, and that creates organic conflict around her choices and actions. So I do applaud that part of her development—it just could’ve been SO much better with the right pacing.So there you go. This game does a lot of things right, but because of its bad pacing, it really suffers in the story and character department. Ultimately, I enjoyed my experience playing the game, but if a haphazard ending will ruin the experience for you, it might be better to walk away.

number of helpful: 15 of 24 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												The difficulty of reviewing role-playing games is that they so often seem more an assembly of parts than a sum, and, while Child of Light's parts do cohere nicely, it remains a challenge to describe as a whole rather than a collection of discrete elements.  Perhaps this reveals that its coherence is an illusion, or it could just be the nature of the genre.  It's a game that clearly has a soul, but that soul doesn't seem to come from a single auteur so much as a group of artists and designers working hard to ensure that their ideas coalesce.  At times, they strain themselves, but to their credit the seams rarely show.Child of Light is a Japanese-style role-playing game along the lines of Final Fantasy but agreeably streamlined.  You play from a side-on perspective, traveling through landscapes filled with roving enemies, environmental hazards, simple puzzles, and secret paths and alcoves.  Exploration is a pleasure because of the freedom afforded by the ability to fly in all directions, and each area feels fluidly laid out and is full of treasure to discover.  The protagonist, Aurora, is accompanied by a light elemental named Igniculus who can interact with objects and stun enemies, enabling Aurora to move past them without a fight or to get behind them for a surprise attack.Battles pit Aurora and one of her companions against an enemy set of up to three, and all participants move along a timeline displayed at the bottom of the screen.  This timeline is the core of Child of Light.  It is divided into two regions: a long wait period and a short cast period.  When a combatant reaches the threshold between them, s/he chooses an action to perform.  The cast time for any given action depends upon the character's speed and the specific action itself, and, if a character is successfully attacked during his/her cast period, the action is interrupted and s/he gets set back on the timeline.  The only exception is for defending, which has no cast time; thus, when choosing a character's action, the player must decide whether it can be completed before an enemy attacks or whether it is best to be safe and defend, effectively forfeiting the turn.  Finally, Igniculus provides the flexibility of control: the player can position him over a single foe at a time, slowing it down as it cowers from his light.  This allows you to make tactical decisions constantly, changing a turn-based game into something much more directly involved.  Many of the best systems in videogames are very simple but allow for great depth, and Child of Light accomplishes this by providing lots of tools that can be used to manipulate the timeline.  The items that are hidden throughout the world are gems that confer attributes when equipped.  Some of these are standard RPG fare such as fire, water, and lightning offensive and defensive affinities, increased damage resistance or attack power, and bonuses to hit points and magic points, but the most useful—and interesting—gems affect the timeline.  Tourmaline grants attacks the possibility of paralyzing their targets, citrine yields a chance to set enemies back on the timeline, and spinel causes characters to begin every turn with a bump forward.  A crafting system allows the player to improve or transmute these gems as strategy requires.  The final piece of the puzzle is the characters' skills, which are quite varied.  In addition to the expected haste and slow effects, there are skills that set enemies back on the timeline, jump allies forward for a set number of turns, paralyze enemies for a given duration, and prevent interruption altogether during the cast phase.  Enemies provide their own interesting wrinkles, though; particularly later in the game, many will counter your interruptions with their own buffs, requiring you to alter your tactics and show restraint even when you have the opportunity to prevent them from acting.Dominating a group of dangerous enemies by carefully controlling the timeline is quite satisfying.  However, Child of Light, being a role-playing game, cannot be won through skill alone.  If you play on Expert difficulty—and you should, as Casual is too easy to allow you to experience the depth that its systems have to offer—you need to make thoughtful use of the gems that you find and craft while exploring, your different characters' skills, and your real-time ability to selectively slow enemies; but you also need the numbers to back that all up.  If your characters don't progress at a sufficient rate during their adventure, no amount of tactical mastery will make up for their statistical shortcomings.That's where the game's main design flaw comes into play.  To be fair, it's not entirely Child of Light's fault; this is a problem inherited from the long tradition of Japanese role-playing games.  While placing enemies within the game world for the player to avoid or engage at will happily eschews the standard exasperation of constant random battles, it represents a hypocrisy of intent since, while battles are made to appear optional, they really just aren't.  Taking advantage of this opportunity to avoid combat gradually puts players at an increasing disadvantage; those who are careful to circumvent what enemies they can will find their characters underpowered when they are forced to fight.  The ability to bypass battles sounds great on paper, but its implementation requires a more thoughtful approach for making it challenging to do so and for rewarding successful evasion with character progression to substitute for the experience that would have been gained through those battles.  For the player, the workaround is simple: make sure to fight enemies regularly throughout the game, even though you don't have to.  It's unfortunate and disingenuous for a game to indirectly force us to regulate our behavior like this, consciously preventing ourselves from taking advantage of an ostensibly viable gameplay option, but the problem does disappear in practice once one reconciles promise with reality.As you're likely to have noticed already, Child of Light is remarkably composed of watercolor art in motion.  It's gorgeous from the start and straight through for the entire 20 or so hours it lasts.  The score by Cœur de pirate, the stage name of musician and composer Béatrice Martin, infuses the game with the most pervasive melancholy, albeit one occasionally relieved by notes of triumph.  This music might actually be the strongest aspect of the entire game: it thoroughly characterizes the experience and often seems more profound than the fairy tale narrative warrants.The fundamental plot is clichéd, all evil stepmothers and light in the dark, but it is rescued in the telling due to the novelty of its rhymed verse.  Some may find it precious or cloying, but it charmed me.  While the writing can certainly come across as forced at times, it always arrives in bite-sized chunks, so no fault is ever severe.  There are plenty of dialogue exchanges that made me laugh or feel affection for the characters, and Child of Light plays with form by intentionally deviating from its rhyme in a couple of key moments.  Unfortunately, despite presenting a well-paced journey overall, the final moments of the game are rushed and sadly don't provide as satisfying a conclusion as they should.Although my opinion of Child of Light may sound measured in some respects, this is the result of taking a step back from the game to think about it critically; the truth is that I delighted in my time playing it.  Both established fans of RPGs and those curious enough to try a streamlined gateway into the genre should consider it highly recommended.

												Brilliant little turn based RPG Final Fantasy'esk game. I had been sitting on this game for a number of months since purchasing in the sale. I had often thought the graphics would not suite me, but they really are enchanting once you start playing. The colourful scenery, water effects, and lighting makes this a very pretty 2D game.  I really enjoyed the story. It wasn't too short, and wasn't too long, which some games sometime seem to suffer from. I wasn't too keen on the fact you don't really have a "quest log" to view all of your side quests, they all seem to get jumbled up in your item inventory, why, i have no idea?The combat system in very simple. Two of your party members fight up to three enemies at any one time. You can switch members around in the midst of combat so you can always try and get the advantage over the enemy.This game is really an enjoyment play through. 100% worth the price tag of £11,99, so if you can get it cheaper in a sale, you have yourself a huge bargin!

Child of Light is an amazing game. That's the short review. It does, however, have a major flaw: While the art design and turn-based combat system never disappoint, the story leaves much to be desired. Not in the journey, but in the ending.I do not want to get too into-detail so as not to spoil those who want to buy the game, but I will leave this warning: If you get attached to storylines and value proper closure and complete endings, this might be a game to avoid. The story flows incredibly well until the final stretch of the game, in which the developers sloppily attempted to wrap everything together. It honestly feels like they ran out of budget or time and had to quickly slap an ending on the game.If you value the journey more than the ending, have at it. It will not disappoint.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
												Clearly a game worthy of its price, reduction or not.Pros :- The game is surprisingly long. With that kind of game you would usually expect about 5 hours of lifetime. This one will take you approximately 15-20 hours to reach the end, unless you rush it like an idiot. If you like to complete games to 100%, you can add another 10 hours to that already long lifetime.- The combat system is nice. It's strongly inspired from the one from Final Fantasy but with some extra mechanisms like the possibility to interrupt or be interupting during the casting time of an action, the possibility to slow down a specific opponent using your mouse, etc.- The graphics are really sweet, colorful and yet sober.- There are plenty of little things hidden here and there that will push you to explore every place in order to find them. These hidden things can be gemstones or various bonuses, poems or even new hidden characters that can join your group. This is something that we used to see a lot a decade ago in games like Zelda OoT and that we see less and less in nowadays videos games where exploration is not rewarding you.Cons :- Sometimes you have to solve enigmas by doing some specific actions to advance in the level. These enigmas are not bad, but they are very simple to solve and are rather redundant. Must of the time it's pushing/pulling a box to the right place or using your mouse to create a shadow on a wall and aim it at something.- The gem combination system itself is nice, but the game doesn't provide enough information about it. You can hardly know what are the possible combinations unless you look them up on wikis or find them by luck.- You're forced to install and use Uplay to play the game. I already have enough crap on my computer, I don't really like being forced to install another privacy invading game client that sucks extra RAM on my PC just to play a game. Steam is already enough.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												Child of Light is that game that every gamer should play just to relax, listening to it's awesome soundtracks and to realize in the process that even small games deserve much appreciation. Now, the game is in 2D, portraying great art style of a land ruled by a Dark Queen and her forces which you as a Child of Light must fight to return peace to it's inhabitants. The story might sound very familiar but what must be taken into account is the way it is told. The pacing is precise and the dialogues are well written. The gameplay is simple and enjoyable, moving around and exploring different areas of the land of lemuria, collecting various items, turn-based fighting various enemies and a few bosses here and there, leveling up your character, crafting occuli (gems combined for various effects applicable to gear), solving a few simple puzzles and completing few side quests. The game length is around 20hrs if not rushed. I find it real value as the game is beautifully done overall. WHY YOU SHOULD GET THIS:+ Epic soundtrack, especially during fights+ Visual Design+ RPG/ Turn-Based style of gameplay+ Party management + Well paced story and events that can move your heart + Not too long and not too shortNEGATIVES:- Light vs Dark story is enjoyable but we've heard it before (not a big negative)- More side quests and more bosses/enemy variety would have been awesomeOVERALL:  85/100

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												- This review isn't written by a native speaker, thank you for your understanding -- If you haven't found this review helpful or if you have found a mistake please leave a comment below -Rating Must PlayPlatform U-Play (actions, rewards)- Key features below ---- Review after -----------------------------------------------Play time needed (perfect) about 16 hoursGaming level Casual or GamerAchievement level Casual or GamerGame style RPG, puzzle (some), platformer, turn-based (casting bar), crafting (occuli)Game modes Story modeGraphics Artistic !Story Good storyPlaythrough 1Voice Good.Music Very good and relaxing !Controls Keyboard and mouse or controllerTutorial Yes.Unmissable / backtracking content Yes.Customization Occuli and DLCDownload contents DLC Yes, not needed to finish the game.Glitches / bugs Not at all.Worth price It definitely worth it.- Review below ----------------------------------------------------------------------Child of Light narrate the story of a future princess that wish to save his father from his deadly loneliness through a long journey to a new world where she was sent away from her father.The story, music, voices and graphics make that game become a tantalizing work of art which will please teenagers and adults.Fighting are subtle as you may have a lot of mechanisms to work with beginning with your first partner a firefly. Your new partner will help you to slow down one enemy or heal the wound of one of your partner at time using its own power. You will need the mouse? or the right controller stick to move him. You'll then have a lot of friends to help you in your journey. All of them including you have their own skills, and a 3-branch skill tree to master. You can only use 2 character at time but can switch to another one when one of your ally is about to be ready.Also during your quest you'll find some occuli shards, which after being crafted are stronger than before. Every occuli have its own power depending of the color and the size of it. An Occuli can be equipped to one of the three slots of each character. Finally Occulis have a different powers depending on which slot they are assigned.The game difficulty can be set to normal or hard mode whenever you want. The hard mode makes mostly bosses becoming real bosses as you'll need to be smarter than them. Some boss may be frustrating but preparing a strategy will help a lot to slay them all.The game doesn't stop there. Indeed the game features some puzzles about a dozen where you need to use the help of your firefly friend or use some objects to interact with. There is also a whole new world to discover revealing some 'confessions' which are the game's collectibles, star dust (item that can instantly increase one stat of any ally), treasure chests (that may have occuli shards or potions), quests givers (several), lots of foes and many healing plants.I can only strongly recommend you that game if you love RPG games !Perhaps one of the most frustrating mechanism of the game is the interuption feature. If your character is hit by a foe while casting a spell or only using a potion, he is interupted and pushed backward. But you can hope that the other ally will be hit or defend yourself waiting for the right time. You can also always rely on your firefly friend. So there is almost always a way to avoid that.

												Very unique and enchanting experience. It feels like an "Americanized JRPG" and I mean that as a full compliment. The art pulls you into the world, and the combat system is solid, and it's varying difficulties make it welcoming for new players and experts alike. The combat rarely seems like a 'grind' with level ups happening frequently and your characters showing almost constant growth. The level of detail, polish, and absolute love put into this game by its creators really shows.Also, I think it's a steal at only $15 (the price at the time of this review). Any sale price below that makes this a 'must get'.---------A few notes: with the exception of "The Golem's Plight", the DLC is all bull, don't bother. Golem's Plight adds an extra character into the game (about an hour and a half into the game) who is useful, but certainly not necessary as the experience would still feel "complete" without it. For the other DLC, you get 'Oculi' as rewards in combat, kinda like money in most JRPGs. It's just a waste to buy it. Also, uPlay sucks, blah blah blah, but you knew that.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												Child of Light is an interesting game, but unfortunately it just isn't very fun. As other reviewers have said, the art is incredible. The combat, however, is a mix of frustrating and boring - not a good pair of attributes to blend in a game that's heavily focused on leveling up. Child of Light is a good thing to watch, but it just isn't very fun to play.Unlike many JRPGs, this game has gorgeous art and an actually interesting story. Each of your party members has a unique skill tree, as well as some unique dialog to carry you through the game. The story is told in bits of conversation, scraps of poetry, and the overall world design. In a way, it invokes the same sort of feeling as the much-vaunted Dark Souls: the game does not make you sit through pages of dialog, but the story is in the world if you want it. You don't need to pay attention to it if you don't want to, though, which is also nice. Most quests come as side quests, so you can comfortably ignore whatever you like.Levels are open and interesting, with enough nooks and crannies to keep exploration interesting. The game - on normal difficulty - loads you down with potions and other consumables, so even though you don't need the loot, it's still fun to get. You'll enjoy the light / dark theme that plays out in each level. Child of Light uses a few basic light mechanics (shadows, brightness, etc) over and over, but it still feels relatively fresh since the puzzles are kept very simple.Unfortunately, the combat is just unpleasant. In the beginning of the game, I enjoyed it, but by the end, I was desperately avoiding combat because it just took too long and was too frustrating.The mechanics of combat have been described by many other reviewers, so I won't re-tread that ground. The interrupt mechanic is just poorly implemented, and whenever you get interrupted (which will happen a LOT), the game continues to yell at you that using the Defend option will "prevent interruption". It doesn't. Defend skips your turn in exchange for increasing your defense and giving yourself a speed boost towards the cast meter. Defend does not prevent skill interruption, and I spent the first couple of hours frustrated that the game was telling me otherwise.With the gems (occuli) slotted, each of your fighters becomes specialized. So for each combat, you have a choice. You can either hit for low damage (i.e. using a Earth gem versus a Fire creature does no bonus damage) and immediately get countered for 3-6 times your damage. Or, you can swap out characters over and over. While you're doing this, you're continually getting interrupted and stunlocked. Defend, as I explained above, won't fix the issue since you ultimately will need to attack at some point.I really didn't enjoy the combat at all.

number of helpful: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 17, 2016
IntroductionAlright so Child of Light, interesting game, I won't go in to overly pretentious detail about what you can expect from this game in terms of artistic style because let's face it, it's all subjective, if you like what you see, then you're already interested. I'm not here to tempt you in to appreciating it's art style, I'm just here to give you the facts of what you can expect. However I will warn you that all the dialog is spoken in riddles and poems that rhyme... just let that sink in. It's not like you really have to pay attention to the story any way, it's fairly cliche drivel that you've seen before... If you've seen any Disney princess movie then you already know what to expect.How does it play? / Overall ImpressionsWell it starts off as you'd expect from watching trailers and such, a 2D platformer with RPG elements, leveling up, skill trees and a huge party roster, half of which won't get much, if any, exposure due to novelty or situational skill set they have. The problem with this game is the pacing... You think it's going to be kind of clunky and slow to start but shortly after the first boss encounter (about an hour in) you gain the ability to fly. Once you have this ability, that's it, you can pretty much traverse all the terrain in the game, there is no place out of reach. I foud this rather odd and it was a tad overwhelming. There is no limit on the amount of time you can fly either, like you literally just jump in the air, press the jump button again and that's it, flight mode... Another point of note is that there are locked doors in the first couple areas, these doors can never be opened so don't bother wasting your time. There's nothing behind them and you never get a key or a side quest for them... just locked buildings for the sake of it...This gave me the impression that this game was rushed, and upon further inspection, I think it kind of was, the end of the game just seems to kind of hit you really hard and fast and I never really felt like there was a "long way to go"... I finished it in just under 12 hours, two sittings, fairly short game, but again, it's 15 dollars. Honestly I'm not sure why this game is getting 9's and 10's... To be fair and honest, it's more like a 7 but I've found some pretty heinous glitches in it which lowered it's score for me to around a 6.5 / 10... It definitely needed more polish.That doesn't mean it's a bad game or a game not worth playing, but there are just some things I can't overlook when it comes to video games... I'm a bit of a stickler for poor design and glitches that ruin my over all experience... Enthrall me with a story as much as you want, it's still a video game in the end, not a movie... So when things are bugging out, I can't overlook it.Obnoxious Bugs / Glitches To Look Out ForAs you may or may not know, this game has a BUTT LOAD of collectible items in it, and the game conveniently keeps track of all of this stuff, you have 16 letters to collect, over 400 treasure chests and around 50 upgrade items. Here's where the fun stops...So I'm fairly O.C.D. when it comes to getting 100% in games, especially one as simple as this, so I felt up to the challenge, unfortunately there were a few isntances where I wanted to smash something.If you initiate the battle sequence (touch an enemy) while opening a chest or collecting an item the game will glitch. Upon exiting the battle the chest will be open / the item will be gone from the map, the problem is you won't have collected it. Instead you have to re-open the open chest or re-collect the item again even though it is no longer visible. BE CAREFUL!In the final area of the game there are 97 chests to collect but Ubisoft forgot how to count and placed 98 chests in this area and one of them doesn't count towards your final total... I'm not sure if not collecting it will count against you, I just found it to be a nightmare while following a collection guide... I knew I had opened 24 chests in the first area but the game said I had 23... just another warning.Is The DLC Worth It?No. Do not throw extra money at this game, it isn't worth a cent. There's an extra character you can buy for 3 dollars named Golem, he's not worth it. He's the strongest physical fighter in the game and the best tank but he's so slow all he's good for is being a damage sponge... Basically his utility is crap. The best party in the game is Aurora and Finn, main DPS / Buffer and a Magic Nuker... that's all you need to win.The other DLC items include giving you various combinations of stat upgrades and gems to combine so you can enhance your characters powers, you'll learn about that as you play... Don't buy them. If you're desperate for gems, just hack the value's in cheat engine, problem solved. Don't throw extra money at Ubisoft for junk.Final ThoughtsIt's a decent little RPG title if you're craving some good old school turn based action, the party is unfortunately small though, two characters max... Reminds me of FInal Fantasy Mystic Quest, really basic... but still fun. My biggest issue is that some of the characters wind up under utilized or not used at all, for a game that bolsters a cast of over 8 characters, it's a bit ridiculous. Again the game felt really rushed like it could of been twice as long or had twice as much effort / thought put in to it but they seemed to just toss this thing out there.People claiming this is a 9 / 10 game are seriously wearing blinders, it's no where near a perfect game, in fact it's quite flawed. I am recommending it though because you will enjoy some of the RPG elements it has to offer, even though it's easily exploited. It doesn't take much to complete it, a couple 6 hours sessions and you'll have it done in a weekend so it isn't a huge time sink. I wouldn't pay 15 dollars for it though, try to get it on sale from Humble Bundle or GMG for 10 bucks at most.Final Score6.5 / 10+ Looks good+ Gameplay is solid (Good balance of exploration, puzzles and battling)+ Fun battle system, albeit simple+ Lots of characters to choose from+ Interesting design- Felt Rushed (Locked doors you can never open, ability to fly given too soon)- Not a good time to price ratio (too short)- Bugs and glitches still not fixed (O.C.D. Nightmare)- Story is cliche, nothing new here.- Wasted Potential (Big character roster, two character party max)- Uplay....*puke* (I already have a main game client, I don't need yours Ubisoft)Get it on sale.

number of helpful: 14 of 23 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												Child of Light is a turn-based roleplaying game with a very distinctive pseudo-storybook graphical style, written entirely in rhyme. Many of its mechanics are reminiscent of Final Fantasy X – including some painful dialogue.Gameplay	The game consists of two portions: environmental navigation and battle.	Environmental navigation is actually a bit tiresome; at the start of the game, the player can only walk and jump, but very soon they gain the ability to fly around the 2D environment, eliminating all of the platforming elements in the game very early. This has a somewhat negative influence on gameplay speed, the player must explore an environment from top to bottom to find all the items and secrets, greatly increasing the amount of space which needs to be explored. In parts, it works decently well, but frequently it is tiresome, and only a few environments full of puzzles and traps are even remotely interesting to navigate.	There are no random encounters in the game; rather, monsters appear and wander around on the screen, and will attempt to pursue the player if they see them. The player will be “ambushed” if the monster runs into them while their back is turned, and will ambush the monster in turn if they manage to run into the monster’s back. This means that most of the time, the player will ambush the monsters, as not only is navigation simple, but the player controls a small ball of light which can be used to temporarily stun the monsters, in addition to healing the player between combats and activating some switches and puzzles	The game’s combat is actually reasonably sophisticated. The player controls two characters in combat, and faces off with up to three enemies at a time. It is somewhat reminiscent of Final Fantasy X in many respects; the player can switch out their characters at any time during combat, including replacing KOed characters with another character, and different attacks have different speeds. However, unlike Final Fantasy X, there are two different speeds which matter: the base speed of the character, and the speed at which the character acts.	There are two portions of a gauge at the bottom of the screen; the first portion represents the time spent between turns, while the second, smaller section represents the time spent charging up to attack or perform some other action. Each action has its own speed through the second portion of this, and if someone is attacked while they are charging an action, their action is interrupted and their turn is reset into some random (or semi-random) portion of the between-turns section of the gauge. As such, the player can interrupt enemy attacks, or the enemies can interrupt player attacks. There are some means of protecting yourself from such things, and some monsters will automatically counterattack against certain types of attacks (physical or magical) or against attacks made while they’re charging their actions.	The characters are actually quite varied, with each character having their own skill-set which is unlocked via a character-specific skill tree. Each character has their own set of abilities, and there are two characters who are primarily magic users, a warrior who can force enemies to attack him, a character who focuses entirely on speeding up or slowing down allies and enemies, a couple of physical attack characters, and some support characters. Gauge manipulation, interrupting enemy attacks, exploiting enemy elemental vulnerabilities, and applying the right status ailments while keeping your own party healthy are all important. The ball of light you control while navigating the levels also appears here, and can be used to slow down enemies or heal your allies – it is almost always better to slow enemies, though, as that prevents them from doing damage (and makes it easier to interrupt them) much more than healing yourself does.	Unfortunately, after a while, the battles become a bit routine; while the first set of enemies in an area are new and fresh, after a while they become very routine and can be defeated via a very samey set of actions in the same way that Final Fantasy X fights often went. This makes many of the fights in the game fairly dull, and while they’re skippable, the bosses, which are much more difficult, basically require you to beat every other enemy in the game so that you’re the proper level to face them.	The boss encounters tend to be the highlight of the game; they’re the most enjoyable bits of it, and tend to be a bit different from other encounters, mostly in that the bosses and their companions tend to be more dangerous, quicker, and more prone to retaliation and inflicting annoying status ailments that require you to actually think on your feet. Even still, I got through the game without getting a single game over, and I suspect that most players will do so as well; indeed, I was left with an overabundance of items at the end of the game and used them with wild abandon against the final boss, as I had hardly used any prior to that point.	There is also an equipment system, in which craftable, equippable gems which are acquired over the course of the game are put into slots and have various static effects on a character and their statistics; these can be used to add elemental damage types to physical attacks, grant bonus damage, make a character tougher or more resilient, or even increase the rate of xp gain.While this system seems neat in theory, I had the xp-gain gems equipped to my characters’ body slots for the entire game, and never needed to remove them to mitigate damage. Moreover, I pretty much figured out exactly how I was supposed to equip all of my characters quite early and from there on out it was just a matter of marginally improving my equipment over time – not the most exciting thing in the world, but it gave some sense of progression.Presentation	The game is reasonably well-presented; the game tries to go for a sort of storybook style, with the characters appearing almost like paper cut-outs or things from a storybook, and the monsters having a similar stylized character. The music and sound are both reasonable enough, but a lot of the dialogue – delivered entirely in rhyme – is pretty awful. Sometimes it works well, but other times it falls down and is kind of painful to read.Final Summary	Child of Light is not a bad game, but it isn’t exactly thrilling either. Everything about it is a decent enough idea, but in practice, it only shines on rare occasion. The game takes on the order of 20 hours to complete, and has no replay value; while there is a new game + mode, there is little reason to play it.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												This is a real gem of a game!As a light-weight RPG with tactical combat and including some light-weight platforming elements, this game is perfect for nearly any age and well-suited for the young who are exploring RPGs for the first time. The learning curve is low, characters easy to manage, and the entire game is controller-friendly. Combat is simplified by not having to choose weapons and armor, yet fun because the tactical element requires you to stay on your toes.The mechanics of the game might be too easy for more experienced gamers, but there is a hard mode to make fights more challenging. The story is an engaging fairy tale that is like playing through an interactive children's book. Aurora is a spunky and thoroughly likable main protagonist, wandering through the magical land of Lemuria trying to help its people and in the process trying to find her way back home (a palace in Austria) where her father, The Duke, has taken gravely ill.What follows is an adventure full of danger and camaraderie. Aurora is predominantly a spell-caster but can hold her own in physical combat with her sword. Other NPCs that join the party fill out the roles of magician, healer, archer, buffer, tank, and crowd control. Each character has a skill tree with three branches that can advance abilities via points granted with leveling up. It's impossible to max out anyone's tree in the first play-through, so the player can exercise some control over what they want their characters to do best. There is also a simple crafting system that isn't too grindy and allows the use of gemstones to augment skills and stats.The art and music are gorgeous. The violence is underplayed in keeping with the children's story theme. The length is perfect for the tale being told and never seems to drag. My recommendation is don't rush through. Stop and enjoy the scenery, and explore everything because there's lots of hidden treasures to find that help with crafting and battle. As an added treat, a second person can grab a controller and play as Igniculus (a talking ball of light) who assists Aurora's group in battle, solves light-based puzzles, and can reach items that are not accessible otherwise. In solo, he is controlled by the other thumbstick.This game has no Steam achievements, which is a shame. But that's because it's UPlay.Rating: 8/10Fun for ALL ages! Might be a bit easy for hardcore RPG fans.
