content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												Child of Light is an extremely gorgeous piece of work. From its method of storytelling to its stunning visuals and appropriately airy and pleasant orchestral soundtrack, everything about this game's presentation ties together like a fine piece of poetry. Sure, the writing is a little clumsy at times, and they reeeeally stretch the language to hit the nail on the head for some of those rhymes (see what I did there?), but the heart is there and that's why Child of Light shines as brightly as it does. It just has a ton of heart and love in it and its creators' care for the project shines through and is ultimately infectious. Child of Light's RPG elements are heavily inspired by Game Arts' Grandia series. Combat plays out with all characters assigned a spot on a timeline at the bottom of the screen. When a character or enemy hits a specific point on the timeline, they are then allowed to act. If a character or enemy is successfully attacked in the moments before their action is carried out, their attack is interrupted and they are pushed back on the timeline to hopefully try again. Combat mostly boils down to who can control the timeline better with their attacks or employing dirty tricks like slow down spells or status effects that inhitibt a character's movement on the timeline. All of the game's random battles have this strategic element, and boss fights even more so, which makes encounters not feel so mashy as RPGs can tend to be.Combat is enhanced further by the way you customize your characters. Level ups grant skill points that you can spend on skill trees to grow your characters toward the stats and moves you want the most, though there's never any need to maximize any one part of a skill tree if you want your characters to do a little bit of everything. The Oculi system helps customization further by allowing you to imbue your characters with elemental attacks, defenses, and abilities to alter their or their enemy's stats on the timeline. These aren't the deepest systems ever, but they add enough depth to keep the character progression important.  So yeah, Child of Light is pretty awesome. Its only flaws are that it can be a tad too easy (I HIGHLY recommend throwing the difficulty up to Expert as soon as you have the ability to) and a character or two don't quite get their chances to shine in the story before the game wraps up. Other than that, fans of JRPGs will be incredibly happy with what Child of Light has to offer with its engrossing story, beautiful world, and solid RPG mechanics.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												Child of Light is brilliant. The artistic value of this game is remarkable: the hand-painted backgrounds are stunningly beautiful, the orchestrated soundtrack is melodious and enchanting. Everything together makes you feel like you're really in a fairy tale. Exploring (or better, flying over) Lemuria is an absorbing experience, I think I'll never get tired of it.Fortunately, under the huge artistic value there's a good game. The RPG mechanics are simple, yet engaging. There are no random encounters: you can see the enemies on the map and decide whether to engage them or not. The combat system feels like a good ol' jRPG, revolving around anticipating/interrupting the enemies and party members swapping. You can also use your little firefly Igniculus to slow down enemies and heal yourself, adding a layer of complexity to the combat mechanics. This system feels fresh through the entire length of the game, so you'll just find yourself willingly engaging all the enemies, since fighting them is fun.Even though everything seems swell and nice, Child of Light has some problems. Aurora is the only fleshed out and likeable character. The other characters are just... there, they don't make a difference. The whole game is written in rhyme, which seems cool, but it's not: the metric is all over the place, it's not consistent at all. In the end it didn't bother me, but it could bother you. The plot is simple, a standard (maybe a bit darker) fairy tale plot. I liked it anyway, it's a good justification to explore Lemuria and to flesh out Aurora's personality, but if you're seeking a complex plot you're looking at the wrong game.In the end, is it worth 15 euro? Absolutely, it's worth more than that. We need more games like Child of Light, we need more middle ground between Indie and AAA titles. If you're on the fence, it's time to jump and buy this game. ;0

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												I can't even begin to describe how GORGEOUS this game is! It's like you're literally inside a watercolor masterpiece world! I would put this on the same level as Okami for aesthetic value :) Yes, the rhyming does feel forced (because it is) especially during the dialogue, but that just adds to the quirky-ness of the Lemurian world. I found the battle system interesting. It took me a while to get used to because I'd never played a game with this timer-turn-based strategy system (though I'm sure it's not the first of its kind). But once I got the hang of how it worked, I was surprised, and elated, by how thoughtful your moves need to be, particularly in boss battles, to be successful and effective. However, you could certainly get through this game by simply throwing your most powerful moves at the monsters, you just won't be nearly as efficient. Some may consider that a downside to the game, but I think it is an upside: you can progress through and enjoy the story whether you want to play strategically or not, allowing more skill levels to be able to enjoy the game.There is also a significant amount of exploring you can do to find bonuses, which I simply loved. This game exceeded my expectations in every way, and I would highly recommend it to anyone! As of this review (about 16 hours of gameplay), I have completed the main plot and all of the side quests (that I have found anyway), but I still have a bit more exploration to do to find the remaining hidden items in all the areas.I did experience a few glitches, such as Aurora's hair disappearing during battles and visual stutters near the end of the game, but nothing that effected gameplay.

												No matter how good a game is, or how much I enjoy/enjoyed it, I normally don't feel compelled to write a review for it. But, man...this game. After nearly having a coronary from Dark Souls 2, Child of Light was a very welcome respite that just melted the rage away. The music is well done and the evironments are beautiful (the giant walking in the background near the starting part of the game was a very nice touch), and the dialogue is fun (but maybe that's just the English major in me talking, even though I've never been much of a poet). The gameplay itself is straight forward and easy to get a handle on while still requiring a bit of forethought and attention. It's also kind of refreshing to have a little girl who is undoubtedly strong in her own right as the main character. Haven't finished the game yet, no idea how far in I am, but I did have to force myself to stop playing so I could stretch things out over the course of a few days instead of greedily devouring it all at once.Unlike what seems to be a majority of people, I haven't had any problems with the UPlay aspect (with this game or with Far Cry 3 or Might and Magic) so that isn't an issue for me.I also bought all the Day 1 DLC just to spite the a-holes who throw hissy fits about it. So let me end this pleasant review of an excellent game by saying to the haters: lol u mad?

content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
Child of Light ReviewChild. Tuck yourself in bedAnd let me tell a storyOf Lemuria, a long lost kingdom,And a girl born for glory.Child of Light is a RPG produced by Ubisoft Montreál, released in April of 2014. In this game you embark in a journey, playing as Aurora, a young princess whose soul is brought to the Kingdom of Lemuria. On this journey, you will have to recover the three sources of light and defeat the Black Queen in order to restore the Kingdom of Lemuria.Aspects Of The Game:•	An exhillarating and tranquilizing mix of music. •	A beautifully executed simple story. •	Hand drawn art.•	A classic blend of RPG elements in a side scroller.•	Turn-based combat.•	Great side-characters.•	A delightful main lead.•	An agape world called Lemuria with alot of adventure.GameplayIn terms of gameplay it is a good game.The combat mechanics are pretty simple. However, you need to think your actions well in order to act in the best and fastest way as possible. At the start you will play solo, but with time you will find many interesting and strong allies which will help you, by forming a party of 2 characters during the battles. You also have a firefly as an ally, which you control with the mouse. A pretty interesting mechanic but it becomes pretty repetitive during the combats. Out of combat it is an simple 2D platform game, with some puzzles, traps and tons of hidden loot. Sadly, in terms of combat, the game becomes extremely repetitive in the second half of the game because at some point, excluding boss battles, you will repeat the same tactics over and over again since the variety of enemies is pretty low. It gets so repetitive that at some point, you will start avoiding your enemies instead of attacking them to earn experience. You also have a perk system, as expected in a RPG, which is also pretty simple, yet intuitive. There is also a gem system called Oculi, that gives you the chance to upgrade certain stats of your characters.StoryThe story in this game is told in an extremely simple way, yet that is part of the beauty of it. It is a very sad story with some unexpected plot twists, supported by excellent characters and good dialogues, except the fact that they always rhyme, something that really grinded my gears, especially during the second half of the game because the rhymes start to feel too forced. Apart from that, it is an excellent tale of the journey made by the protagonist Aurora, in her attempt to save the Kingdom of Lemuria.VisualsVisually this is an epic game. The game art is absolutely astonishing, it really gives life to this wonderful fantasy world. Everything as an immaculate aspect, it is hard not to like the artistic work made in this game. Another highlight is the fact that this game as the "feeling" that all was hand crafted, as if the game was drawn on a canvas. Really spectacular in this category.Music and SoundsThe biggest strength in this game is the soundtrack. Absolutely amazing! It is hard to not be immersed in this awesome world with this wonderful combo of visuals and sounds. Simply astonishing. The sound and music gives the strength and energy you need to play this game, really inspirational.Pros:•	Wonderful visuals•	Intuitive combat system•	Amazing soundtrack•	Beautiful storyCons:•	Combat is repititive.•	Not much replay value.Almost every aspect of Child of Light is amazing.I don't regret buying it.Really worth the money.It's a great work of art.My Rating: 9.0/10

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												Child of Light is a 2d Metroidvania turn-based RPG in which a young Princess, named Aurora, wakes up in a mythical land known as Lemuria. In order to return home she needs to find the powers of the Sun and Moon but a sinister plot gets in her way. She finds creatures from all walks of life to help her in her journey, each with their own special power.The artwork is really really good especially if you have an affinity for oil based and watercolor style paintings. The game worked perfectly with my Xbox360 controller and a 2nd player can control Igniculus the firefly with a mouse or 2nd controller too. The combat is a mildly complex paper-rock-scissors system (almost exactly like South Park: Stick of Truth) which has a timeline that shows which order the characters/monsters will attack (much like the Grandia games). It can be difficult to use in the beginning but by the end of the game nothing stood a chance against me even on expert. There is a skill tree that has 3 branching paths/playstyles for each character. There is also a crafting system for gems (Oculi) that you can equip on the character's weapon, armor or accessory to give it different effects and bonuses. There isn't much complexity in terms of platforming seeing as how you get the ability to fly early on and from there it's about not getting hurt by environmental hazards. It's a well made and beautiful game with a fitting classical-hybrid soundtrack. One thing that might be off-putting for people is the dialog, written in poetry form with rhyming. I got used to it though and found it less annoying the more I played. I played it for about 8 hours my first time through and got sidetracked with other stuff and stopped. I came back to it 2 years later and finished the game with ~16 hours logged in on my save file. Was it worth the $15 I paid for it? Yes. I'd say this is a pretty solid game well worth the asking price but even better if you can get it on sale.

												It has been quite some time, since a game caught me, suched me in, and made me even loose sleep over it. This cute game, with it's fairy tale atmosphere and story, has succeeded in doing exactly that.I recommend it very much, and I hope there will be more games made in the same spirit as this one.As for the game, it is mostly a puzzle game, a game for exploring every nook of this sad yet uplifting world, and also a sort of turn based fighting game. The mix of exploring, fighting and crafting better occulus fits me greatly. With characters, or rather, companions, with individuality to booth, a lovely score, somewhat familiare story and lovely artwork I have not quite seen in any other game, this one has been on my "I must Get that game!"-list since I accidently saw it on youtube. And yeasterday (and today) I am finally taking time to play it.In fact, playing it in my winter night/dim room, with the snow outside and silence surrounding me, echoes to the mood set in the game.The question I am left with is; How can such a sad game yet feel uplifting?And that, I guess, sums the brilliance with Child of Light.

												Child of Light left me delightfully entertained at every turn. With beautiful backgrounds, lovely music, and a fun twist on the standard turn-based style of game play, it provides a  comfortably level of challenge as you learn to balance the timing of your attacks and how you delay you delay your enemies. The story is fun, even if a little predictable. The rhyming conversations between characters (and lack there of for one) is a cute little detail for this storybook style adventure.My main complaint for it is that, despite gathering quite a few companions on the journey, you are limited to two characters in fights (two in a have if you want to count your friendly little firefly). That said, it is balanced by the free swap out, if you even need to do so (casual really did not require it, but the more challenging mode might).

content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												Yes, it uses uPlay, but the game is so great I need to recommend it anyway. Regarding uPlay: When it functions how it's intended to (as it did for me), after you set up an account and register the game via CD key, the game launches straight from Steam, and just leaves the uPlay window in the background. After some simple settings, the only interaction you need to have with it is closing the window when you quit the game.Regarding the game: It's a pseudo-real-time turn-based RPG set in a fairy tale world, wrapped up in a fairy tale story with fairy tale narration. Everything is in rhyme, and while the story really isn't too complex or gripping, it has a gentle nostalgic feel to it. The timing of the combat adds a fresh twist to the stale formula JRPGs have used forever, making each battle feel more real and alive.The cast is diverse, yet the characters are flat- I didn't especially care for any of them, and there was one in particular that just got on my nerves. But the simplicity of their design fits in nicely with the simplicity of the story, and they each have their own little story which helps flesh out the world a little more.To put it simply- This game is like playing through a bedtime story. For the most part, there isn't much depth, but the game doesn't lead you to believe otherwise. All it asks of you is that you listen, you enjoy, and you embrace this enchanted world. It's a great, simple experience.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
So good that I played it twice, back to back!Child of Light reminds me in some ways of Studio Ghibli movies: they have a childish aesthetic but are more mature in story and tone. There is an unmistakable somber quality throughout Child of Light, something I wouldn't have expected from a game with a whimsical watercolor art style. This game excels at bringing together elements from various genres and fusing them together into a shining example of innovation for the industry.Let me list a few of the highlights of the game before I get into a few critiques. This is a gorgeous game, like a living painting with fantastic use of color, interesting inhabitants and exquisite backgrounds. The music stood out from the start and meshed perfectly with the overall tone. The combat showed its depth when I got my greatest enjoyment out of it during my second time through (New Game+ on Hard). A simple but satisfying crafting system allows for customization without too much complexity. Dialogue written in poetry combined with a chapter structure and occasional video cutscenes all add to the moving storybook feel of the game.Unfortunately this game is not perfect. Some of my complaints, particularly the first one, are matters of personal taste so you'll have to decide for yourself whether what I'm describing sounds like something that would bother you or not. I'm not much of a fan of poetry. At times I did enjoy the rhyming dialogue but other times it seemed like the writers were doing verbal backflips to fit the rhyme in, which made it feel forced and/or obscured the meaning. I do appreciate the novelty of it and how it lends itself to the storybookesque design. Some may dismiss the game as a kid's game due to the childish visuals or playing as a young girl but I urge you not to make that mistake.Without spoiling anything, I will simply say that the ending felt like it came rather abruptly but was otherwise satisfying. There was a point roughly 2/3rds of the way through my first playthrough that the combat became boring for a time. I was afraid going into my 2nd playthrough (New Game+) that I would be bored with the combat during most of it but that turned out not to be true. The level of challenge on Hard kept me on my toes and making use of all my party member's specialties. I must say that potions are fairly useless in the game. I only used about a dozen in total. Also, don't expect any complex puzzles or platforming. You can fly from nearly the start of the game so traditional platforming goes out the window in favor of mostly manipulating things with your firefly sidekick. Controlling both Aurora with WASD and Igniculus (firefly) with the mouse keeps things interesting. If I haven't mentioned any aspect you're wondering about go ahead and assume it's good, this game simply oozes quality.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												Child of Light is a beautiful children's story book brought to life with an exquisite hand-painted world. You play as a child princess, exploring and fight your way to the truth in a dream which turns proves to be more than a figment of imagination. You move around in the game by literally flying across the world from very early in the game. There is not much of gameplay outside combat other than avoiding traps and trying to hit the enemies from behind to trigger a ‘sneak attack’. Most of the enemies are optional but you’d want to fight them as frequently as possible to gain valuable experience which will come in real handy during the game’s much tougher boss fights. The combat is Turned-interruption-based. There is a timeline bar on the bottom of the screen and every action takes a fixed amount of time to perform. The bar is towards the right is split into ‘casting region’, which is the envelopes the time it takes for player as well as the enemies to perform their move. The idea here is to hit your enemies while they are casting so you ‘interrupted’ them.  Meaning they not only be able to perform their action, but they are also sent back a few notches behind the timeline, opening the window of opportunity for you to attack. I was not very familiar with this type of combat mechanics as a result I died quite a few times during boss fights. I asked around and to many people they found the game very easy on the ‘advanced or normal’ difficulty I played on. I had to grind to level up in order to defeat the final boss, so again I suggest to engage in all encounters. There is no drawback to losing to an encounter, you simply start with a full health and mana at the beginning of the section or whenever there was a checkpoint.  So the difficulty really depends on how familiar you are with this type of game.There are certain things I didn’t like about the game though. I feel the combat system doesn’t relay a lot of the vital information to the player. For example, you do not know the health of the enemies nor do you know which type of elemental stuff you have your team equipped. This means you are forced to memorize how you distributed your equipment and cannot make a well-timed final blows with no stats to look after. This especially hurts in the boss fights where the margin of error is very thin. Also the crafting is also not very well explained. You basically equip elemental attacks and defenses by equipping specific colored gems. You can also combine gems to create a different colored one. The game does not really explain which colors are possible to craft. So it is possible for a lot of players to go through half the game without knowing a certain gem color exists. I suggest you look into a guide just to make sure you get caught up with all the colors so you can equip your team with more organized attacks and defenses. I am not a fan of Ubisoft as a whole, but this is a side of Ubisoft I really admire. In the end I feel the game could have been a more rounded experience if they had more time and budget. A lot of effort had gone into making this game visually spectacular, unfortunately it meant the core mechanics of the game suffered and stretched a bit too thin for my taste. In the end these drawbacks can be frustrating, but does not detract much from the beautiful experience this game delivers.7/10 = Good!

Posted: May 28, 2014
												This game is a really loveable 2D-flying-around RPG with Final Fantasy-style combat. It combines classical 'explore the level for treasure chests' with the RPG-known elements such as leveling of your party as well as timeline-based menu-combat. There are some minor additional features such as empowering your equipment with gems.What I really like about this game is the way it is created visually and atmosphere-wise. Its partly hand-drawn backgrounds are beautiful for anyone who appreciates this kind of 'fairytale' style. The conversations are all in rhymes. The game emphasizes that it is a mystical tale about a girl searching for a way home to her sick father. The music fits perfectly, too.Yes, sometimes i found some drawings a bit too childish, but the whole concept was great.You might notice that I am a strong fan of this kind of games. Nevertheless, be warned: If you are looking for pure-adult-action games, or dont have the muse or time to dive into the atmosphere of the game, it is nothing for you.I think it somewhat speaks to the inner child in everyone, and it got me hooked up there :)I strongly recommend giving it a try. I found it worth every cent.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												Child of Light is a fairytale-inspired RPG with modest exploration and puzzle-solving elements.The story is set in the magical world of Lemuria, which is suffering under the rule of an evil Black Queen and her dark creatures which have overrun the land. The main protagonist is a young girl, Aurora. Aurora is the daughter of a duke from 1895 Austria who has found herself separated from her father and whisked away to Lemuria. Aurora must navigate the hazards of this beautiful, but dangerous world in order to return to Austria and reunite with her father.Without spoiling the story, what I enjoyed the most about Child of Light's plot was that it managed to touch upon critical tropes integral to a fairytale story, while subverting ones which are no longer relevant in modern society. Aurora's adventure is a coming-of-age hero's journey, involving hidden destinies and familial strife. Despite her fear and uncertainty at being in an unfamiliar world, Aurora is no helpless damsel in distress; Aurora is a girl of strong morals and action who helps those in need, and who over the course of the story matures into a strong leader.The art style evokes nostalgia for watercolored storybooks of childhoods past. Both the character sprites and the backgrounds are simple at first look, and extremely detailed upon closer inspection. The visuals themselves are beautiful and alone make this game a piece of art.The soundtrack by Coeur de Pirate is a perfect accompaniment to the setting and story --  appropriately whimsical, triumphant, or haunting, as appropriate to the point in the story.One element of the game that some may be put off by (though personally I enjoyed it) was the use of rhyming iambic verse in nearly all of the dialogue in the story.All in all, I feel that Child of Light is a truly excellent adventure and well worth the full price of the game and deserving of the 2014 GOTY nomination it received from IGN.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												This game carries its own little charm. Artistically, it calls back to the watercolour art of fairy tale books. Looking at it is incredibly nostalgic, since I used to read books like this as a child. Even the narrative is reminiscent of the best of fairy tale tropes, though the game manages to sneak in its own details and wit that keep the story feeling fresh and light. Even the characters are unique, with our heroine Aurora experiencing a coming of age story but still retaining a spunky attitude.The best thing this game has to offer is the absolutely fantastic musical score that helps to create the atmosphere of Lemuria. The songs are emotional, they can be light, and they can be dark, all accentuating points throughout the game. And nothing is as good as the amazing boss battle music, with a male choir singing as you slice your way through hordes of monsters.The turn based system was really interesting to see, and I really enjoyed how they implemented it into the game. The twist with the turn based mechanic is a sort of "wait" or "charge up" time, and it adds another layer of strategy in that you want to stagger your opponent and prevent them from doing the same to you.A slight downside is that, at least for me, I had a challenging time with bosses while playing casually (though it could just be the fact that I don't play many turn based games often and so suck). Also, while Aurora and several other characters are 3D models, her allies are not, which can be a little jarring but not enough to inconvenience the game. I do think they should have developed models that looked at least a little bit different or accurate to their drawn portraits.Overall, Child of Light is a lovely game, and something you should check out when you can.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Final Impressions (01/11/2015; 15.5 hours playtime; Story Complete)If and when some unfortunate woman bears my child, I will do everything within my power to have that kid play this game. What a delightful synthesis of fairy tales, story-telling, and JRPG mechanics. This truly is a great coming-of-age story that was unfortunately ignored due to Ubisoft's many misteps in 2014. But I have the excellent meltotheany to thank for bringing it to my attention as I originally stated.The art direction in the game is fantastic. It really does look and feel like a children's fairy tale is playing out on screen. Moreover, the landscapes are varied and colorful, ranging from caves, forests, fires, castles, villages, etc. I found the rhyming dialogue charming. In addition, the dialogue really serves to bolster the characters' different personalities and backgrounds, whether they be brave warriors or merchants with a savvy eye on profit. Background characters aren't fleshed out as much in dialogue, often repeating the same two-line rhyming couplet. But this is forgiveable as they are background characters. A select few that give quests offers up for extensive dialogue that relates their personality so it's clear that it could've been done. But I will give Ubisoft the benefit of the doubt in that that didn't want to overencumber the game with too much irrelevant dialogue for the sake of word-building. There's just enough in there to give a generalized sense of the tribes and their cultues.As far as battle mechanics go, this was pretty interesting to me. I've played a handful of JRPGs in my time and this echoes the turn-based model. However, it brings an interesting twist. The player can interrupt enemy attacks by timing their attacks to occur in a limited time window, and vice versa. This really put me on the defensive more than I otherwise would, often trying to decide whether I should gamble on getting an attack in before my characters are hit or whether I should buckle down and defend to mitigate damage. In addition, the use of Igniculus (a firefly companion that the player can control with the mouse) helps in the tide of battle by slowing enemies down, healing your character, or activating one of two or three troves of health and mana. Equipment management is largely tossed aside (which I think is actually a pretty good idea) with the exception of oculi. Oculi are gemstones you collect and craft throughout the game which can be placed in one of three slots for various combat perks. The crafting system is simple and easy to understand with the use of a small chart that is provided and the player is left to their own imagination as far as experimenting with different combinations.The story of the game is also superb. On the one hand, it is somewhat traditional. On the other, being a sort of video fairy tale this is perfectly fine and there are a couple of twists to be enjoyed through the narrative. Ultimately, the game is a coming of age story as we watch Aurora deal with the new problems she has been presented with. Both the music and the narration butterfly perfectly with the narrative. This is especially true of the narrator, which chokes me up a little bit and brings me back to thoughts of listening to my mother tell me stories or read me books.From what I've read and experienced, many of the chracters are optional and are not required. The genius part is that this drastically affects gameplay, making the lone wolf much enjoy a much more difficult experience and a slightly stripped down story.All in all, this is an excellent, charming game with a sweet soul. It seems to me that a lot of love and attention went into its development and it really reflects in the experience. I encourage anyone to purchase it and give it a go. And THEN, after you beat it, do a little research on things mentioned in the game as there is a grain of truth at the heart of the story.First Impressions (01/08/2015; 7 hours playtime)Child of Light answers the question of, "What would've happened if fairy tales and video games were invented at the same time and co-evolved?" The music is beautiful. The art direction is fantastic. As it stands right now, this game is a diamond in the rough that hasn't received the attention it probably deserves. Hell, I wouldn't even have known about it if it weren't for my friend Melanie.Only two minor complaints so far. First, you have to use Uplay. That's not such a bad thing. My other complaint, however, broke my immersion for a brief moment. Early on, I was getting a few chuckles out of a particular character's dialogue. Shortly after an achievement popped up that said "Comedy." Normally I don't notice these if I'm not looking specifically for them on Steam. However, Uplay's design pops them in a big black box in the upper right and it's hard not to notice. I have hopefully turned these notifications off for the future but I recommend doing this before you begin your first play session.Anyway, more elaborate review forthcoming upon my completion of the game.

												童话故事般的娓娓叙述，彩绘涂鸦般的缤纷世界，悠扬婉转的背景音乐，独具特色的角色魔物，无处不在的收集要素，成就了这样一个有着别具一格特色并且令人十分着迷的游戏。简单的操作对于RPG初心者也是极易上手，回合制的战斗设定清楚明了。角色属性的配点以及各种装备的选择也许会给你带来一点烦恼但请放心这丝毫不会影响游戏的乐趣。即便对于强迫症患者在收集元素的过程中迷茫于路途，也不会感到厌烦因为每一个小细节都能发现游戏制作者的用心之处，其中有不少是支线任务中必须完成的要素。整个游戏就像个大礼品盒，里面充满了一个一个小惊喜。善良而敏感的小公主，自认为幽默又特别认真在搞笑的小丑，长满胡子但实际只有13岁刚成年的小侏儒等等有着鲜明个性的角色为看似平淡普通的童话剧情增添了不少色彩。IGN评分9.3，如此精良的游戏没有理由不推荐给身边的朋友，just buy it.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												Child Of Light is a beautiful piece of art. It is an amazing combination of beautiful visual, music, gameplay, and fairytale style story. Playing this game is like playing an interactive fairytale story that's been told by our parents before our sleep. But instead stay in the bed just hearing them. We jumped in right into the world and feel the emotion in the first handYou are Aurora, a little girld who's a daughter of a duke in austria at late 19th century. In one day you fall sick and died. But instead of go to afterlife you woke up in the world of Lemuria. You find out to go back to your father you need to help Lemuria regain it's sun, moon, and stars that been stolen by the Queen of Night. This is the quest of a pure hearted Child Of Light to help Lemuria and come back to her father.The world of Lemuria is so beautiful, really well made and you can feel ubisoft were put their best effort to realizing this world. It's an eyecandy for me, at first I was caught in awesomeness with the artstyle in this game. And later on I found this world has many place to explore. Hidden crates, hidden places with some puzzle solving that aren't so hard nor too easy to solve really make every exploration is worthwhile in this game. The music? SO AWESOME. Coeur De Pirate has really done amazing job to living up the world of Lemuria. Her piano playing suites well with the atmosphere of the game. And the boss battle music can pump your adrenaline, make you talked to yourself, "Oh god oh god, this is must be the boss battle, this is gonna be awesome!!"It's really amazing to see the development of Aurora. She's pure hearted, unadorned like how a little girl should be, really honest to other people and especially to herself. But at the same time she also very brave and don't hesitate to take a drastic measue (Read: Violent measure). At first she's so scared for being far away with her father in such strange and dark place. But later on with help from her friends, she began developing her own bravery. My favourite line in this game is when Aurora facing a giant that get in her way.Aurora, "Step away, or I will turn you into clay."She, and all the characters in game were not voiced, only a dialogue balloon like how the comic does. But because of that, I imagine my own version of her voice. I imagine a little girl voice but full with confidence, has no doubt nor fear. It made me chilled my spine because of the excitement.The language that been used in this game is quite a mixed bag. They used somekind of language style that been used by old literature. At one side it can enhance the feel of a folklore, it feels like you just found an exciting old books, covered by dust in the box that been keeped by your grandfather. But in other side, sometimes it feels like it was forced. Like you want to told them, "Just speak normally."The gameplay involve 2D platforming adventure when engaging the enemiesis turn based with action timed battle. Once you engaged by an enemy you will moved into a battlescreen like how the old JRPG has done. The battle is so engaging, the boss can be quite challenging in the hard difficulty but failure is not very punishing. Every party member has their own speciality. As example Aurora is the physical damage dealer and the only one who can inflict Light Element magic. There are only 2 party active member at one time. I said active because basically every member can be involved in a battle. And you can always switch the party member at any turn. Switching party member depend on the situation is critical. Fortunately you are not have to keep Aurora in the active party at all time. The main character can be putted on the bench so other party member can take her place.Character skills customization are quite typical. In each level up you gain one skill point to spend. The skill tree in each character has 3 branch and that 3 branches is the only option of skill customization. In the late game one character can max one to two main branches. The equpment customization is more unique than the skills. Each characters can use occuli to increase modify their attribute. There are many combination in this game that maybe can make you sit in the occuli system for hours just to make sure every party members has the most effective occuli combination.But unfortunately, there are very annoying bug that ruin the beauty of this game. In this game, only Aurora and several other human character that been modelled by 3D. Other characters simply use 2D sprite. But when Aurora meets a characters that been modeled by 3D, the model overlap with each other. As example, in Aurora place, there were Norah, other character that modeled by 3D, stacked in her place. And in Norah's place, there was an Aurora stacked at her place. It always been like that and not a single time when Aurora meets other character with 3D model this bug didn't appear.My verdict is 9 out of 10. It is a very beautiful interactive folklore that make you wonder why there are no books of it so we can tell the children about Aurora Story before they asleep? With full of moral lesson that not too being smart♥♥♥♥♥or too being rightful one. This game is amazing for every ages. Oh have I said this game is very cheap? Only $15 dollar for about 17++ hour of excitement is totally worth it.

content:

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												DONT BUY THIS GAME!Pros:  Game play is interesting and the story is absorbing.  Amazing animations and a really well thought out game, WITH ONE PROBLEM!Cons: SAVE FAILED!This is a known issue that is apparently due to UPlay (another overlay launcher like Steam).  Numerous people have complained and while there are several fixes, none of them have worked for me.  This game uses an autosave feature and you CANNOT save the game yourself.  With this broken, it would be like playing a Final Fantasy game and starting over every time you quit the game.  DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!  Ubisoft has made no attempts to fix this problem either, leaving lots of people (myself included) extremely frustrated.UPDATE: Ubisoft tech support was finally able to fix thsi for me by having me download a different ubosft installer.  Still, I'm not changing this rating, as this is something they should fix across the board with a pushed update.

number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												Child of Light is a bit of a rarety on steam, for several reasons. 1st, it needs you to install some third party pseudo platform from ubisoft. If that's a sticking point for you then don't read any more, because the rest of the review is quite positive.2nd, its kinda in the realm of a visual novel, but without any of the drag along standards that keep visual novels geared towards older teens. If you want a story driven game that you could relax while letting your kid brother play at your grandma's house, here you have one.3rd, this is a short and easy game. Not that this is bad, just different. None of that "Hours into a dungeon and still no save point." The whole game took me just over 12 hours on casual setting. There is something to be said for an easy dungeon that is just long enough to chew that last piece of rhyming dialogue, before the next one.Graphics are top notch, though it is getting rare to see a new game that graphics aren't awesome in. Still worth mentioning, because its not about detailed realistic graphics that a hudred people coded together in a secret room any more. Instead what makes graphics shine is grabbing onto an artistic vision and being true to it throughout the game, which Child of Light definitely does gorgeously.The music is okay, at least what there is of it. It felt a couple of times like they ran out of funding for their orchestra only 30% through the recordings. Some silence here and there, and a couple of somewhat obvious loops.Personally, I very much enjoyed this game. I really hope to encounter not a sequel, but a series of games based on this style.Here are the subjective numbers:10/10 graphics4/10 music and sound9/10 story0/10 first person shooter experience8/10 game experience10/10 storybook experience

content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
												Child of Light is a somewhat short but still fun take on the RPG genre.  I played the game on the casual difficulty, there is also an option for hardcore difficulty but I'm not sure what that changes that makes to the gameplay.You start off as a girl named Aurora who begins a journey in another land.  At the start of the game you are only limited to walking along the ground however you will soon be granted the gift of flight and the game takes off from there.  After learning to fly you'll begin exploring the world of Lemuria and gaining companions to explore the world with you and fight the evil your tasked to fight.  The combat in the game is active turn based combat with the ability to have your turn or the enemies turn interupted.  There is the waiting phase and the casting phase.  If you attack an enemy in the casting phase they will lose their attack, while if the enemy attacks you in that phase you lose your turn.  There are skills both passive and active (friendly or enemy) that can speed up or slow down your waiting/casting bar.  There are not to many complicated enemies in the game.  Most enemies are pretty easy to decipher what they are weak to (Water/Fire/Lightning/Light) and you are able to slot some gems into your weapons/armour to plan for them.  As well some characters have type specific damge.And moving into Characters.  The game features a wide array of various side kicks to help Aurora in her quest.  The side characters have a unique look and feel to them.  Your elemental light companion will be your main companion through the whole game and does add some uniqueness to the game.  He has the ability to find hidden areas as well as aid in battle or heal Aurora outside of battle.  However when the battles begin is where the most of the characters begin to feel kind of generic.  Most of the characters have very similar abilities outside of a select few.  For the most part they have a single target attack, multi target attack and then a spell of some sort.  For my play through I only used 3 or 4 of I think the 8 avaiilable side characters.  You also gain levels fairly frequently which lets you keep adding to the skill tree.  The skill tree seems large at first, however the amount of levels gained, the tree fills quickly.  But progressing through the skill tree doesn't provide as big a reward as it should, most of it is just increasing damage for certain abilities.The enemies do also fall into the generic sorts in battle.  There isn't the biggest diversity of enemy types and then some are reused for the different element types (Fire/Water/Lightning), but there's enough types you won't see the same ones over and over gain the whole game.The story is good, nothing ground breaking or exremely memorable.  But it does have it's moments that keep you interested in it.The art is probably the biggest thing that I enjoyed about the game.  The game has a very unique/interesting art style and while not everyone may like it, I felt it suits the game's story and overall feel of the game.  There are variety of unique locations in the game and the art does make them feel unique and makes the game enjoyable to explore. The levels/areas in the game are fairly straight forward.  There are some puzzles and hidden areas to find, but for the most part each area is pretty simple and straight forward to go through.  There is a little bit of backtracking throughout the game but not enough that it gets frustratiing.The game is a uPlay activated game and for some that's a big issue.  I've never really had any big issues with uPlay that haven't got resolved quickly.  The game does go on sale fairly frequently and I would suggest picking it up on sale as it is fairly short and not overly difficult.  Also the DLC is not realy required however I did enjoy the Golem so I feel that might be worth picking up with the game.  Overall if you are looking for a not to difficult active turn based RPG with unique visuals than this game should meet all those requirements.  If you are looking for a lengthy adventure, or a more challenging task, than this is something you may want to pass over.  I enjoyed the game for what it was and it was enjoyable to play through.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												An RPG with a beautiful watercolour artstyle and a lovely soundtrack to boot. The difference between this game and other turn-based RPGs is that each character's move is set on a timeline, with the player having the ability to slow the speed of each enemy's move, creating a more tactical approach to fighting than just waiting for your next turn to occur. The story is really well set out as well, with a great cast of characters and conversations in the style of poems. The only downside to the game is that you need to run UPlay in order to play it, but if you can overlook that then you'll find a great hidden gem from the past year's games.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												There are times when you encounter good games. There are times when you encounter great games.And then you encounter Child of Light.This is not only a game but a masterpiece, a love poem, a gift for your senses. In this game you take the role of Aurora, a princess who passed away due to a physical ailment she contracted and wakes up to find herself in the lands of Lemuria. She seeks to reunite with her father and save her kingdom from the claws of the Black Queen.This might sound very cliché and all, you might already have an idea of how the story develops and you might even be right, but what makes this game valuable is not the story it tells but rather how it tells it.Every conversation will be in rhyme (ABCB style) unraveling Aurora and her companion's story. The gameplay is smooth, natural and so intuitive you can stop playing the game for a year and get back to it in a matter of minutes. The art is incredibly beautiful, the animation combines both 3D and 2D elements, making it top eyecandy material. The soundtrack is mystical, takes you to an amazing journey through the lands of Lemuria, makes you dream, feel the game, taking the Child of Light experience to its fullest. The characters are very unique, every one of them will be an irreplaceable link in your party, and their story will make them not only pawns in your war, but friends.And Aurora F**KING FLIES around the screen, making the scenaries totally enjoyable in every perspective. This is a feature I'd love to see in more games.For once I can say I've fallen in love with a Ubisoft game.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												Child of Light is one of the most beautiful games in the world.There's no doubt that the game is mostly story driven, but it's also wonderful in every other aspect. Sure, there's a horrible third-party DRM involved (Uplay), but that shouldn't stop you from buying this game. Anyone who skipped buying it for that reason, or for any reason at all, is missing out.Boasting exquisite art that amazes the eyes down to the finest detail, playing Child of Light is akin to walking through a picture book. From Aurora's intricate character model to the resplendent backdrops present throughout the world of Lemuria, the game never ceases to impress with its visual glory. Moreover, the ability to fly is granted to the player very early on, allowing you to explore Lemuria as you wish.Battle in Child of Light is largely similar to typical turn based systems in other games, though there are still some twists that make it unique and perhaps, slightly difficult. Good timing of moves in particular is extremely important to triumph over the various monsters that you will encounter during your journey.Multiplayer isn't a totally fleshed out feature of the game, but it's possible. During battle, a second player may assist you by controlling Aurora's companion, Igniculus, to slow or stun single targets. This allows you to focus on planning and executing your moves rather than having to bother with micromanagement simultaneously. It's perfectly possible to handle both tasks on your own if playing by yourself, however.Child of Light's soundtrack was composed by Cœur de pirate (Béatrice Martin), a tremendously talented singer/songwriter. I've personally purchased the soundtrack (which is available on her website) for the sole reason that it was a pleasure to listen to.Naturally, this game's winning asset is its impeccable story - one that's heartbreaking and heartwarming at the same time, albeit easy to follow and understand. Saying any more would simply ruin the serenity of its plot, so I'll leave it to you to find out for yourself!

												This pretty, sweet and rather short fairy tale has nothing really great or novel about it. The story is your typical "little magical girl and her friends against the forses of darkness". The gameplay consists of a mildly explorable action-adventure overworld and an active time turn-based battle system. Watercolors-on-paper graphics create a feeling of a kid's book come alive. Nothing about it is groundbreaking, but everything is exceptionally well-crafted and fits together so well that it becomes hard to put down. A cozy and heartwarming experience among the world of bloody power fantasies.

Posted: July 15, 2016
Pleasently suprised by Child of Light!I had this game in my library ever since its release but never got around to give it a shot.The art direction is really superb. Great visual style with an outstanding soundtrack (piano by Béatrice Martin, aka Coeur de Pirate). My only wish would have been if the soundtrack been possible to buy as DLC since it is not. (if interested, you can acquire it on either iTunes or here:   Website link[musique.coeurdepirate.com])The combat gameplay is all turn-based so it is not "so simple" as it may seems. As for non-combats, you have some quests to do, which can unlock some more companions that follows you in your adventure. All companions offer a different set of skills and abilities for the turn-based combat. Enemies all have weakness to some type of attack/damage type whether magical or melee. Experimenting with different combos is another strong suite of this game!Story is pretty much your "already seen, already played out" but I'm still fine with it.Overall, this is a game that I wholeheartedly recommend for either adults and even for kids... or ever better, parents playing this with their kid!

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Look, i'm not the type of person who usually plays these kind of games. I tend to stick with larger Tripple A titles from larger companies, and may sometimes jump into smaller, 2D, indie or story based games, but this game just blew me away.The mixture of a great story with a fantastic soundtrack, and beautiful art design (so good). I remember exploring this world and seeing the amazing mountains and buildings in the background, and once even noticed a giant walking in the distance. The beauty of the game really blew me away, and the beautiful soundtrack made it better. It was so beautiful and fun exploring this world, and it left me wanting more when I finished. The combat was intense, interesting and really fun as well. I was really satisfied everytime I won a battle. The boss battles were really the highlight of the combat in my opinion. I had more fun fighting the bosses than the actual creatures you come across while exploring, and this is obviously how it should be.The only negative thing I came across was that the menu was so obviouly made for consoles. It was awkward navigating at times and I often made mistakes, but it's something that I got used to and didn't mind too much, it's only a slight issue.Overall it's a great game that you should buy. 9/10 for those who care about scores...

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												While many would call this a children's title based off its presentation and appearance, it has a bit of depth in terms of a complex and somewhat fun combat system.  Its difficulty can be a bit underwhelming at times, but battles place a heavy reliance on planning, buffs, timing, interrupting enemy attacks whilst preventing your own from being disrupted and your usual RPG elements.  Namely, elemental weaknesses or some enemies being heavily resistant to physical attacks, but crumble under magic.  Or those that stage counterattacks to physical attacks, etc.  That part feels very Final Fantasy.Unfortunately, the depth and sense of achievement that would come from this Active Time Battle inspired element disappears when the game's relatively low difficulty comes into effect.  You are never in such danger, even by the midgame, that a health potion or a debuff spell doesn't completely turn the tides in your favor.  To that end, I do feel the game was intended for a younger audience.Nitpicking aside, it holds very true to being a digital fairytale - if a somewhat dry one.  The story is not particularly engaging, so most of what will carry you along is the combat system and the overall charm the world itself presents.  There are mountains walking about with cities on their backs, visible in some area backgrounds far in the distance and that you scale from the ground up that gives some good flavor to the world overall.  But the slow pace of the story makes the beautiful watercolor backdrops something you'd probably be more satisfied taking in bites rather than trying to playing the whole game through in one sitting.Overall, it's a decent attempt.  It could do with a few more engaging or deep elements, but it is what it is - an indie-game-lookalike with a decent combat system and some charming decor.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2014
												I'm deeply ambivalent about Child of Light.  Its target demographic seems to be tween girls, which doesn't quite describe me, but I did find it engaging enough to spend the 18-ish hours of a complete play-through with all the side quests -- well, nearly all; about which more later.  Despite that, though, I finished with the sense that it's simply not that good overall.  I'm glad I only paid $15 for it.On the one hand, much of the game is frankly gorgeous.  The watercolor world,, layered and constantly in motion behind the primary action, is brilliantly done.  So is the character animation while roaming that world: Aurora's hair billowing around her is nearly a character in its own right, and adorable.  There's a great deal to be said for a game that is purely wonderful just to look at.On the other hand... it's not a particularly good game.  The most that can be said for it is that the difficulty ramp is tuned fairly well, with the significant foes in the final stages of the game being approximately as challenging as the corresponding ones in the early stages.  Beyond that, well... there's a great deal of repetition, of "oh, these are just like those only they're ice now instead of fire" cookie-cutter critters, and not much actual variety throughout.  The combat mechanic looks highly varied on paper, but in practice I found myself using essentially identical tactics against every foe, and all those options were pointless.  The thin veneer of "puzzles" in world-navigation in the end amounted only to "find the heavy thing nearby and drag it onto the pressure plate," repeated several times.And oh my stars, the writing.  The writing is bad.  Quite bad, really; and bad in multiple ways.A lot's been said about the game's couching all of its text in rhyme, and yes; it's all true.  The writing is clunky, forced, sophomoric -- so bad that I wonder whether it's a translation from another language.  The game is from Ubisoft Montreal, after all; perhaps it was written in French and then translated?  If so, I hope the French is considerably better.  In English, it's not only bad but illiterate.  The game consistently writes "fair" when the right word is "fare," for example.  That's one that a competent editor would have spotted a mile away.Beyond the quality of the poetry (or lack thereof) there's the story.  The story, too, is bad.  It's thin.  Insipid.  Narratively it's incredibly weak -- nothing you actually do has any relevance to the story; the mechanics of the game turn out to be unrelated time-filler in between cutscenes that actually tell the story.  The cutscenes themselves, all strung together, add up to very little storytelling time, and that's proof right there that there's just not much story here to be told in the first place.  There are other fundamental design and production flaws as well.  The mechanical powerup system is left coyly to the player's "experimentation" -- a ridiculous conceit given the availability of Google.  One of the significant side-quests was also, as far as I could tell, buggy and therefore unavailable in my play-through.  I consulted a number of walkthroughs, and they would say things like "go to this location and then pass through the village to the right until you reach the girl with the ! over her head.  Talk to her and she will tell you about the side quest" ... but there was no such character in that location or village.  Oops.I said above that the game is gorgeous, and it is -- the bulk of the time.  The world-traversal artwork, where you spend the bulk of the game (and in more static fashion where combat takes place) is terrific.  The animation of the Aurora model is similarly delightful, as I mentioned above.  Other characters' animation is disappointingly weak by comparison, though; combat winds up looking more cartoony and less engaging as a result.  Worst of all are the conversation interludes: they're ugly.  The detailed, multilayered watercolor world is set aside and instead we get zoomed-in three-quarter profiles of the characters, rendered in a rough, almost crayon style.  It's hugely jarring, especially since the poor artwork is invariably accompanied by worse (rhymed) dialog.... and yet, on balance, I'm recommending the game!  A lot of that is because it is inexpensive -- if it were a $40 first-tier title, I would absolutely tell you to save your money.  But $15 for twelve to twenty hours of entertainment is not that bad, especially if you compare it to things like movie theater rates (2 hours for $10!).  And it was entertaining -- despite gritting my teeth every time I had to get through a conversation scene's appalling rhyme and sub-par artwork, I was hooked, wanting to see the game through to the end.  I don't think I can honestly recommend against a game that I cared that much about despite significant flaws.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												This side scrolling RPG game is full of gorgeous art, tells a heartfelt story and has classic turnbased gameplay. It just has a little problem with details.POSITIVES -And honestly if that's what you want in a game, Child of Light is completely for you. Its gameplay is very simple, a little repetitive and not complicated, like the usual RPG. It'll throw in stat boosts, debuffs and a rock paper scissors formula as the game goes on, but nothing that's too difficult or new. So if you're fine with that old school feel, you'll be impressed with the game.The art is painted, water colored and ... well, amazing. The music ranges from soft and to intense; the developer really knew what she was doing. The atmosphere is also done so well, from the dark and moody beginning, to the huge and open bright fields after you've gained your new powers.And really the feel of this game is what helps the story. You play as a young girl named Aurora who's been thrown down the rabbit hole, everything straight out of an old child book. And it really works. This coming-of-age tale is detailed and imaginative, but still very simple. It's a tale of good vs. evil, growing up and even tragedy. Running through a lonely and dark forest in the beginning of the game, only to shout a cheer when you gain your wings and sword, it just feels triumphant. Our main protagonist goes from being a slightly selfish princess and child, to someone who takes on responsibility, even if it means making tough decisions and charging into a dark world that isn't so different from our own.NEGATIVES -The few problems of Child of Light are mainly its tedious puzzles, lack of development in its side cast and rushed ending.I had no problem with the old feel of gameplay or skill set, like some people do. But after hours of playing the game, even in its last dungeon, you'll be maneuvering around the same spikes, pushing boxes and following clues you've seen before. It would have been nice to have a little more variety.The side characters are extremely endearing filled with personality, even if a little cliché. But after their initial introduction, they barely get any extra personal touch and their problems don't get mentioned or resolved until the end of the game......which is rushed. And that's unfortunate, because it's VERY rushed. The game has a way of giving a good poetic feel when it comes to its plot. And certain things in this sort of fantasy setting aren't meant to make complete sense, but Child of Light still has it all structured. So it's pretty jarring when the game ends rather quickly, really quickly. It resolves everything, but it seems much more forced than everything you've been through so far. And certain plot twists and events don't get explained fully or at all at the end.CONCLUSION -Child of Light is really an amazing game and one of my favorites for 2014. It has everything put together so well and it’s just lovely. But the details are sometimes a little muddy.Those issues didn't distract me enough though to not HIGHLY RECOMMEND this game to anyone.Wonderful. Bravo. I want a sequel.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												As a player of console-style RPGs, I'm really happy this game exists.  It's a beautiful example of how art direction can add so much to solid gameplay and a classic, if well-worn, story.  The game's combat system is really easy for any veteran of the genre (which is why they included a Hard mode), but works well and integrates well into the tactics you can do with your party.  It's solid, it's fun, and it strikes that balance where battles don't frustrate you into hating whenever they crop up, but they also interest you enough to put thought into the fight.It's really the art direction that sells this game, though.  Everything is a dreamy watercolor and ink, perfectly suited for a children's story book.  Coupled with the excellent music, I found myself completely involved in Aurora's adventure, wanting her to succeed and happy that I was there helping her out in a way.  I cringed at her bare feet on the rocky ground, chuckled at every time she had to sternly correct people that she wasn't a princess, smiled at her childish and loving dialogue, fought not to cry at her moment of despair, and sometimes even found myself staring in awe as she took on grim creatures for the sake of Lemuria and her friends.It's a fairy tale, so don't expect any plot twists, but it makes no bones about what it is, and as such people who come in expecting to be sucker-punched should probably stick with the games that do that kind of plot, like OFF or The Witch's House.  This isn't to say that the game lacks emotional torque; I've found it very difficult to get past teary-eyed even at the most intense moments in games I've played, and this thing had me fighting not to cry around the midway point.  I knew every last thing that would happen, and yet the telling was beautiful enough to make it seem fresh and new.  That's the core of it, really; it could have easily fallen apart with how cliched everything could be said to be, but it believes so deeply in its story that I ended up believing too, and that experience is what makes the difference.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
												I'm not entirely sure what drew me to Child of Light.  Was it the beautiful watercolor art?  The plaintive music?  The little girl that reminded me of my own daughter?  All I can say is that the previews exhibited an intangible quality that made the game one that I had to purchase.First and foremost, Child of Light is a classic fairy tale, told simply and in a straightforward manner.  It is filled with the tropes one might expect - wicked stepmother, lost child, an impossible quest - and is also possessed of the melancholy that the best fairy tales have, a feeling intensified by the haunting flute melody.  This effect is also heightened by the beautiful art direction.  I felt like I was watching a painted book illustration come to life, and when I first started the game, I spent a minute or two just marvelling at the way Aurora's hair swirled as if underwater.Child of Light is also a role-playing game, and although some of its mechanics fall short, the main battle system is wonderfully and unexpectedly engaging.  The basic concept is simple: during combat a single time bar shows who is the next to act, whether it be a member of your party or a monster.  Chosen actions and haste attributes affect how long it takes to reach the end of the bar and perform your action.  And if you hit a monster (or vice versa) in the small space of time right before it acts, you interrupt the creature and send it flying back down the time bar.This one modification to a pretty standard combat system adds a layer of excitement and calculation.  Chain-interrupting a monster over and over again feels utterly dominating; trying to ensure that your party avoids interruption can be nerve-wrackingly tense.  And when you encounter later monsters and bosses that punish you for interrupting them, the sudden scramble to figure out an appropriate strategy is enjoyably frenetic.The supporting game systems - skill trees, potions, gem crafting - are less polished, almost like afterthoughts.  Rather than enhancing the play, they feel like something tacked on just to give the player additional things to do.  That leads to another potential criticism: Child of Light is not the most difficult game, and someone yearning for challenging depth may be disappointed.Add my feeling that the ending was a bit abrupt, and the conclusion is that Child of Light could have done with a few more coats of polish.  That being said, I still loved my time playing the game, the sensation of falling from the present into a magical and wondrous world.  For me, Child of Light is an easy game to recommend.--- Closing Eyes is Magic ---"Ready?" he asks, and Melly nods.  He pinches a blue plastic brick between two fingers and lifts it up before his daughter.  "And now," he says, "I will make this disappear!"  Melly nods again, solemn as a statue.  She doesn't smile much, not anymore, but he is hopeful that this will do the trick.He holds the brick for a heartbeat longer.  Then he takes his other hand and swirls it.  "Abracadabra," he says.  "Hocus pocus. . .  Now close your eyes!"Melly does so immediately.  A faint tink falls somewhere in the room.  "Look," he says.  "It's gone!"It is gone.  Melly jumps up and down and claps her hands; pleased, he spreads his arms in triumph.  "Again!" she says.  "Daddy, do it again, please!"He knows he shouldn't, but he no longer has the heart to refuse her much.  And so he does it again: he holds another brick out, he waves his hand, he incants the magic words.  Except this time when he shouts for her to close her eyes, she keeps them open.  Her gaze tracks the brick as he tosses it over his shoulder.He sighs.  "Potato," he says, invoking his pet name for her, "you didn't close your eyes.""I wanted to see what you did."  Melly says.  Her forehead creases, and for a moment he sees the ghost of her mother there.  "You just threw it!  That's not magic."He rolls his eyes, exaggerating for effect.  "Well  of course not.  That's not where the magic is."  He takes his index finger and places it on her forehead, firmly.  "Closing eyes is magic."Melly hesitates, then agrees.  And when he performs the trick a third time, she closes her eyes.  When she opens them, the brick is gone, he is grinning, and she laughs and laughs and laughs.***The next afternoon as they walk home from kindergarten, Melly trips over cracks, stumbles over rocks, bumps into mailboxes.  After the third time she falls, he examines her and frowns.  "Potato," he says, "are you walking with your eyes closed?"Melly smiles.  One hand grips her father's; the other is outstretched, palm up with fingers lightly curled, as if holding an invisible hand, or perhaps one that has been missing for the past half year.  "Closing eyes is magic," she says, gently.  "I remembered."Startled, he opens his mouth.  He should say something, but he does not know what.  So instead he watches his daughter float along, a dream on her face.  A few steps later, he closes his own eyes.  And then he opens them again to cross the street.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												A type of game that we are not used to seeing developed by Ubisoft, "Child of Light" is a successful experiment of showcasing the JRPG genre with a really good story, and a fascinating art style once more to the Western audience.=STORY=A girl named Aurora wakes up in the world of Lemuria after falling asleep due to a physical ailment when stolen from her home. After meeting a unique firefly named Igniculus, she learns that Lemuria's celestial bodies, the Sun, Moon, and Stars, have been stolen by the Dark Queen. While she is more concerned with re-uniting with her father, she is tasked with recovering the Sun, Moon, and Stars to save Lumeria before she does. Along the way, she will come across various opponents, and allies to assist her on the journey and in battle.=GAMEPLAY=Child of Light is primarily focused on the JRPG genre, with the battle sequence elements inspired by Final Fantasy and Grandia. You will have to wait until it is your turn to cast on the battle timeline to attack and ultimately defeat your opponents. However, if you get struck while on the "Cast" portion, you will be interrupted and will have to wait until you can cast once more. Each character has physical and magic attacks, although of course, some will specialize with one over the other. Aside from that, we have the open world type gameplay. Traveling to different towns and destinations are pretty straightforward, but no one said you can't explore. Each town you visit will have some sort of issue you must tackle before you can advance; it reminds me of Dust: An Elysian Tail pretty recently, but that game will be for another day. Towns will also have side quests if you are into doing it. Some of them do reward you with additional allies in the game, which is beneficial for the harder boss fights ahead. Something that I was really interested in but got bored of towards the end was the rhyming that they made in the game. It does sound like a nice concept to use when characters are talking to one another, but it seemed a little bit forced at times.=VISUALS/ART=Visually speaking, it is really awesome to look at when you're so into the game. According to the reveal at GDC Europe 2013 by Patrick Plourde, it is said that the art style is inspired by the films of Studio Ghibli and Yoshitaka Amano (known for his commissioned illustrations for Final Fantasy). The art is really pretty to look at, especially the way Aurora looks at one point in the game...my goodness...she's beautiful...I wish I knew how to elaborate on this subject more, but I'll leave that to those who can actually draw, unlike me.=MUSIC=Musically speaking, I find it interesting and really nice to listen to. However, my only complaint is the amount of repetition for the music pieces involved in regular fights and boss fights equally.=FINAL VERDICT=Giving the chance of bringing more publicity to the JRPG genre, packed with a beautiful looking art style, a great story, and nice soundtrack, with the expense of tryhard-ish rhymes, "Child of Light" is worth getting if you're big on other games like Final FantasyOn a scale of Meatloaf to Pizza, I give this game: A "Spaghetti and Meatballs" rating.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
												Even though Child of Light is tagged as a platformer, the tactical battles play a much more significant role in the game. It's a unique and engaging system where success depends on selecting the right characters for the encounter, utilizing the skills in an intelligent way, and a unique system of timing the attacks. Beautiful visuals are accompanied by exellent music. Music I'd actually listen to outside of the game. I almost quit playing after tiring of forced rhymes, and a story I wasn't that invested in. Around the middle of the game, I started enjoying the story a bit more. There were times when the story touched an emotional chord. Combat could become a little repetitive, but a new challenge usually wasn't too far around the corner so I persevered during those times. The music in the final battle was like a reward for my persistence. Controlling the flow of combat with Igniculus was rewarding in its own right, just as much as selecting the right characters for a particular encounter and making smart skill choices.A new game+ mode exists for those looking for more, but I think it is a 1 playthrough type of game. A playthrough which I enjoyed more than I first thought I would. For a more detailed review please see my  full review.[www.oneguytoomanygames.com]

content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												Curator Page: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/disastercake#curationOverall a very enjoyable romp through a colorful dream world where you can fly!I completed the game in about 10 hours.The battle system is heavily inspired by Grandia's active time combat with interuptions coupled with Final Fantasy 10's feature to swap team members in and out whenever you want.  In addition it has the twist that you can hover over a single enemy and click to "slow" them with light.Some notes:Pulls a lot of similar classic JRPG inspirations as my own game, Soul Saga.Plays and feels like a polished indie game, but was actually created by Ubisoft, a rather large AAA studio.An interesting european take on the JRPG genre.Beautiful water color styled 2D graphics.There are 2 difficulty modes: Easy and Hard.  I played on easy and, to be expected, it was quite easy.  I never tried hard.Healing is done in a unique way where you find glowing bushes that spawn a series of orbs you then move your cursor over in the correct order to spawn healing orbs.Classic European evil godmother and step sisters type fairytale story (with its own unique twists) that takes place in a surreal dream world.You can fly early on in the game, making exploration quite fun.Clever and interesting puzzles in the level design related to your light creating cursor and flying ability, though the puzzle variety is very limited.No equipment, instead you combine gems you find to determine stats.A few quick side quests (12 total), but mostly just a linear main storyline.All of the characters talk in rhyme.  Apparently they designed the game to be like an interactive fairy tale poem.Some weird uPlay login system, apparently a secondary DRM.No Steam achievements as of this review posting.  Apparently the uPlay thing keeps its own achievement records.Took about 10 hours for me to do a nearly 100% playthrough. (missed one side quest)There's some sort of new game plus, but I haven't looked into it as I felt satisfied with the amount I playedA small critique, but it feels like the ending is a little rushed compared to the pacing of the rest of the game.  By just my intuition it seems like there might have been one last dungeon planned but got cut out for the scope.  Perhaps related: apparently the art director passed away a year before the project launched.  At the end of the credits his name, Thomas Rollus, appears as dedicated to.  As a game developer myself I was curious to know more about how an interruption with such a critical role affected the project, but couldn't find anymore information.  If anyone knows, please feel free to share.
