content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												Don't let the cute exterior of this fantastically designed game fool you.  Beneath the cute, cherubic face of the main character, Aurora, lies a deep plot of betrayal, death, despair, witty dialogue, and complex emotional situations.  While the characters speak largely in prose, sometimes the rhyming seems a bit forced or tedious, but overall, this doesn't detract from the appeal of this game.  You may need a dictionary or thesaurus handy for some lines, as Ubi is definitely flexing their literary muscles with this title.UbiArt has found the perfect fusion between picturesque platforming adventure games and true, turn-based classic rpgs.  Using a battle system somewhat reminiscent of the battle systems in Final Fantasy 6 through 10 and a skill system something like out of 10 and 11, the player is given an experience that will probably be familiar, but with new aspects to it, such as the ability to choose an enemy to slow down.  The combat system is further diversified with the use of special crystals that the characters can equip in order to enhance various combat abilities.I just spent two days marathoning this game on hard and feeling very satisfied with what I had played.  While somewhat short in terms of rpgs at roughly 20 hours without DLC, there's no shortage of things to do in the game.  The tendency to skip battles will be high with the ability to simply fly around many of them, but you may not want to.  Boss battles tend to be pretty hard and need a good bit of planning to get through.  I'm honestly not sure if that holds true on lower difficulties.  One nice feature of the game is that if you've missed a side quest or mini-quest along the way, that's not a problem.I think the two best features of this game are the local co-op and the use of the light-based puzzles.  The second player takes control of Igniculus, a small light elemental that helps Aurora at the start of her adventure.  Using either the mouse or the second player controller (controllers work best in this game, imo), the second player can move around, gather items for the player, light up rooms, and slow down enemies.   This is a great feature for gamers with kids that actually want to take part in their parent's activities.  Even if they don't listen to you and go off and do their own thing, it won't be devastatingly bad, except maybe during a boss battle.The light puzzles caught me offguard at first, but once I got used to them, they were fairly easy, yet still interesting.  More games integrating puzzles into their gameplay could definitely learn from the examples in this game.  I nearly got thrown off by one puzzle at the Gate to the Palace of the Sun, but was able to figure it out with some careful observation.The soundtrack for this game is amazingly well done.  Songs are sufficiently long enough that being stuck on a stage doesn't become an experience of wanting to pull your ears off of your head, and the boss music is sufficiently epic for fighting demons, dragons, and things of that sort.  Perhaps even more fittingly epic than many other games that I've played.

												So here is the thing - if you like Uplay, or aren't annoyed by having to use another steam-like client in addition to steam every single time you want to play this game - consider my review a thumbs up and move on to the second portion of my review.The following reasons for hating Uplay are my reasons for giving this a thumbs down (this is ubisoft developed)1. Steam already exists.2. Uplay is chewing up more than 0% of my resources.3. There is no way to bypass Uplay to simply launch Child of Light.4. Uplay pop-ups. 5. Steam ALREADY EXISTS AND HAS ACHIEVED MARKET SATURATION.Please - if any part of Ubisoft is reading this, add it to the pile, we hate Uplay! We hate uplay, even the people who love your games (and I really enjoyed what I played of child of light!) hate uplay. Stop foisting it on people in an attempt to replicate valve - you will never replicate valve, as evidence by the fact that I am writing this review on steam, and so have many others.The game itselfNot without its flaws, the rhyming gets a bit repetitive, and the combat feels shallow in certain ways (repetitive abilities, recycled enemy art) yet is satisfying and the story and environment are delightful. I really enjoyed how it fused a fairy tale style with JRPG mechanics and was intrigued to see how it concluded. If you enjoy JRPGs, and like what you've seen from the screenshots and video I would hazard a purchase, just make sure you have an hour set aside to try it out in case you need a refund. I honestly would have happily finished this game, but every single time I went to play it, Uplay functioned as some sort of harassing butler that kept jabbering at me about sales and uplay points or some such nonsense. I'd give the games a thumbs up - but the shrieking visage of Uplay  is now linked to it via pavlovian response, so I give the two of them a thumbs down. If Uplay finally dies a death I will return to this game and edit my review.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
												Yes, I know: UPlay is terrible. We all know that. So what if you can stomach that crap?First: I really, really wanted to like this game. It is beautiful to look at and a joy to explore. Everything's hand painted.That said, you are still left with an Extremely Hard turn-based strategy combat game. If you are exceedingly good at those Disciples games, then my recommendation is to buy this game. You will love it. If you are not exceedingly good at those Disciples games, you may hate this game.Guess which one I am? I just rage-uninstalled the game after my final, tedious boss fight. The highlight had to be finally humbling myself and moving down to the casual difficulty (inexplicably, there are only two difficulty levels). Even then, I was no closer to beating this particular boss.Better yet, after failing out of combat this last time, I ran around and collected little wisps to replenish my health and magic, but who the hell cares: I went back into that super-hard fight minus all the potions I used in desperation the last time. I had one of those moments like "oh yeah, this happened last time."I found potions in these ornate boxes with so much fun little mini-fanfare - like collecting candy - only to blow them all in one bad fight.If you need to farm, the game fails to convey it. You sure don't get much from the random combats out in the world. There is almost always a resource cost for any combat useful enough to gain XP from. As a result, I never had enough resources. Add to that the very last thing that I'm sooo tired of in this genre: The constant action interruptions and revive-fall-revive-run-away stoopid-loop that seems to characterize the games in this genre.I keep wanting to like this genre. I keep being disappointed. And yes, fanboys: I suck. So what. If you suck too, you will come to hate this beautiful horror.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Not for experienced rogue-like RPG players.Yes, it has lovely pastel visuals. Yes, the dialogues rhyme. Yes, it actually has a pleasantly optimized battle system.It is also extremely EASY. I started the game on "Casual" and immediately switched to "Expert" because "Casual" played more like a peaceful demo than an RPG ("Casual", - the name says it all).I mean, I can see why this game would be geared towards people like me - those who enjoy having a strong story, nice visuals, and simpler, easier battle that can just serve the story instead of presenting an additional and parallel challenge.I know we're not in Dark Souls territory here, but I like earning my victories and the Expert mode is barely making me work for it. If it's too easy for me, it's probably too easy for 90% of players out there.This would be a must-have game for youngsters (14-18 year olds) interested in getting into rogue-like RPGs. It's gentle enough, eases you into the battle and has an engrossing story.For experienced players though, the game would get old fast and the characters seem very over-powered for a real challenge to eventually develop.Now, if the previous warning hasn't changed your mind, here are all the wonderful things that this game has to offer.SPOILER WARNINGS (perhaps)In combat there is a time-dependent turn system that allows the player to skip ahead of enemies' turns if the right casts and potions are used. Each actor's time to next action can vary, sometimes spectacularly (you thought you were behind an enemy, but suddenly he is interrupted by your teammate and his TTNA is lengthened). This adds a level of interesting unpredictability to combat gameplay.Another useful bit of info that nobody else has mentioned: during battle the firefly glims generated when Igniculus "shakes" the light bushes are worth about twice Igniculus' light meter. For optimal utilization of the glims, always try to capture about half of the glims, then let the rest float around until the light meter is running low again. Otherwise, once the meter is full, any additional glims are going to waste.Ubisoft made the welcome change here of shifting cleric-type casts like healing and enemy debuffs outside of the turn system and onto the Igniculus character. This enables a more offensive dynamic to develop with PCs and focuses on matching attacks to enemies, timing offense and defense (NB: when enemy and player character are within the timer's "red zone" the preferred action should be defense), and generally making your party more proactive and less micro-managed.I personally spend most of battle with the Igniculus trigger enabled on one of the enemies, according to each of their turns in the battle sequence and their action speed.Party members start out "pre-typed" so to speak - Aurora is clearly a mage-type build, despite the big MFKN sword she receives at the beginning. The skill tree however, offers an opportunity to shift the character type more towards a melee fighter with strength and HP boosts. If that is your intention, I would recommend to either grind a bit at the beginning to earn Uplay credits that you can redeem for HP and strength bonuses, or maybe to wait for the right party member to join gameplay and mould it into the fighter that you want to have up-front and in the face of your enemies.Sadly there is no cover system, no grid and no distinction between melee and ranged fighting - a mage cast is equivalent to a physical attack, and each character has a primary physical attack. Honestly at my current level my characters are so OP that I can't tell if it makes a difference or not. The only noticeable thing is that my fighter character has MP that she never uses unless there's a major crisis like HP drastically low while Igniculus' meter is empty - in which case she can heal any party member (as a turn-based action). This permits for the fighter character to occasionally squeeze out a buff for the entire party at the beginning of a battle and just sit on the rest of the MP until needed at a later time.The gem upgrade system was also nice (called "oculi" in-game) with a no-nonsense elemental interdependence (fire, water, lightning) that allows you to have ridiculously unfair advantages against enemies. A typical attack makes almost triple the damage if the correct oculus (can I decline it that way?) is applied to the weapon.One thing that bothered me at the beginning was that when Aurora walked, the feet were misaligned with the path on which she was walking (it looked pretty half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥for all the effort that was put into creating the backgrounds in the first place), but after the first boss-battle where the additional ability of flight is unlocked, and implicitly moving speed increases, that is no longer an issue.That being said, it's a nice game that's difficult to put down. If I had kids, I'd let them play this.Will update my review if my opinion changes before I beat the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												(disclaimer: I had heard that this game was easy so I played it on the harder difficulty, this may have underlined some of the faults and influenced my opinion)The overworld and sub-quests are not bad, but I won't go into much detail, because plenty of people talk about them.My complaint is with the interruption system in combat. If a character is attacked while preparing an action, they get knocked back on the timeline. The problem is that this is a feast or famine system; you're either obliterating the enemy or caught in an unwinnable situation.In the second half of the game, there are enemy combinations who will caste haste on their entire team and slow on your team. Add to that, that there can be 3 enemies, but only 2 of you. This leads to battles where you're consistently getting knocked back or put into a situation where all you can do is block or try to heal (basically never being able to damage the enemies to give yourself a chance). Then, you try the fight again and get a bit luckier (or are better equiped) and win easily in 2-3 turns.It really feels unbalanced, and I didn't enjoy it.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												Child of Light was one of those games for me, which I was hearing about from every corner, yet I was not sure if I should get it or not because it looks "childish" and "cartoonish". Well, I bought it during the Steam summer sale for 3,74€, I can say that this amount of money is well worth for the game. It took me a little over 9 hours to finish this game and I can say that it was time well spent. However, I dont see myself replaying this game at all. It's like one of thoose books where once you know who is the killer it doesnt motivate you to reread it because you know what will happen in the story. Your actions in the game doesnt alter the game ending in any way.In my opinion, this game is indeed kinda childish. I can see my younger sister to enjoy it, since she love stories like this but this game was definitely not made for adults. Its not the story and the characters which kept me playing this game, even the combat can be repetetive after some time.... but it was the execution and the presentation of the game which was presented to the player in a very stylish fashion. I cant say that I agree with the full price on this game, but if you can manage to get it for 50%-75% off, I say go for it. It is a beautiful one time ride.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												My girlfriend and I just finished Child of Light, and it was quite well done! Here are my thoughts.The visual presentation is stunning. We were both consistently blown away by how beautiful landscapes and characters were. Same goes for the soundtrack - as a pianist with a love of piano music, it resonated with me. Powerful yet serene, sorrowful and joyous.Gameplay was a nice mix between exploration / environment absorption and challenging combat. We played on Casual and felt it was suitable.The characters were each well-developed enough, memorable and provided enough variety combat-wise to make me care! This is often difficult.I absolutely loved the Oculi system - it provided both meaningful upgrades and creativity in crafting. Loads of room to experiment, too! I spent a lot of time wondering about gem combinations, which tier was the highest, can you combine diamond + onyx (yes = spinel!), etc.The co-op play was outstanding, too! GF does not like complicated systems and Igniculus let her help in both exploration and combat. Really reminds me of Wind Waker's Tingle Tuner asymmetric co-op gameplay. I'd love to see more of this approach to co-op.In short, Child of Light was an outstandingly strong game - cohesive, enticing and thoroughly enjoyable. 10/10, would recommend to everyone!

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												UPlay problems aside (sigh, when will they learn....), this is actually an excellent little unique turn-based RPG. Think old style jrpg, but with a side scroller twist. Only a couple hours in, and it's already showing signs of being quite deep with a nice skill tree setup for character progression. Story seems a bit 'childish' (with a name like that, no surprise there) but it looks to be headed in deeper territory. Visually pleasing, with lots of variety to locales and cool effects. Very nice. Also expect plenty of chuckling as the dialogue is almost entirely done in rhymes.Thumbs up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												It's like crime how Child of Light can rob you of your time.The combination of side-scrolling exploration, challenging turn-based tactical gameplay, amusing rhyming dialogues and a wonderful art style makes Child of Light an unusual but enjoyable gem.You'll quickly fall in love with the beatifully drawn landscapes of Lemuria as you travel through its dark forests, mountains and even under the sea. They are typically riddled with secret areas you can sniff out for treasure, puzzles or hidden bosses. Often there'll be more than one path to your destination, making exploration more interesting.During your travels, you'll meet many fun characters who'll give your quests, join you in your adventure, or both. My favourite was a female jester who couldn't do the dialogues in a proper rhyming fashion, allowing the other characters to jump in and correct her. Her healing abilities were also very welcome in a fight, making her one of my most used characters during combat.The combat is turn-based but has a real-time element that lets you delay enemies' turn or slightly heal your party out of turn. Timing this ability is important to winning encounters, as it lets you better use or avoid being the victim of the interrupt mechanic. Interrupting means hitting a character trying to perform an action, resulting in his turn being delayed. If you don't go for the easy difficulty, combat offers good and rewarding challenge that makes you invest time into considering how to specialise your characters.Each character has a network of specialisation trees, offering abilities unique to him while giving you a choice between the different paths. For example, there's a wizard who can specialise in lightning, water or fire, allowing him to excel against certain creature types vulnerable to his focused element. Another character can choose between improving his defense, his offense or his ability to direct enemy attacks against him.A problem that grows as the size of your party increases, is the frequency of level ups. Very quickly you'll be looking at one or multiple level ups after pretty much every battle as your characters gain levels and extra skill points to spend. It becomes tedious looking at the skill tree menu this often.Another part of character customisation is the Oculi system. Oculi are gems you gather and can use kind of like equipment items such as swords and armor in other games. They offer different bonuses depending on color and slot used, and can be combined to form more powerful gems. Oculi juggling gets a little cumbersome, but is nonetheless an important strategic element as you want to equip the right damage and resistance types depending on the opposition of your current area.Apart from having trouble with Steam starting the game through Uplay for some reason initially, the only bug I noticed in the actual game was that sometimes when entering combat, Aurora's (the main character) usually flowing hair wasn't drawn.If you're not playing on Easy difficulty and like to explore and look for secrets, you should expect around 20 hours of gameplay from Child of Light.TIP: While Child of Light offers controller support, I really must recommend using mouse and keyboard. You will need the precision to properly manage the real-time element of the otherwise turn-based combat.TIP: If, like me, you have trouble starting the game through Steam, try launching Uplay directly and start the game from there. After doing that, it's been working for me no problem.

content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
												I picked this up today in the sale and so have barely even started, but I feel compelled to write a review anyway. If you haven't played it, I STRONGLY recommend that you do so. I'm only about an hour into it (up to just beyond the first boss) and I'm already spellbound. It's like a fairytale/Disney movie. The video sequences are all told via beautiful stained-glass scenes (remember the intro to Beauty And The Beast, or Sleeping Beauty? That.) The dialogue is often in rhyming couplets, which lends to the fairytale charm of the game. And don't get me started on the hand-drawn backgrounds or the music. Oh my God, the music. Outside of the Final Fantasy series, this is fast becoming my favourite soundtrack. Speaking of Final Fantasy, the combat is very similar in the sense that it is turn-based, dependant on speed - which I adore. I love the idea of the plot (the sun, moon and stars have been stolen and it's up to you to recover them - fantasy plots are my favourites.) Outside of combat, the game is played via side-scrolling environments. Everything just looks FANTASTIC. It lends further belief to the "games are art" ideology.I got this for just under £3. If you can get it that cheap for yourself, it's a no-brainer. If I'd known it was this great I would have got it a lot sooner, and happily paid the full price.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												(disclaimer: I had heard that this game was easy so I played it on the harder difficulty, this may have underlined some of the faults and influenced my opinion)The overworld and sub-quests are not bad, but I won't go into much detail, because plenty of people talk about them.My complaint is with the interruption system in combat. If a character is attacked while preparing an action, they get knocked back on the timeline. The problem is that this is a feast or famine system; you're either obliterating the enemy or caught in an unwinnable situation.In the second half of the game, there are enemy combinations who will caste haste on their entire team and slow on your team. Add to that, that there can be 3 enemies, but only 2 of you. This leads to battles where you're consistently getting knocked back or put into a situation where all you can do is block or try to heal (basically never being able to damage the enemies to give yourself a chance). Then, you try the fight again and get a bit luckier (or are better equiped) and win easily in 2-3 turns.It really feels unbalanced, and I didn't enjoy it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Not for experienced rogue-like RPG players.Yes, it has lovely pastel visuals. Yes, the dialogues rhyme. Yes, it actually has a pleasantly optimized battle system.It is also extremely EASY. I started the game on "Casual" and immediately switched to "Expert" because "Casual" played more like a peaceful demo than an RPG ("Casual", - the name says it all).I mean, I can see why this game would be geared towards people like me - those who enjoy having a strong story, nice visuals, and simpler, easier battle that can just serve the story instead of presenting an additional and parallel challenge.I know we're not in Dark Souls territory here, but I like earning my victories and the Expert mode is barely making me work for it. If it's too easy for me, it's probably too easy for 90% of players out there.This would be a must-have game for youngsters (14-18 year olds) interested in getting into rogue-like RPGs. It's gentle enough, eases you into the battle and has an engrossing story.For experienced players though, the game would get old fast and the characters seem very over-powered for a real challenge to eventually develop.Now, if the previous warning hasn't changed your mind, here are all the wonderful things that this game has to offer.SPOILER WARNINGS (perhaps)In combat there is a time-dependent turn system that allows the player to skip ahead of enemies' turns if the right casts and potions are used. Each actor's time to next action can vary, sometimes spectacularly (you thought you were behind an enemy, but suddenly he is interrupted by your teammate and his TTNA is lengthened). This adds a level of interesting unpredictability to combat gameplay.Another useful bit of info that nobody else has mentioned: during battle the firefly glims generated when Igniculus "shakes" the light bushes are worth about twice Igniculus' light meter. For optimal utilization of the glims, always try to capture about half of the glims, then let the rest float around until the light meter is running low again. Otherwise, once the meter is full, any additional glims are going to waste.Ubisoft made the welcome change here of shifting cleric-type casts like healing and enemy debuffs outside of the turn system and onto the Igniculus character. This enables a more offensive dynamic to develop with PCs and focuses on matching attacks to enemies, timing offense and defense (NB: when enemy and player character are within the timer's "red zone" the preferred action should be defense), and generally making your party more proactive and less micro-managed.I personally spend most of battle with the Igniculus trigger enabled on one of the enemies, according to each of their turns in the battle sequence and their action speed.Party members start out "pre-typed" so to speak - Aurora is clearly a mage-type build, despite the big MFKN sword she receives at the beginning. The skill tree however, offers an opportunity to shift the character type more towards a melee fighter with strength and HP boosts. If that is your intention, I would recommend to either grind a bit at the beginning to earn Uplay credits that you can redeem for HP and strength bonuses, or maybe to wait for the right party member to join gameplay and mould it into the fighter that you want to have up-front and in the face of your enemies.Sadly there is no cover system, no grid and no distinction between melee and ranged fighting - a mage cast is equivalent to a physical attack, and each character has a primary physical attack. Honestly at my current level my characters are so OP that I can't tell if it makes a difference or not. The only noticeable thing is that my fighter character has MP that she never uses unless there's a major crisis like HP drastically low while Igniculus' meter is empty - in which case she can heal any party member (as a turn-based action). This permits for the fighter character to occasionally squeeze out a buff for the entire party at the beginning of a battle and just sit on the rest of the MP until needed at a later time.The gem upgrade system was also nice (called "oculi" in-game) with a no-nonsense elemental interdependence (fire, water, lightning) that allows you to have ridiculously unfair advantages against enemies. A typical attack makes almost triple the damage if the correct oculus (can I decline it that way?) is applied to the weapon.One thing that bothered me at the beginning was that when Aurora walked, the feet were misaligned with the path on which she was walking (it looked pretty half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥for all the effort that was put into creating the backgrounds in the first place), but after the first boss-battle where the additional ability of flight is unlocked, and implicitly moving speed increases, that is no longer an issue.That being said, it's a nice game that's difficult to put down. If I had kids, I'd let them play this.Will update my review if my opinion changes before I beat the game.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												Beautiful game with music to match.  It's got a battle system that's similar to the JRPG Grandia series, which is a lot of fun.  Battles have a timeline where characters and enemies have to wait until it's their turn and actions take differing amounts of time to perform.  Get hit during your action time and you get interrupted.  The same goes for enemies.  Strategy gets enhanced by buffs/debuffs, counters, and the ability to swap characters instantly on your turn.I was able to get through on Expert fairly easily without any time spent grinding for levels, although I didn't avoid any enemies as I enjoyed the battle system too much.  Leveling up grants you skill points which you can spend on one of 3 branches of the skill tree.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												Only rating the game here, not Uplay.Ubisoft Montreal delivers a very charming if short game. The protagonist, Aurora, daughter of the Duke of Austria, finds herself awakening in the mystical land Lemuria which has fallen under the spell of the Queen of the Night. Aurora is tasked by the Lady of the Forest to free the Lemurians from the suffocating reign and bring back the light, all the while she tries to get home to her father, who is dying of grief over Auroras's supposed death.The gameplay features elements of a JRPG, with a growing cast of supporting characters aiding Aurora in her quest, character development and a hybrid turn-based and real-time combat system. Yet the game is a sidescroller with some puzzles and plattforming in the mix.The game really is rather short but sweet, features artful visuals plus a terrific musical score. I really can't say anything bad about the game besides the lack of variety in endings which was hinted at by the developers. So, for 15 bucks you get around 10 hours worth of content for the basic game, and a New Game Plus Mode (which I can't say anything about because I haven't played it yet). If you can put up with Uplay, it's worth of your time.

												Where to start? This game does have a very nice story. The only problem I have with it was a somewhat abrupt ending. I still strongly recommend the game however.  This is one of those games that makes you want more of everything in a good way.Quite simply, the music is addicting. I do wish the sound track did have the vocal track version heard in the game. The DLC does add a nice boost to the game with an additional character.  Graphics: It feels as if you are playing in a painting that was done by watercolor. It is THAT good. Smooth animations. Music: As mentioned above, one of the absolute best parts of the gameGameplay: You have a hefty amount of skills and a fairly simple crafting system. The controls are smooth and easy to use. Though I recommend strongly using a controller.Overall: 10/10, I haven't enjoyed a game like this in a while. Another good one I enjoyed was Fable.

The RPG style character progression trees/weapon augments and interesting battle system make me very very happy that I preodered this game. Mastering how to use your little firefly friend to slow down enemies as their meter builds is not only innovative and capitivating, as it's better than just sitting there waiting for you turn, but I can tell that it will become an essential tactic later on. This game is adorable, but still a very legitimate RPG title I thoroughly reccommend picking up. DLC as well, since the extra augments and stat buff items help you out early on. :D

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												UPlay problems aside (sigh, when will they learn....), this is actually an excellent little unique turn-based RPG. Think old style jrpg, but with a side scroller twist. Only a couple hours in, and it's already showing signs of being quite deep with a nice skill tree setup for character progression. Story seems a bit 'childish' (with a name like that, no surprise there) but it looks to be headed in deeper territory. Visually pleasing, with lots of variety to locales and cool effects. Very nice. Also expect plenty of chuckling as the dialogue is almost entirely done in rhymes.Thumbs up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												It's like crime how Child of Light can rob you of your time.The combination of side-scrolling exploration, challenging turn-based tactical gameplay, amusing rhyming dialogues and a wonderful art style makes Child of Light an unusual but enjoyable gem.You'll quickly fall in love with the beatifully drawn landscapes of Lemuria as you travel through its dark forests, mountains and even under the sea. They are typically riddled with secret areas you can sniff out for treasure, puzzles or hidden bosses. Often there'll be more than one path to your destination, making exploration more interesting.During your travels, you'll meet many fun characters who'll give your quests, join you in your adventure, or both. My favourite was a female jester who couldn't do the dialogues in a proper rhyming fashion, allowing the other characters to jump in and correct her. Her healing abilities were also very welcome in a fight, making her one of my most used characters during combat.The combat is turn-based but has a real-time element that lets you delay enemies' turn or slightly heal your party out of turn. Timing this ability is important to winning encounters, as it lets you better use or avoid being the victim of the interrupt mechanic. Interrupting means hitting a character trying to perform an action, resulting in his turn being delayed. If you don't go for the easy difficulty, combat offers good and rewarding challenge that makes you invest time into considering how to specialise your characters.Each character has a network of specialisation trees, offering abilities unique to him while giving you a choice between the different paths. For example, there's a wizard who can specialise in lightning, water or fire, allowing him to excel against certain creature types vulnerable to his focused element. Another character can choose between improving his defense, his offense or his ability to direct enemy attacks against him.A problem that grows as the size of your party increases, is the frequency of level ups. Very quickly you'll be looking at one or multiple level ups after pretty much every battle as your characters gain levels and extra skill points to spend. It becomes tedious looking at the skill tree menu this often.Another part of character customisation is the Oculi system. Oculi are gems you gather and can use kind of like equipment items such as swords and armor in other games. They offer different bonuses depending on color and slot used, and can be combined to form more powerful gems. Oculi juggling gets a little cumbersome, but is nonetheless an important strategic element as you want to equip the right damage and resistance types depending on the opposition of your current area.Apart from having trouble with Steam starting the game through Uplay for some reason initially, the only bug I noticed in the actual game was that sometimes when entering combat, Aurora's (the main character) usually flowing hair wasn't drawn.If you're not playing on Easy difficulty and like to explore and look for secrets, you should expect around 20 hours of gameplay from Child of Light.TIP: While Child of Light offers controller support, I really must recommend using mouse and keyboard. You will need the precision to properly manage the real-time element of the otherwise turn-based combat.TIP: If, like me, you have trouble starting the game through Steam, try launching Uplay directly and start the game from there. After doing that, it's been working for me no problem.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
												This game is simply beautiful - from the hand-drawn graphics to the soothing background music. The battle music is epic and reminiscent of Final Fantasy VII. The turn-based combat is nicely unique with the option of using your little glow-worm friend to slow down opponents and heal allies, giving you the chance to get that all important potion or cast in before you're anhilated. Combat is not your usual one-shot-as-you-go, and I admit a couple of the boss fights have taken me a couple of attempts. There is also a nice option to switch out your allies mid-fight to give you the upper edge. Game is not quick to play - the story unwinds slowly as you meet new characters. I've been playing for about 2.5 hours and have only just reached chapter 4/10. The skill/talent tree is also reminiscent of the Final Fantasy games. The puzzles are interesting to complete. As a bonus, if you're playing this single-player, you also get to control your little friend too, which can be a bit tricky to manage both to begin with, but you soon get the hang of it.The only downfall I found was the jumping - until you recieve the ability to fly, the jumps are very tight and can be difficult to make with a controller as I couldn't quite get the right diagonal key-press. I found myself putting down the controller and using the directional arrows on my keyboard to complete the jumps - much easier. This, obviously, is no longer an issue once you gain flying. Overall I give this game 10/10. It's fun, quirky, engaging, and not over-simplified. And guys - don't dismiss this game as being girly. Give it a try, you never know you might like it!

												So I finally got this game working... As everyone has said below, dealing with the uplay is a nightmare.  Here's what worked for me:1.) go into steam and retrieve the product key - don't install game2.) shutdown steam completely3.) go to uplay.ubi.com and download the uplay client from their website.4.) install the uplay client you downloaded5.) let it do it's updates6.) go to activate product and enter the key you copied from steam7.) once it shows up in the uplay library relaunch steam8.) install game from steam9.) run from steamI'm clicking yes for recommend, the game is great so far and it shouldn't suffer just because of the software it got packaged with.

												I have to say that I really like this game. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												Child of Light is a fairytale roleplaying game in the vein of many fondly remembered children's stories.  Aurora, first born princess of the Austrian King, falls to illness and is transported to the fantastical land of Lemuria--a kingdom of monsters and anthropomorphic animals alike.  It is in both the adequately written prose and beautiful illustrations that one feels they are interacting in a proper storybook.  The gameplay also draws from a long-line of classic influences; side-scrolling areas are subtle in their similarities to Metroid-vania games, while the battle system is turn-based and real-time with a smattering of Grandia's system of delaying and interrupting actions with carefully timed attacks.The combination of beautiful illustrations, a lullaby-like soundtrack, and a nostalgic battle system enticed me to return each day to learn a little more about Aurora's newfound whereabouts.  While dialogue between characters is again illustrated with beautiful character profiles, the conversations themselves can feel a little contrived at times--granted, I would snicker here and there.  Each part of Lemuria is broken up by chapters and again highlight the range of beauty that the game's artists are capable of showing us.  Animations are smooth and the use of lighting for backgrounds and objects really adds to the fantasy.In the end, I found myself enjoying Child of Light for what it was trying to be; an interactive storybook that subtly entices you to turn each page carefully and deliberately in the hopes that you'll get lost in it.  At the same time, I was disappointed by that very thing--a mostly pretty game with a fun story that doesn't demand that you invest in their characters beyond some archetypical quirks.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												FIRST IMPRESSIONS:Nearly all of the game's dialogue (which is primarily text-only, with spoken narration for cutscenes) is in a poetic rhyming format. Personally, I find this quite annoying, and it distracts me from the text's actual content. However, I did find a character (party member, even) that goes out of her way to use a word that does NOT rhyme, when there's a better-fitting word that DOES rhyme, after which another character corrects them. I find this somewhat amusing.The combat, however, piques my interest. First off, it uses a "turn-time" system, whereby faster units take more turns than slower ones, as opposed to Pokemon (for example) where speed only determines who moves first in a turn, yet everyone still gets the same number of turns. However, this game takes it a step farther; each unit's turn is split into a wait period and a cast period. Once a unit's wait period finishes, they select an action and proceed to the cast period. Once the cast period is done, the action occurs. However, an action can be interrupted if the unit is hit while in their cast period. This results in a lot of strategy in manipulating the timers, especially given the fact that you can pick an enemy and slow them down nearly any time.I read a lot of reviews that mentioned having problems with Uplay, be it the inabilty to play or having saves erased. I haven't had these issues. I also read that you should use Uplay in offline mode, which I've done thus far.SECOND IMPRESSIONS:Now that I have more than two party members, I now see how party swapping works. It's kind of wierd. At first, I thought it was the same as FF10; on a player unit's turn, you can swap him/her out for any other player unit not already active, and this is completely seamless and takes no time. But there's another option. Lets say you have three party members, named A, B, and C. A is picking an action. B is on the field, but waiting to act. C is off the field. You can use A's action to swap C in for B, and this will cause A's turn to be spent, but C is now immediately ready to act. Confusing? Yeah, I thought so too. As a result, I only use the swap-for-self method that FF10 uses.I'd also like to comment on the art style. It has its own unique fantasy charm. I like to describe it as the developer being on juuuust the right amount of drugs.THIRD IMPRESSIONS:Dang, the game is getting hard.There's two difficulty levels, Casual and Expert. I picked Expert. The difficulty was high, but managable until recently. It's getting quite brutal at this point. I'm managing, but only barely.And I'm loving it. BRING IT ON!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
												This game is simply beautiful - from the hand-drawn graphics to the soothing background music. The battle music is epic and reminiscent of Final Fantasy VII. The turn-based combat is nicely unique with the option of using your little glow-worm friend to slow down opponents and heal allies, giving you the chance to get that all important potion or cast in before you're anhilated. Combat is not your usual one-shot-as-you-go, and I admit a couple of the boss fights have taken me a couple of attempts. There is also a nice option to switch out your allies mid-fight to give you the upper edge. Game is not quick to play - the story unwinds slowly as you meet new characters. I've been playing for about 2.5 hours and have only just reached chapter 4/10. The skill/talent tree is also reminiscent of the Final Fantasy games. The puzzles are interesting to complete. As a bonus, if you're playing this single-player, you also get to control your little friend too, which can be a bit tricky to manage both to begin with, but you soon get the hang of it.The only downfall I found was the jumping - until you recieve the ability to fly, the jumps are very tight and can be difficult to make with a controller as I couldn't quite get the right diagonal key-press. I found myself putting down the controller and using the directional arrows on my keyboard to complete the jumps - much easier. This, obviously, is no longer an issue once you gain flying. Overall I give this game 10/10. It's fun, quirky, engaging, and not over-simplified. And guys - don't dismiss this game as being girly. Give it a try, you never know you might like it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												Talk about a beautiful and engaging game. Child of Light is an RPG from Ubisoft Montreal. Let’s get rocking.The GoodFirstly, the thing that struck me the most about this game is the art. The artwork is beautiful in every sense of the word. It has a distinctive, watercolor style and it works splendidly with the premise of the game. You’ll really feel like you’re playing through a storybook and it is a wonderful experience.The story of the game is pretty good and it is filled with interesting characters (and enemies). The game world itself is a great canvas on which the story is able to unfold. It’s imaginative, original, and refreshing.There’s a good variety of enemy types for you to take on during the course of the game. There’s more than enough to keep you interested in combat.The combat system itself is very old school. It’s set on a timer, and you’ll need to time your character’s attacks if you don’t want to get interrupted and have to take a penalty on your timer.The BadAs far as RPGs go, I typically go in expecting to have at least a good handful of items to equip my character/party with. While CoL does have some items, it is quite lacking on the changeable weapons front.The MehEven if you get this one through Steam, you’ll be having to play it through Uplay.Verdict: YeaChild of Light is a solid RPG and a worthwhile addition to any collection (and that is just for the artwork alone). You can find it in the Steam Store and with the Halloween Sale (most likely) just around the corner, you should keep an eye out for this one. As always, thanks for reading.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												This game will melt your heart. It has been some time since I had last been emotionally touched by a game. But the princess is just so cute, especially when she is weighed down by her large sword after holding it up for a victory. Awww!! The dialogues are often cute and funny, I also didn't think the riming got tiresome, but maybe that's because I'm not a native speaker. The soundtrack is great and wonderfully adds to the atmosphere.The story is a bit in between. It's very nicely presented with the dialogues and all, but there is little meat on the bone if you look at it more closely. Still, the game is not very long, so no big drawback.At some point the battles will become a bit drawn out and you'll find yourself battling just for the XP and maybe some oculi loot. That's a shame, considering you'll spend so much time battling. Personally, considering the style of the game, I would have preferred spending more time exploring the world.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												Child of Light is a remarkable adventure. Once I accepted the sadness that is so intertwined with every element, I grew so much closer to Child of Light. It's easy to heap praise on the combat because it's so engaging, and it's certainly a high point in this adventure. That's not what makes Child of Light stand out, though. Rather, it's how confident it is in its own feelings of woe. There are so few games willing to explore that dull ache that I became mesmerized by Aurora's journey, even when I needed to step away from her plight while I regained my composure. Child of Light is a wonderfully realized, somber adventure, and I couldn't be happier that such a game exists.Ignore the Uplay naysayers; it really doesn't change anything.

Ubisoft have stated that they took a big risk with this game, it is not their typical triple A title that must be churned out year on end.How glad I am that they took a chance on this game!an Astounding soundtrack by Coeur de Pirate, compelling storyline, diverse and interesting characters and involved RPG mechanics akin to the final fantasy series all come together to create a game so atmospheric I found it difficult to put down. Once you do complete the game there is the chance to go back and play again with the same stats and oculi (stat modifying crystals) so that you can unlock every skill for each character ( I finished my first playthrough at level 49)You can also play it co operatively as a second player can control the firefly igniculus who can heal allies and slow foes down, reach areas Aurora can't and illuminate the dark.10/10

												A land missing its lost Queen. A lost girl missing her Mother. The Queen of the Night who has lost her way. Help Aurora on her quest to restore balance to Lemuria.I wasn't expecting much when I purhcased this game. It was recommended by a friend and I picked it up fairly cheaply. Once I began playing I understood why it was recommended to me - I love fairy tales and fables. The game tells its story entirely in rhyme, or at least near rhyme in the case of one character who can't quite grasp the concept. It might be an odd thing to bring up first but I assure you that the dialogue in game is an integral part as it draws you in and immerses you in the birghtly colored pastel and watercolor world of Lemuria. The combat is also quite well done, with a bit of an extra twist that you'll soon find almost second nature.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												    Child of Light is a beautiful game that has many elements of other types of games that have before it while combining them in fantastic ways. I received this game as a gift from a close friend and immediately began to play it without hesitation. I quickly fell in love with this game due to its adorable gimmicks and lovable characters. Aurora is a cute little princess who seems too good to be true, and remains strong even though the weight of the world weighs down on her. Let's get to a little list of positives and negatives!Positives- As previously said, the characters are cute and lovable, while all having their own personalities.- The ability trees are very interesting and let you build characters in many different ways to create a team as you see fit.- The DLC is cheap if you're interested and adds in some more colorful characters, which I only recently discovered.- The storyline is sweet with amazing cutscenes that love to show off all of the hard work put into this game.- The quests are all very direct which makes the game a bit linear (if you enjoy that) but also allows wiggle room if you like to do side quests.- All side quests that I've found give really good rewards while not being too easy or difficult.- The puzzles are simple enough while still being entertaining in the few places that they show up.Negatives- Aurora can often be seen as too picture perfect even if it is part of her charm.- You can bypass a lot of companions if you aren't paying careful attention.- Although the new game plus is fun and adds to the game, it's important to take into consideration that nothing changes except for the levels, which kind of dries the game out.- Theres no type of multiplayer unless you hand somebody your mouse so they can be your little firefly friend, which gets boring quickly.    This is a decent list of some vague things in the game that are obvious once you play it a bit, although it should give you a good enough idea of whether or not you'd like to buy it. The game is personally one of my favorites and I adore the pleasing feeling of freedom you receive when you have the ability to fly around like a fairy while looking at the picturesque landscape of the stages you go through. This game is entirely worth it if you're a fan of fairytales, books, poetry, or platformers.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												If you already played Grandia I or II, you will find this game pretty familiar. It's like Grandia in 2d perspective!The Good:- Great animation- Great Music and Sound Effects- Good History- Mechanics similar to Grandia ( Although Grandia is better in this aspect)- Decent ammount of customizationThe Bad:- The need to install Uplay and update manually directly from website in order to run the game. However, once making an account on uplay, you can remove all options of uplay overlay. - Character walks a bit slow but later you can move faster.- DLC's are not big deal. It just give to you freebies that you can acquire on game. The only ones that are worthy: Golem pack , Dark Aurora and Light Aurora, due to additional character and skins.- The game did ran slow to me. I've needed to do some steps in order to fix:  *  Needed to put on Full screen  *  Auto-hide the desktop bar  *  Used Razer Cortex to increase the speedAfter this it worked like charm and I've got 66-90 fps which is great! Overall, I recommend to get this game and don't be  afraid because of the other DRM.

												One of the reasons why I bought this game in the first place was because of it's artistic look. This game owns the most beautiful backgrounds I've ever seen. The story itself is also pretty good - even tho am not used to play games that own a plot which sounds like it has been taken out of a children's book. The game itself is pretty enjoyable. I like to collect stuff and find some hidden areas - this game has both of 'em surprisingly much which keeps the player busy.Even if you wouldn't like to look for extra items - the game still has a lot to offer.So yeah, I really enjoyed playing this game, but there's only one teeny tiny minus. When I was about to face the boss - I was expecting something new and exiting, but instead - the fights stayed pretty much the same. The only difference was that it took some more time to kill the enemy. "Face the enemy, kick it's butt, done. Face the enemy, kick it's butt, done...". The longer the pattern keeped on going - the more boring the game started to feel like. But don't take this the wrong way - it really is a good game.8/10

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												I have to say that I really like this game. It is a great example of how games can be considered art.Child of Light is a lighthearted RPG-platformer crossover with wonderful art and a beautiful (!) soundtrack. The tactical battle system is simple enough that it fits nicely with the casual fairy tale style of the story, but is still deep enough not to be boring even after the myriad of battles you'll face throughout the game. In addition, all dialogue is presented as poetry; although the rhythms are quite irregular and the rhymes are a bit of a stretch sometimes, it is overall very entertaining. Especially recommended for RPG fans who want a relaxing break from heavier and longer games.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												The most enjoyable RPG I've played in a long time. Its mechanics are solid, easy to pick up and play, and never seem to leave me bored like so many other RPGs. Its a little on the light-weight side, but its design is very intuitive and to the point, but still presenting a challenge. It has checks and balances against "min-maxing", but that's often done simply. The progression system is also simple compared to older RPGs and some modern one (though much more advanced than, say, games like Final Fantasy 13 or World of Warcraft). The story is very nice and inspiring, very melancholy and darkly beautiful. Its like looking through the eyes of an innocent child at a destitute world; that's pretty much the theme throughout. Its more than the sum of its parts in the emotions which it evokes.Its a long-run RPG but ends abruptly, however it still manages to wrap things up nicely. As far as I can tell, there are no end-game quests, no "ultimate weapons" to be had, which I find somewhat disapointing. I know there's some things I haven't completed, but I'm not holding my breath for anything like, say Final Fantasy 8's endgame.All in all its a great game, and one of the best of its generation of games (Xbox 360 era till now).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												This game just flat out awed me and filled me so full of nostalgic feelings for the RPGs I played on my Playstation when I was a young girl. What I love most was the battle system which was a slightly more dynamic version of the turn-based Active Time Battle system used in many older Final Fantasy games. The visuals are beautiful and the story is entertaining and poetic. I thoroughly enjoyed all the different party members and the game's plot. Literally, my only disappointment is I wish this game was longer, because I didn't want it to end so soon. Also, it requires Uplay, a client provided through Ubisoft. Based on other reviews, it appears to be finicky. But I didn't seem to experience any problems with it. Even after I had nearly stopped playing the game for a year and went back to play it again later, I incurred no serious issues with the Uplay service.If you're into RPGs you should definitely give this game a try. And if you're not too familiar with the style of RPGs, don't worry. This game is straight forward, easy to get into and quite intuitive when it comes to controls.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												Friends. Family, Hope. Find all of these things in the game and disregard the real-life counterparts. Withdraw from all social events involving your friends and family. Procrastinate even more skilfully and deftly with this charming and deceptively strategic RPG. And, if you're a student like me, disappoint your parents even further by spending an embarrassingly large amount of time before the screen, watching little animals violently flog one another to death. Because my goodness is this game glorious.This game has it all : storyline engineered to make you cry, beautiful watercolour artwork, simple yet strategic gameplay, treasure hunting, side quests, crafting, levelling up (with the possibility of grinding if you're into that), hauntingly heartbreaking music and sexy rats in finery and merpeople (again if you're into that). The world and gameplay are utterly absorbing, such that 7pm quickly becomes 10pm and you give up on doing your essay and instead consign yourself to playing for another couple of hours because it's already late and you're kinda tired and what can you do.  I'll speak on the strongest part of the game (and arguably the most important part) : gameplay.So the game incorporates the Active Battle System (Active Time Battle ? Active Battle Time ?) seen in early Final Fantasy games - in other words, the player and the enemy each have a bar that charges up, and when it is full they may "cast", or complete an action, be it attacking, defending, taunting or buffing allies up with freakish dancing. An interesting component (or two) included in this game is the ability to interrupt an action by hitting the character in mid-"cast", causing the interrupted to have to refill their charge bar. Time it right and the enemy will never land a hit on you, whereupon the aforementioned flogging takes place. Alternatively, panic as you yourself are trapped in such a vicious cycle of flogging and swear under your breath because the enemy is too many and too fast, and you are too slow and weak and pitiful or both. You also have the ability to manually slow down the enemy (or heal yourself) by clicking and holding the mouse (although it's a firefly in the game) over the characters, allowing you to turn the tide of battle or at least give yourself a bit more breathing room if you're getting absolutely pummelled. There is nothing more satisfying than defeating a boss that you have branded as being "cheap" and "too fast" in the first minute of battle, nothing more elating than having your frustrated despair abruptly change to malicious glee as you discover the proper strategy required to take them out, and there is absolutely nothing that trumps the feeling of having successfully carried out your petty vengeance by dealing an inordinately and unnecessarily large amount of damage to an enemy barely clinging on to life. Eat it !  So concludes the more positive part of the review.The negative part is a lot smaller and miniscule in importance.Essentially, if rhymed poetry is not your friend, or if rhyming in general just gets on your nerves, watch out. The entire game is composed of rhymes, and some of them wholly repetitive. There's only so many words you can rhyme with "bye" or "me" (actually that's a lie, there's a huge amount that rhymes with those two words, but in the context of a video game, let alone a conversation in a video game ? I think not). You can also collect collectibles in the form of "confessions" (essentially background history) which is also completely composed of rhyme. And this time the language is a lot more sophisticated. So if you're lazy, a bad reader (which means you should've stopped reading this review a good 5 paragraphs back), a second language speaker (I joke) or simply rhymephobic, avoid at all costs. But because this game is a combat game and not a reading poetry game, I'd have to say that its impact on the game is fairly minimum.Anyway. Buy it. Play it. Love it. Finish it. Then don't touch it again until nostalgia brings it to the forefront of your mind.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												First off: This game is incredible. The soundtrack, the watercolor background, the immersive story. It genuinely makes you care about the characters. The only complaints I have are that the 10 hours that you get to play it through aren't enough. Second, there's so much to explore. As in most open-world games I try not to stray to far from the intended path of the game until beating it, and miss out on tons of side-quests that improve the game, but I found I never cared if I spent 20 minutes exploring a cave when I should have been saving Lemuria. Every single moment I played this game has been awesome. The combat mechanics are simple to learn and are an awesome variation from boring regular turn-based combat. I can not stop saying good things about this game, it is truly a work of art and I definitely recommend getting it. I'd also recommend the Golem's Plight DLC pack, as having another character on the team helps a lot and the Golem is a lot of fun to use. The Dark Aurora skin is my personal favorite, though the heal skill of the Light Pack is very useful. If you feel like spending an extra $7, get the Light and Dark Packs, and the Golem's Plight. I hope you enjoy this game as much as I did!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												Warning: Indepth reviewVisuals-Gorgeous watercolor artstyle-Charming/cute fairytale-like character designs-Extremely beautiful and detailed environments and scenery aided by the artstyle-High attention to detail for character/skill animations. E.g, main character fumbles around a lot while wielding/using her sword because it is practically the same size as herAudio-Eargasmic fully orchestrated soundtracks-Music styles range from lighthearted disneylike bgm to intense, adrenaline pumping musical scores to sombre, lonely, melancholic pieces-Soundtracks that play during normal monster battles are so epic that they feel more like final boss battles instead-Much effort and detail put into sound effects for every little thing. E.g., sound of barefeet stepping on wet rock as your character moves around a dark forest, or the metal tinkering sound of the crown when it hits the floorStory-Straight out of a fairytale, but with a slightly dark and gloomy atmosphere replacing the usual happy, uplifting mood found in these type of stories-Some nice plot twists and turn of events that match well with the sorrowful mood of the story, but otherwise, fairly straight forward like most fairytales-despite the generally sombre feeling of the story, still heartwarming at times-At its core, a coming-of-age story. People looking for something with an intricate and deep plot will be disappointedCharacters-With the plot being reminiscent of a disney movie, likewise the characters also follow suit (talking animals/ mythological creatures)-Charming/cute characters that compliment each other well due to their distinctive personalities and character traits-Main character (Aurora)  is an incredibly cute and sweet, but brave little girl. (Very likeable protagonist)Dialogue-Everything is spoken in rhymes; adds to the cuteness/fairytaleness of the story, but may become annoying for some people as the game progressesGameplay-Old school turn based combat with several added twists-Order of turns in combat dictated by a timeline mechanic, which is further influenced by an interruption mechanic when characters are attacked during the 'casting' part of the timeline-Timeline/interruption/cursor mechanic help add to the tension/unpredictability of fights and fosters strategic elements unique to these mechanics (e.g, knowing when it is worth using weak, but fast speed attacks to interrupt enemies VS straight brute force killing the monsters with strong but long cast time spells)-However, at its heart, it is still turn based battle, so it will not appeal to all people despite the previously mentioned mechanics that speed up the flow of battleRecommend to everyone but the most diehard haters of turn-based battle.Oh, and theres Uplay. ♥♥♥♥ Uplay. But seriously though, it's worth the hassel of installing and signing up for Uplay to experience this game. Cheers~

Posted: January 31, 2016
												okay here's the lowdown: this game has great visuals, a gorgeous soundtrack and functional characters/storyline, but good ♥♥♥♥ing LORD the gameplay is tedious, it's actually really peculiar because this game pulls an interesting twist on the traditional turn-based rpg combat system and implements a time bar that can be influenced to determine who strikes when, but the hindrance that catastrophises not only that glimmer of innovation but also tragically the rest of the game was how ♥♥♥♥ing monotonous and repetitive the gameplay was, the whole game circulates so reliantly on level grinding, which is a perfectly fine and definitely expected aspect to appear in an rpg, but not when you have to do it legitimately 85-90% of your time playing it. that's not an exaggeration, i've spent 18 hours on this game and i'm willing to bet 14 of them absolute minimum were dedicated to grinding. and i played it through on the easy difficulty too, god forbid anyone even attempts to grind through the hard difficulty because you won't be getting those hours back my friend. it's seriously such a shame that this one normally traversable issue in an rpg was so massive that it took away from the enjoyable facets into which there was obviously a lot of effort invested. i was going to recommend this game but, in spite of it's overall 6/10 score, from pretty much all angles it's just not worth it: it's too dull for the casual player, it's atrocious both in terms of mental stimulation and accessibility for a brand new player (the gems/items/lore system is poor and disorganised), it's not even that good for a hardcore player who spends their life grinding the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of games because the rest of the game simply becomes uninteresting indeed as a result of how much this game is composed of grinding. like all the ingredients are there to make a nice, simple, pleasant video game experience, but some ♥♥♥♥wit in development knocked over the entire jar labelled 'levelling up system' into the bowl and the end result just left me with a bad taste in my mouth. holy♥♥♥♥♥♥that was probably the best joke i've ever made in my life. anyway don't play this game unless you're willing to go the distance, and i ♥♥♥♥ing mean really go the distance

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												Ususally, I don't play turn-based games. I don't like that you have to wait a preordained period of time to be able to do something (where's my freedom to do whatever I want?!), so I bought this game on a whim. I liked the art mostly. It's cute. And it was on sale. So with my bias against turn-based games, I started playing it, thinking ˝Well, if I don't like it, at least I didn't spend that much on it˝. And to my surprise, I kept on playing it. I did not feel frustrated about the turn-based system, because this game's system is more dynamic (play the game or youtube it and you'll see what I mean). As with all turn-based games, the fights can become repetitive, but I found them to be engaging enough to not really care about it.I haven't finished the game yet, but so far I found the story to be quite engaging and well narrated. The rhymes add a taste of childhood, without being childish. The art is stunning and the soundtrack is well matched with the pacing of the game. Overall, this game was a very pleasant surprise for me.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
												Not a bad little rpg, i originally was captured by the artstyle and continued to play on.It has a nice feel to flying and a lot of the fluidity feels like the honed gameplay from some of the recent rayman games. Infact i can imagine them just taking the straight rayman engine and loading it up with these cartoony/storybook assets.Anyway the game started out strong for me, an interesting story and art style and game mechanics but after a while those things get stale. Most puzzles involve using Igniculus to shine on some element or to project a shadow. I thought you might get other abilities other than flying but you don't. Then i also found myself skipping alot of the dialog which i rarely do in games, i think its just due to the fact its not straightforward chit chat.All in all though it was fun enough to push through, the other characters and pickups and parts of the story were intersting enough and i could see some different experiences happening between players if you don't seek out every single thing in the game.I can see a sequel or another game of a similar style really tightening up some of these aspects and making a much better rounded experience.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Child of Light is one of the best recent rpg's I have played.  When I first thought about playing this game I had decided that I would rather watch it on youtube, which would have turned out to be a huge mistake.  Since it's an rpg you get a lot more choice in how you play over somebody elses experience.           I think the story of this game is pretty good but not amazing, as it's told in a fairy tale type manner.  Every character speaks in rhyme, so a lot of the time they have to select words and phrases that would rhyme with the last, instead of telling a rich story.  But that isn't to say there is no story because there definetely is.  The main character actually grows up throughout the story, like she starts off selfish but becomes selfless to the end, unfortunately thats it for character growth though, at the end of the day everybody is there for the main character.	The combat of this game is 99% of the team easy and excellent, and if you play the game on casual mode you won't have to fight half the enemies in the game, it's really easy.  It's only on expert that the game becomes a lot harder.  It's a turn based rpg where your character moves across on a bar at the bottom, which depends on your speed stat.  Your character will start at the wait part of the bar, which is basically waiting to select a skill.  Once you hit the end of wait you will hit a line where you can select a skill.  Each skill has a time that it takes to get off, depending on it's strength.  Now the mechanic of the combat that makes it somewhat strategic, is the fact that if the enemy hits you well you are in the red bar you will get interrupted, and pushed back on the bar so that you have to reselect your skill.  If you hit the enemy well they are in the red bar they will be knocked back and interrupted as well.  So you can really plan knocking back enemies judging by how fast they are on the bar.  Other than that you only can fight with 2 characters and  the enemies can have up to 3.  	What makes this a good game to play yourself is the skills that you get.  Now it isn't as in depth as a skill tree is, but it has enough depth so that you can choose what you want each character to do.  Each skill has two forms as well, the solo one which hits one enemy and the all version which hits all enemies.  The all version takes a lot longer to get off though.  Also if you play the game on the casual difficulty, not only can you avoid most fights to beat the game, you get more exp.  In the expert version you can finish the game at level 50 but on casual it's around 70.  	Expert difficulty also creates the importance of the crafting system where you actually have to use items and upgrades to survive.  There is a crafting system in the game called Oculli which isn't explained so much, but it isn't that convuluted that you wouldn't understand it with some practice.  The game also gives you a lot to use for crafting.  Basically they upgrade your strength in certain aspects.  Like the red Oculli gives your character fire damage and the blue one water damage.  They also give you defencive boosts, based on which Oculli is put where.	Overall I'd say this game is good, but don't expect the most immersive rpg mechanics or characterization, that other rpg's like final fantasy have.  This game took me about 14 hours to complete, but I did enjoy my experience.  And it was nice to be able to play an rpg that wasn't going to take me 100 plus hours to beat.  I'd recommend this game to people who want to play an rpg that isn't too hard or takes too much time to get into.  I also recommend playing this game on expert difficulty, which is the way it was meant to be played.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
												Not a bad little rpg, i originally was captured by the artstyle and continued to play on.It has a nice feel to flying and a lot of the fluidity feels like the honed gameplay from some of the recent rayman games. Infact i can imagine them just taking the straight rayman engine and loading it up with these cartoony/storybook assets.Anyway the game started out strong for me, an interesting story and art style and game mechanics but after a while those things get stale. Most puzzles involve using Igniculus to shine on some element or to project a shadow. I thought you might get other abilities other than flying but you don't. Then i also found myself skipping alot of the dialog which i rarely do in games, i think its just due to the fact its not straightforward chit chat.All in all though it was fun enough to push through, the other characters and pickups and parts of the story were intersting enough and i could see some different experiences happening between players if you don't seek out every single thing in the game.I can see a sequel or another game of a similar style really tightening up some of these aspects and making a much better rounded experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												Ususally, I don't play turn-based games. I don't like that you have to wait a preordained period of time to be able to do something (where's my freedom to do whatever I want?!), so I bought this game on a whim. I liked the art mostly. It's cute. And it was on sale. So with my bias against turn-based games, I started playing it, thinking ˝Well, if I don't like it, at least I didn't spend that much on it˝. And to my surprise, I kept on playing it. I did not feel frustrated about the turn-based system, because this game's system is more dynamic (play the game or youtube it and you'll see what I mean). As with all turn-based games, the fights can become repetitive, but I found them to be engaging enough to not really care about it.I haven't finished the game yet, but so far I found the story to be quite engaging and well narrated. The rhymes add a taste of childhood, without being childish. The art is stunning and the soundtrack is well matched with the pacing of the game. Overall, this game was a very pleasant surprise for me.
