content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Child of Light is one of the best recent rpg's I have played.  When I first thought about playing this game I had decided that I would rather watch it on youtube, which would have turned out to be a huge mistake.  Since it's an rpg you get a lot more choice in how you play over somebody elses experience.           I think the story of this game is pretty good but not amazing, as it's told in a fairy tale type manner.  Every character speaks in rhyme, so a lot of the time they have to select words and phrases that would rhyme with the last, instead of telling a rich story.  But that isn't to say there is no story because there definetely is.  The main character actually grows up throughout the story, like she starts off selfish but becomes selfless to the end, unfortunately thats it for character growth though, at the end of the day everybody is there for the main character.	The combat of this game is 99% of the team easy and excellent, and if you play the game on casual mode you won't have to fight half the enemies in the game, it's really easy.  It's only on expert that the game becomes a lot harder.  It's a turn based rpg where your character moves across on a bar at the bottom, which depends on your speed stat.  Your character will start at the wait part of the bar, which is basically waiting to select a skill.  Once you hit the end of wait you will hit a line where you can select a skill.  Each skill has a time that it takes to get off, depending on it's strength.  Now the mechanic of the combat that makes it somewhat strategic, is the fact that if the enemy hits you well you are in the red bar you will get interrupted, and pushed back on the bar so that you have to reselect your skill.  If you hit the enemy well they are in the red bar they will be knocked back and interrupted as well.  So you can really plan knocking back enemies judging by how fast they are on the bar.  Other than that you only can fight with 2 characters and  the enemies can have up to 3.  	What makes this a good game to play yourself is the skills that you get.  Now it isn't as in depth as a skill tree is, but it has enough depth so that you can choose what you want each character to do.  Each skill has two forms as well, the solo one which hits one enemy and the all version which hits all enemies.  The all version takes a lot longer to get off though.  Also if you play the game on the casual difficulty, not only can you avoid most fights to beat the game, you get more exp.  In the expert version you can finish the game at level 50 but on casual it's around 70.  	Expert difficulty also creates the importance of the crafting system where you actually have to use items and upgrades to survive.  There is a crafting system in the game called Oculli which isn't explained so much, but it isn't that convuluted that you wouldn't understand it with some practice.  The game also gives you a lot to use for crafting.  Basically they upgrade your strength in certain aspects.  Like the red Oculli gives your character fire damage and the blue one water damage.  They also give you defencive boosts, based on which Oculli is put where.	Overall I'd say this game is good, but don't expect the most immersive rpg mechanics or characterization, that other rpg's like final fantasy have.  This game took me about 14 hours to complete, but I did enjoy my experience.  And it was nice to be able to play an rpg that wasn't going to take me 100 plus hours to beat.  I'd recommend this game to people who want to play an rpg that isn't too hard or takes too much time to get into.  I also recommend playing this game on expert difficulty, which is the way it was meant to be played.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												This game just flat out awed me and filled me so full of nostalgic feelings for the RPGs I played on my Playstation when I was a young girl. What I love most was the battle system which was a slightly more dynamic version of the turn-based Active Time Battle system used in many older Final Fantasy games. The visuals are beautiful and the story is entertaining and poetic. I thoroughly enjoyed all the different party members and the game's plot. Literally, my only disappointment is I wish this game was longer, because I didn't want it to end so soon. Also, it requires Uplay, a client provided through Ubisoft. Based on other reviews, it appears to be finicky. But I didn't seem to experience any problems with it. Even after I had nearly stopped playing the game for a year and went back to play it again later, I incurred no serious issues with the Uplay service.If you're into RPGs you should definitely give this game a try. And if you're not too familiar with the style of RPGs, don't worry. This game is straight forward, easy to get into and quite intuitive when it comes to controls.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												The most enjoyable RPG I've played in a long time. Its mechanics are solid, easy to pick up and play, and never seem to leave me bored like so many other RPGs. Its a little on the light-weight side, but its design is very intuitive and to the point, but still presenting a challenge. It has checks and balances against "min-maxing", but that's often done simply. The progression system is also simple compared to older RPGs and some modern one (though much more advanced than, say, games like Final Fantasy 13 or World of Warcraft). The story is very nice and inspiring, very melancholy and darkly beautiful. Its like looking through the eyes of an innocent child at a destitute world; that's pretty much the theme throughout. Its more than the sum of its parts in the emotions which it evokes.Its a long-run RPG but ends abruptly, however it still manages to wrap things up nicely. As far as I can tell, there are no end-game quests, no "ultimate weapons" to be had, which I find somewhat disapointing. I know there's some things I haven't completed, but I'm not holding my breath for anything like, say Final Fantasy 8's endgame.All in all its a great game, and one of the best of its generation of games (Xbox 360 era till now).

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												okay here's the lowdown: this game has great visuals, a gorgeous soundtrack and functional characters/storyline, but good ♥♥♥♥ing LORD the gameplay is tedious, it's actually really peculiar because this game pulls an interesting twist on the traditional turn-based rpg combat system and implements a time bar that can be influenced to determine who strikes when, but the hindrance that catastrophises not only that glimmer of innovation but also tragically the rest of the game was how ♥♥♥♥ing monotonous and repetitive the gameplay was, the whole game circulates so reliantly on level grinding, which is a perfectly fine and definitely expected aspect to appear in an rpg, but not when you have to do it legitimately 85-90% of your time playing it. that's not an exaggeration, i've spent 18 hours on this game and i'm willing to bet 14 of them absolute minimum were dedicated to grinding. and i played it through on the easy difficulty too, god forbid anyone even attempts to grind through the hard difficulty because you won't be getting those hours back my friend. it's seriously such a shame that this one normally traversable issue in an rpg was so massive that it took away from the enjoyable facets into which there was obviously a lot of effort invested. i was going to recommend this game but, in spite of it's overall 6/10 score, from pretty much all angles it's just not worth it: it's too dull for the casual player, it's atrocious both in terms of mental stimulation and accessibility for a brand new player (the gems/items/lore system is poor and disorganised), it's not even that good for a hardcore player who spends their life grinding the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of games because the rest of the game simply becomes uninteresting indeed as a result of how much this game is composed of grinding. like all the ingredients are there to make a nice, simple, pleasant video game experience, but some ♥♥♥♥wit in development knocked over the entire jar labelled 'levelling up system' into the bowl and the end result just left me with a bad taste in my mouth. holy♥♥♥♥♥♥that was probably the best joke i've ever made in my life. anyway don't play this game unless you're willing to go the distance, and i ♥♥♥♥ing mean really go the distance

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												Warning: Indepth reviewVisuals-Gorgeous watercolor artstyle-Charming/cute fairytale-like character designs-Extremely beautiful and detailed environments and scenery aided by the artstyle-High attention to detail for character/skill animations. E.g, main character fumbles around a lot while wielding/using her sword because it is practically the same size as herAudio-Eargasmic fully orchestrated soundtracks-Music styles range from lighthearted disneylike bgm to intense, adrenaline pumping musical scores to sombre, lonely, melancholic pieces-Soundtracks that play during normal monster battles are so epic that they feel more like final boss battles instead-Much effort and detail put into sound effects for every little thing. E.g., sound of barefeet stepping on wet rock as your character moves around a dark forest, or the metal tinkering sound of the crown when it hits the floorStory-Straight out of a fairytale, but with a slightly dark and gloomy atmosphere replacing the usual happy, uplifting mood found in these type of stories-Some nice plot twists and turn of events that match well with the sorrowful mood of the story, but otherwise, fairly straight forward like most fairytales-despite the generally sombre feeling of the story, still heartwarming at times-At its core, a coming-of-age story. People looking for something with an intricate and deep plot will be disappointedCharacters-With the plot being reminiscent of a disney movie, likewise the characters also follow suit (talking animals/ mythological creatures)-Charming/cute characters that compliment each other well due to their distinctive personalities and character traits-Main character (Aurora)  is an incredibly cute and sweet, but brave little girl. (Very likeable protagonist)Dialogue-Everything is spoken in rhymes; adds to the cuteness/fairytaleness of the story, but may become annoying for some people as the game progressesGameplay-Old school turn based combat with several added twists-Order of turns in combat dictated by a timeline mechanic, which is further influenced by an interruption mechanic when characters are attacked during the 'casting' part of the timeline-Timeline/interruption/cursor mechanic help add to the tension/unpredictability of fights and fosters strategic elements unique to these mechanics (e.g, knowing when it is worth using weak, but fast speed attacks to interrupt enemies VS straight brute force killing the monsters with strong but long cast time spells)-However, at its heart, it is still turn based battle, so it will not appeal to all people despite the previously mentioned mechanics that speed up the flow of battleRecommend to everyone but the most diehard haters of turn-based battle.Oh, and theres Uplay. ♥♥♥♥ Uplay. But seriously though, it's worth the hassel of installing and signing up for Uplay to experience this game. Cheers~

Posted: September 4, 2015
												Child of Light is probably the most beautiful game I've ever played.Just to get this clear most, if not all the negative reviews is because ''Uplay ruined this game'' just seriously, grow up! Ubisoft has made their decision and complaining and hating won't make them change it, so just live with it!Ok, back to the game.You're playing as the character Aurora, the Princess of Light who is trapped in a dream world. Your goal is to get back to your father because he's dying, but getting back won't be as easy as it sounds like. She has to fight multiple bosses, help people out and kill enemies. I love the graphics and gotta admit, Ubisoft really did a good job with this game!If you want a game that has a beautiful soundtrack, beautiful game play and the story... It just feels amazing to play. Just for the love of God, buy this game and don't mind the Uplay, I've completed this game 5 times (3 times w/o wifi so it looks like 2 times w/ my gameplay hours) and I gotta admit that I can't get tired of this game. 10/10 from me!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
												On this review, I will be writing the pros and cons instead of just telling you how good the game is. I just wanted to say that this is an awesome RPG with beautiful graphics and with a great mix of platforming.ProsThis game has a sufficient amount of interesting enemies that love the dark, but want to kill you.You can upgrade your protaganist using the skill points you have earned through leveling up.You can distract enemies to avoid engaging in an RPG by shining your partner at them.You can equip a gem to your attacks, armor, or weapons to power them up or give them a buff.I love the hair flow physics it just makes the game feel more magical.Now let us talk about the bad parts of the game(Don't let this convince you into not getting the game if you were thinking about it).ConsYour character walks slow for a dramatic fantasy effect(that or my frame rates are low).The wait for executing your turn in the unique RPG battle system is just a hair bit long. It would probably be better if it was a bit shorter.Your partner can distract the enemies during an RPG battle during the waiting term, but loses stamina while doing that.In dark areas you need to not only light your partner up, but also move him throught the area as well.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
												Do you want to be a princess? Or a fairy? Or a queen? Do you want to see the summers of a land that's never been? Do you want to walk in paintings, fly in water, talk in rhyme? Do you want a grand adventure that takes very little time? Have you known a pair of jesters? Does your gnome-beard touch the ground? Does a mouse-man do your taxes? Does a bear-knight stalk you 'round? Have you heard a fish-witch crying? Could you bid the Earth adieu? Then step through the magic mirror. For your daughters, and for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												Child of Light is a 2D side scroller with stunning visuals,creative puzzles and simple RPG elements . This game will require Uplay account to start . I personally never had any problems with Uplay but some people do . If you not getting CD key , delet Uplay and install latest version (it should let you in without cd key)Please note that this game will not run well on integrated graphics unless you have at least low end card build into your computer . Requirments for this game are very low but not low enough to run it on Labtops that are build for internet browsing . The Story in this game is very generic as some people pointed out in negative reviews . All the plot twists are predictable but my eyes were tearing more than once. It is a same story about princess and stepmother you herd a million times but it does a good job of conveying emotions and setting the atmosphere . Granted you have to like kid stories to fully enjoy this game .Gameplay is a turn-based combat . It is like old over the top RPG games only in 2D side scroller. You have to run into enemies to start combat so its not in real time . If you played many RPGs I would recommend starting the game on expert mode or it might be too easy . Few boss fights kicked my booty so I had to grind few levels which reminds good old times .I spotted 2 big flawed design mistakes with gameplay . You will notice that enemies do not have any information regarding their resitances (some are color coded and the other are not ) I made a guide for that if you run into that problem .Also if you use AOE buffs they will only apply to 2 party members that are in the combat ( which is wird because after using a Buffing character you would want to switch to damage character so it defeats the purpose of AOE buff)There are 7 to 8 characters ( 9 with DLC ) that will be in your party . They all have their own skill trees with passive and active skills . You will need to strategically use each one to beat the game .Beside gameplay this game is very pretty  . You don't see many big companies do these kind of games and I have to say that Ubi deservs some praise on this one . I mean it looks like you playing inside the painting entire time .You can play this game with 2 players in a HotSeat . One will control Aurora and the other will control a little flying thing that can pick items , slow down enemies and heal party members .I don't have kids but if  you have 7-10 year olds maybe it will be a fun activity . This game is pretty much kid friendly .Overall I would give this game 9/10 for what it is . If you like RPGs,pretty side scrollers and kid's stories then it should be a fun experience .

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												Wow... This is a really great game. Not good, great. It has all the mechanics that make a game interesting. You can find the Final Fantasy turn based combat when you first encounter combat, sadly you only use 2 companions at any time.PROS1. StorylineIt's amazing. It starts off with in 1895 Austria with the story of princess Aurora. Her mother is a duchess but died early. Aurora's father, the king, brings Aurora up on his own. Later on, he marries a dark woman as he is lonely. Conincidentally, Aurora catches a cold which causes her to get sick (I think it's pneumonia) and she dies.If you read on, the story delves deeper into the land of Lumeria and a find a deeper battle between Umbra and the light.2. Combination of Mechanics You have Igniculus, the ball of light which you can control with mouse or a 2-player controller. You use him to activate mechanisms, slow down enemies in combat and blind enemies.3. Combat SystemInitiative based system which is amazing. You even get to use Igniculus to slow enemies down.4. FlyingThat won the game for me. Instead of the double jump cliche, flying took the game to a whole new level. It expanded the possibilities of the game so much more. 5. Light PuzzlesPretty cool.6. Background and ForegroundAmazing. When I saw the giant moving in the background, it really made my day.7. Attention to DetailAurora's hair falls about when you jump and fall off ledges. It's beautiful. It's the little things like this that make the game amazing.8. Igniculus, the ElementalThe glowing orb is so useful, let me list the ways.a. Hints on your questsb. Collecting energy and health in combatc. Blinding enemies while travellingd. Slowing enemies while in combate. Activating mechanisms which require lightf. Picking up Confessionsg. Story buddyh. Healingi. Illumination9. The Bells in the Capilli VillageI love it. If you fly into the bells, the bells jingle.10. MusicThe piano accompaniement is so soothing and beautiful. Kudos to the composer.11. CharactersRubella - Jester HealerGolem - Ancient GolemFinn - Capelli MageNorah - Swift Fighter (Betrays you)Aurora - Leader UnitRobert - Mouse ArcherGem - SorceressOengus - FighterTristin - Better copy of RubellaCONS1. Contact Points between the FloorsBefore you get Flying, sometimes just up onto a second level is extremely difficult.2. DLCA lot of the game is DLC-based. But I'll let it slide because the game is amazing.3. 2 Character Combat2 is kind of a few. It would be better with 3.4. Repeated MonstersAlthough there are many uniques monsters, you will find repeats where monsters just change colour from green to red to blue to black. There is also a case of changing monsters from from a live version to a zombie version, but I like this one.Total number of uniques area. Boar manb. Ogrec. Spike dogd. Needle nose flyere. Ghost Horsef. Alligator guard (Has a Zombie version)g. Bird guardh. Spirit of Deathi. Leaf insectj. Centaur ArcherSUGGESTIONS1. Ailment ListCould you provide a hot tip to show what the ailments mean? I had to guess that paralyze was you could move on the action bar.2. Igniculusa. Distracting large and dangerous enemiesb. Uncovering hidden symbols which can't be seem unless illuminatedc. Getting eaten by a large beast.3. MultiplayerI'm actually wondering if you could split the heroes and Igniculus on an online battle. 4. More Monster Slots + Hero SlotsI would like to see a 3 v 7 battle. Like the 3 heroes being surrounded. Just like Final Fantasy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												Child of Light.An exquisite game.The game delivers an amazing storyline paired with a beautiful soundtrack.The story had me from the beginning, very interested as I discovered the game was set in a (magnificent!) fairytale setting, until the end, as I defeated the final boss with some epic boss music. The story leaves nothing to desire. The dialogs fit perfectly with the universe, just like the small little sound effects.I'll have to admit too, Ubisoft Montréal did a great job at the art works. Just like Rayman Origins/Legends, the artsyle is amazing and leaves for some very beautiful sights. The handpainted-look perfectly fits in with the fairytale setting.The gameplay may not seem like a lot at first sight. In some way it's your average turn-based RPG. In another way, it's not. You can control a companion which not only helps you with puzzles, but also during battles. It perfectly adds in the amount of complexity it needed. Easy to learn, hard to master kind of thing. If you want to use it optimally, it would require some experience. During boss battles, decent control of this little companion is necessary if you want to survive.tldr: Nice little turn-based RPG, beautiful in story and graphics.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18
												Child of Light is a fantastic game with a fairytale aesthetic, using classic storybook tropes, but using them effectively enough to make them enjoyable. The mechanics of the game are clean, borrowing ideas from JRPGs like Final Fantasy, with turn-based combat that simultaneously has real-time elements, and other tools like crafting and skill trees.Yes, the ending is rushed, but it isn’t terrible; the plot elements would likely have remained the same had more time been afforded to the development team. But there are other games that rushed or less than ideal endings that are still considered classics, such as Obsidian’s Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic 2, or Bioware’s Mass Effect trilogy. Video games by their nature should be more focused on giving joy in the journey, and this is exactly what Child of Light does.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												Child of Light is a very atmospheric and pretty game. The art style is lovely and well animated (I simply adore Aurora's hair!) and each character quite different from the next. The musical pieces sound unique and fit the setting well.A few times you are asked to make a decision by starting or ignoring a quest, though the only way this will affect your game is the number of allies you have at your disposal.The ending came quite out of the blue and with no real build-up. To be honest I was quite disappointed with that, as I had expected for more to happen and the final boss to at least be a bit of a challenge, which was really not the case.Once you've beat it for the first time you have the option to start a "New Game +". This means that while you have to collect your allies from the start, you still get to keep your items, skill tree, level and confessions. The enemies are a bit harder too, but that's pretty much it, so there's no real re-play value in my opinion.I would also have loved for the dialogue to have a voice over option, but all in all it was still a very fun and captivating game.I did not and will not bother buying any of the DLCs as aside from a new character they bring nothing new to the table in regards to game play or story.=====================||                          |||| This is a Giveback Review! ||||                          ||=====================

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												Overall a nice game.I played through it on normal difficulty (there is also "expert").It is definitely a title worth trying if you are into rpg's, however there are some shortcomings.The game felt short, and although there was a nice build-up, the ending felt a very abrupt and a little anti-climactic. There are some really cool boss fights, but towards the end, they start to feel like they recycled the ideas.The fighting system was decent -- the interrupt timing system makes it so it isn't just mindless spamming attack (like many of the greatest rpg's unfortunately do). The mouse (faerie) clicking mechanic to heal allies/slow enemies was nice, again, perhaps they could've done more with it.The cast of characters are good, but I wish there was more synergy between them in battle; also I would've liked some more fluid combat to keep the pace rolling.The gem crafting system was nice, but there weren't enough gems to properly equip all your characters, so maybe they want to relook at that system, since it has potential. I never had to use a single item throughout the game.Beautiful art, good music (although also recycled). There is good potential here if they decide to do some sort of sequel or spiritual successor. The game was very good and could have been great.Worth getting (on sale), the Golem character dlc is skippable. You won't miss much. Although he is a good character, the game is well balanced without him and he feels like a little bit too much given how diverse the party becomes. Also his story/dialogue is somewhat forgettable (wise old sentry, strong body, but missing something inside, providing wisdom to characters about finding themselves... yep, not cliched at all).6-7/10

content:
Posted: February 18
												Um RPG-lite lindo graficamente, com um estilo bem único. O ar de conto de fadas permeia tudo do início ao fim. A história não é muito profunda, e os diálogos às vezes soam meio forçados pra encaixar nas rimas (todas as falas são rimadas, pra manter o tom de uma fábula).Infelizmente o sistema de combate acaba sendo maçante, pois gira em torno de interromper ações inimigas e evitar que suas ações sejam interrompidas. Qualquer ação leva um tempo pra ser executada, e sofrer um ataque enquanto isso faz com que seja cancelada. O problema é que você controla apenas dois personagens, enquanto os inimigos costumam ser 3 - ou seja, não é incomum você passar um ou dois turnos apenas vendo seus personagens tentando agir e não conseguindo. Isso não torna o jogo difícil, apenas chatinho nas batalhas - ele é boa indicação pra um iniciante no gênero, pois o nível de dificuldade é bem leve - e ainda tem a opção de deixar os combates mais fáceis ainda jogando no modo Casual. Mas, se conseguir ignorar essa parte, não é um jogo ruim. Só deixou um pouco a desejar.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												"Beware the night, Child of Light."One of the aesthetically vibrant, turn-based rpg game one can play. The complexity of gem crafting and proper turn exection may look simple yet its subtleness and the flow of the actual gameplay is astounding. Every place, dimension, and sceneries are a definite sight to behold. Most of its puzzles are simple and self-explanatory, however, the game makes up for its interesting style of battle sequence, becuase it forces you to take advantage of situation everytime you face an enemy. There are many ways of building your character. Ranging from skill trees to varieties of gem, the game easily reflects the result of how effective the builds are against enemies. So one should be mindful and carefully learn all the necessary factors because the game can be quite challenging even if it is in normal mode.Amazing graphics, unique yet complex battle mechanic, and great character development, what more a person can want? Therefore, this game is perfect for Final Fantasy lovers, players that are looking for a change of pace, and especially those that are obssessed in the quality of graphics (including me).P.S. 3 Princess Stones equipped to Aurora = OP

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												This game is incredibly beautiful. The art, music and story are all inspiring.Game play involves a standard RPG style system. If you've played any version of a Final Fantasy game then you will be right at home with Child of Light's game play. Elemental damage/resistance, gem crafting to be slotted in equipment and basic skill trees all serve to give you some level of customization without becoming too complicated.The system and story all make for a beautiful and inspiring introduction to RPGs for a casual gamer or children. For everyone else, it is a calm meditation as one becomes lost in the beauty and travails of lost Lemuria.

Posted: July 31, 2014
												This game is beautiful, well written and hands down the best game purchase I've made in years. I read the reviews before purchasing it and the only negative thing I found was that people don't like Uplay. Do not let that stop you from buying this game. The storyline is poetry (literally) the combat system is party based (2 members) that you can swap out mid combat. There is an ability tree system with 3 trees per character as well as a gem socketing system for your attack, defense and utility slots. This game is amazing, hands down. I seriously found a diamond in the rough when I picked this game up. I really hope that they make more games simliar to this.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Altamente recomendable, visualmente impresionante y con una banda sonora envolvente. La jugabilidad es simple pero no por ello se hace pesado o aburrido.La dificultad no llega a ser un reto en el modo casual pero si lo suficiente para no sentir que no tienes que pensar los movimientos.Es un juego realmente no te arrepientes de comprar ya que se disfruta tanto en jugabilidad (Difiere sustancialmente de la mayoria de juegos actuales) como en historia, la cual si bien no da grandes giros, su universo, dialogos y personajes atrapan lo suficiente para mantenerte enganchado.Algo negativo a destacar es que debes instalar uplay por narices lo cual crea en primer lugar el doble sistema de logue y logros y por otra parte imposibilita compartir el juego con el sistema de Steam Family.Aparte es practicamente necesario jugar a nueva partida+ si quieres llegar a nivel máximo y conseguir varias de las mejores gemas, algo practicamente obligatorio para los fans de los RPG clásicos.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Highly recommended, visually stunning and a marvelous soundtrack. The gameplay is simple but not boring nor repetitive. The difficulty does not become a challenge in casual mode but is enough to feel you have to think about the plays. It's a game that really you won't regret to buy, because both gameplay (differs substantially from most current games) and history ( which is a common one but his universe, dialogues and characters attract enough to keep playing. ) is highly enjoyable.One negative part is that you must install Uplay, that first creates twice login and achievements systems (ubisoft and steam ofc) and otherwise its impossible to share the game with Steam Family. Moreover is necessary play new game + if you want to reach the highest level and get more of the best gems, and that is practically mandatory for classic RPG fans (or hardcore players XD).

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												A good place to start for anyone new to the rpg genre. The game has wonderful imagery and the atmosphere is set well. The combat system is similar to the active time battle system in older final fantasy games, with a few twists. Also the game has a touch of 2d side scrolling as you explore the world you're in. The game isn't too short, but it is easy, so if you want a challenge with your RPG then stick the difficulty up to expert. Replay value comes in the form of a New Game + mode after you finish, which keeps your skills and Occuli from your save file, in return for harder opponents. In short for the price this is a really well made rpg, and if you're curious about the genre and whether you would like this give it a shot. As a major rpg fan, I can definitly recommend this title.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Fantastic art and flavor with a good mix of classic RPG and Platformer elements.  The writing and storyline very much mimic that of folk tales and though sometimes the rhyming is a little too cute for my taste, it doesn't distract from the engaging plot.  The music perfectly complements the storytelling and can be both beautiful and light and eerily haunting. Stunning and unexpected visuals will periodically take your breath away as you explore the world of light and darkness,  Overall one of the best games I've played in a long time.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
*This game requires Uplay third party downloaded.**I played this on another account, so my hours on Steam aren't accurate.* Level0ne Curator  Child of Light    Score Comments   Gameplay 7 The controls of Child of Light were fair but felt clunky as a platformer. Flying was fun until I had to navigate smaller spaces, in which I found I was often crashing the sides and hurting myself. I didn’t so much enjoy the battles, as they got a bit repetitive. It's a platformer with RPG stats, but I found I wasn't interested in the stats. Also the Oculli crafting system felt rushed with some chance buffs not that helpful in battle.   Story 8 I liked moments of the story, but wasn’t completely enthralled. I liked the idea of the story being told in a rhyme, but eventually I was cringing at it. Perhaps a better story could’ve been told without the nursery rhymes constricting it.   Graphics 10 I really enjoyed the graphics of Child of Light. I found it was beautiful to look at, and while flying around the art and environment was wonderful. It felt very much like a children’s storybook and the art style looked hand painted.   Audio 9.5 I really enjoyed the soundtrack to this game. The music here really set the mood at the appropriate moments. The sounds in the game were fitting and often guided/alerted me when I was begrudgingly entering battle.   Replayability 3 While it was a relatively fun game to play, I can’t see myself continuing to maximize my character’s stats/abilities any further, let alone replaying the game again. With a decent story and gameplay, I have no wishes to return to Lemuria.   Overall 7.5 Child of Light set me in a beautiful place called Lemuria. The music added to the tranquil beauty. But the controls felt awkward at times, though didn’t hinder me too much. I want to love the story, but unfortunately I couldn’t get passed the rhyming. 												I absolutely adore this game.The art style is simple, but very pretty.The poetry/rhyming in the game is quite interesting, and more times than not, funny.Art style is very watercolour like, and very vibrant.The characters are charming.Battle is very Final Fantasy style. content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												A beautiful game that really shows how video games can do story telling differently than books, movies, and shows. The actual gameplay is sort of an evolution from classic turn-based RPGs (e.g. FF6) where you have 2 active characters at any given time but can swap characters out anytime it's your turn. On normal it didn't require a great deal of strategy to get through most fights (a couple were scary for sure even so), I imagine it's a bit brutal on the harder difficulty. It may seem short for a story-telling RPG but it really is just about a perfect length for itself. Highly recommend this game, goes up on the top-tier shelf and is another excellent example of how a game can both be fun and tell a story in a unique way. Also it's purty.5/5 fireflies

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												Child of Light is a 10-15 hour game that incorporates elements of turn-based rpgs and platforming in order to weave a tale of fantasy and lost kingdoms.  Immediately striking is the use of water-color inspired backdrops and lighting effects. Each new area and set piece within the game was designed with the same level of care and detail that one would expect from traditional art. The soundtrack, as well as the tone of the storyline, invokes a strange sense of nostalgia for fairy tales and children’s books. Without divulging any spoilers, there are elements of the storyline that mirror tales by Hans Christian Andersen and the Brothers Grimm. And much like these authors tales there lays a certain air of darkness and sadness to the story narrative of Child of Light. Despite this, I consider the game to be suitable for kids. The gameplay element was both familiar and simplistic, however the use of the right analog stick to assist in puzzle solving added a bit of flavor and variety to the platforming. Battles were fought using a turn-based system, with the ability to slow or speed up a character or enemy along in the timeline. This allowed for interesting "on-the-fly" decisions that made the combat fun and allowed for a bit of strategy to be incorporated. XP is awarded after winning battles which can be used to develop a skill tree. Each character the player encounters in the game will have various "specialty" skills, and each may be switched out during combat. There is also a crafting feature in the game that will result in various gems that will "buff" certain skills in battle.Overall, the game was not very difficult. I found the puzzle solving to be a somewhat shallow, and even the combat, albeit seemingly deep within the first few hours, became mechanical and grinding towards the end. However, the overarching experience of Child of Light was satisfying and charming. The amount of work put into creating the fantastical and whimsical atmosphere of Child of Light is what will remain long after the game's conclusion. I would recommend this game. 8/10

content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												An immersive and beautiful game that would always remain as one of my favorites. With its impeccable artwork and illustrious plot/dialogue, Child of Light never fails to succeed in drawing me deeper into the world of Lemuria.Gameplay was interesting, simple and reminds one of the old school turn based Final Fantasy battle style. Although only 2 characters can be used at any one time, the mechanics are simple and really easy to understand.Furthermore, battles are surprisingly just as lively and beautiful as the game. Characters also level easily and there's absolutely no need to grind! (Unless you tend to skip battles actively!)Character development was done really well, and the repertoire of characters with their lively dialogues truly brings the game to life.For only $15, this game is honestly quite the steal! I am even willing to pay $30 for this treasure!Most importantly, the soundtrack is just so beautiful and in synchrony with the plot that as a casual gamer, I really took my time to listen in and enjoy the calming melodies the game has to offer. Definitely getting the entire soundtrack!  Highly recommend this to any casual gamers out there who wants to enjoy 11-13 hours of a beautifully drawn masterpiece and live out your conventional fairytale in Child of Light! C: P.S. I thought the trailer seemed kinda childish at first but the first hour of gameplay showed me how wrong I am to judge this game so quickly at face value, hope everyone out there enjoys this game! Have not tried the DLCs but will get around to it!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
												Wow, just beat this amazing game last night and it moved me so much as a person that I owe UbiArt a review.Right out of gate, I want to comment on Uplay. This game (as with other ubisoft games) requires the installation of Uplay, which is a game launcher that runs outside of steam. Every time you play it does make you log in to Uplay, and while some view this as the biggest annoyance in the world, I honestly don't mind Uplay and barely notice it anymore. Now that I have this covered I will break down the rest of the game in readable chunks.Menu Interface - 9 - I played the game with a controller pad, and found everything accessible, my only minor complaint is in the crafting screen where it can get frustrating to remove gems. Open World Interface - 10 - Playing outside of combat is a thing of beautiful and fluid experience, not once did I feel like Aurora or Igneous was not an extension of myself. Exploration and loot gathering is well paced, and still offers a challenge for those completionists out there. Puzzles and open world dangers offer complexity and can require fluid control, but did not frustrate me or deter my desire to explore. Engaging combat is controllable, and the few times I was ambushed by a well placed enemy it was honestly fun.Combat Interface - 9 - Turn based combat has a nostalgic grab for me personally, and I can say Child of Light does it right. The default combat speed gradually introduces you to the flow of combat, and once you feel you have it locked down you can up the speed for a more seamless experience with quicker progression. My only wish is that I could have a third party member on the board during combat. UbiArt made up for this by allowing on the fly member switching, but I still felt like combat would have been more dynamic with a third member on the board, that said the use of Igneous as support was executed beautifully.Story - 8 - The story of Aurora is enticing and tugged at my heart strings. Her journey through the fantastical world Lumaria expresses personal growth and paints vivid a picture of the pain involved with growing up. While Aurora’s story felt deep and heartfelt, I found myself wanting more depth behind the support characters in addition to their small side quests.Visuals - 10 - I took so many screenshots during my first playthrough I lost count. This game is a testament to how great side scrolling (semi 3D) games can look. Countless times I found myself saying how great the game looked out loud to myself, my girlfriend, or through social media. Audio - 9 - Visuals are important and most gamers put an emphasis on “graphics” as their point of reference to game quality. I am of the opinion that visuals and audio work hand in hand, and Child of Light uses its music to create an immersive atmosphere that compliments its visuals like a twin sibling. My only gripe is that some of the sound effects can get loud and in a few instances became slightly irritating to the point where I turned down the volume. Aside from this small pet peeve, I could not possibly express how touching and appropriate the music is, and has found a place in my playlists.   I could not be happier with my purchase of this game. I was excited to play it months ago, and it has surpassed every expectation I had. Any fan of RPG’s, music, art, and well told stories will enjoy what Child of light brings to the table. I hope this review helps any who are on the fence decide to give this game a shot, you will not be disappointed.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												I cannot recommend this game enough!  From the painted backdrops, to the poetic dialogue, to the characters large and small,  everything in this game is a hand-crafted work of love.  In addition, the exploration and combat are almost exactly like Grandia II, a game which I still consider one of the best, and of having the best combat system in an RPG I've yet to play.My only qualm about Child of Light is that the end comes about a bit abruptly.  As such, you may require a second playthrough to do all of the additional side quests, but that's not really a takeaway when the game is so beautiful and poignant.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												Child of Light. The story of a girl trying to find her way home, while fulfilling a destiny unbeknownst to her. That is the precipice of the story, as for the gameplay. Imagine South Park: Stick of Truth, but with a way larger skill tree and the ability to fly. Half the game is putting the beat down on deadly enemies, the other half is exploring the extensive world that this game offers. It's putting many AAA RPG games to shame. Between the story, incredible art style, the interesting RPG elements and the poetic conversation pieces, this game get's an 8 and a half/10. It would have been better had the DLC's been worthwhile and had it not gone through UPlay in order to play but all in all, one of my new favourite RPG's.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												Really liked this game.    It's beautiful, sometimes sad, sometimes cute... but it always flows, never grinds which is the key.    It's not long to finish, but it's priced very well for what it gives.  Other people like the combat.   Combat and the talent trees are easy to get the hang of it.   Crafting is a little more experiment and learn.   And put together there's a lot of choice.   On the other hand, the game is less challenging in terms of puzzles and combat if you're looking for that...it's pretty easy to never die.   But, this is really about moving and flowing through beautiful and changing scenery and characters and a tragic but still uplifting storyline (compared to the grindingly depressing "Banner Saga").     Plus your situation as Aurora is emotional and interesting and a fair bit different than the usual video game fare.

beautifully.  each different part of the world has new flora and fauna, and its own color scheme.  the many layers make the world look deep and rich, despite movement being strictly 2D.  the lighting brings everything up to an incredible level of beauty.  the allies, enemies, and various populants are unique and designed with great care.  detailed in aethetics and given creative abilities, all the characters contribute something to the feel of the game.  i could easily spend half the game just looking around and exploring the world.  in fact, i did...10/10combat:i have not actually played a Final Fantasy game (a problem i hope to remedy), but the combat is similar in many ways.  it's turn-based battling with various abilities frequently based on elements.  the turns are determined by a timeline-ish mechanic that is also influenced by abilities, which added a very interesting twist to an already solid system.  the mix of all the characters' unique styles of play blend VERY well together even though only two allies can play at a time.  i was a bit disappointed by this initially, but you can pretty easily switch allies during battles, so i ended up feeling okay about it.  there are potions for those that enjoy such things, but i try to do without them if i can help it.9/10non-combat gameplay:there are a few "puzzles" in the game, but they are so simple that it they hardly qualify as such.  fortunately, i never felt like this was why i was supposed to play the game.  there are quests to go on that are basically "go find a few things scattered in places you've been in".  not too crazy, but i enjoyed the opportunity to explore and actually be rewarded for it beyond the fun of checking out all the nooks and crannies.  some could get impatient and bored by visiting old locations, but the quests are decidedly optional, so i wouldn't be too concerned by that.  the map isn't very fancy, but the locations are designed very well and feel very different from one another.  the upgrade tree is interesting, but mostly linear: you pretty much always have three upgrade paths to continually advance without any more options than that.  again, i like the abilites they unlock, you just don't have quite as many options as i prefer.7/10story/plot:the plot isn't necessarily anything crazy or too original (yet), but it isn't really lacking either.  all words are in verse, so that's pretty fantastic!  the characters have bits of dialog often and the narrator will occasionally chime in.  the characters aren't amazingly rich and deep, but they are developed enough to care about them.  it made me enjoy helping them out whenever i could.  basically, the story does advance, and there's been a couple of fun twists, but nothing that really blew my mind.  so it's a entertaining plot with solid characters, but it's maybe not the main reason you should play this game.8/10music:pretty music that really compliments the game, just not sure if it'd be good standing alone.  adds greatly to the feel of wonder and fantasy as you play, though...8/10overall:i have loved every minute of this game.  i've found it to be very well balanced, beautifully made, follows a dandy tale, and is filled with plenty of likable characters.  i haven't yet seen the ending, but so far, i look forward to playing it again on its "hard" setting after finishing the "normal" one...in my opinion, MORE THAN WORTH THE $15 I PAID FOR IT!!  i'll definitely be buying the Golem's Plight pack when i'm finished with the main game...

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												I heard so many wonderful reviews of Child of Light, that I started to be sceptical, and I wanted to know if they were truly as good as everyone said. As I have been so severely let down by triple A titles lately, this seemed like a much needed break. I will sum up everything below in this sentence: Child of Light is the sumation of the genre of RPGs, and an experience I find *essential* to any gamers repitoire. This game started out slow, as many RPGs do, but I was swiftly entranced in what was going on, and suddenly I was 10 hours in and micromanaging my inventory as I panicked about the fact that it was suddenly 5am on a work day. As your party grows, alongside your powers, you may have difficulty deciding who to power up, who to play up, and who to bench, I know I did. I've just prior to writing this discovered a new game plus mode, which I will be devoting this next weekend to. Now I want to break down the game into parts.Graphics 5/5 Now I know this game had such a different style of graphics, but I have to say, it so acurately represents the style it brings, I can't not love it. The fact that I could actually feel accurate depth with the style, and on multiple occasions, that came into play.Story 5/5Yes, it has some of the basics of any RPG, good vs. evil, light vs. dark, and family matters. However, it plays it so well, and makes you care so much, that you get excited and upset, and as someone who not often pines for anything less than a hurt puppy, this is a major deal. Gameplay 3/5Now, don't get me wrong, I loved the gameplay. The combat in this game is one of my favorite features, with how smooth and dynamic it is, yet while being so simple. The only thing is, I know that I like, but I can see where others wouldn't. If you are not a traditional RPGer, and especially level grinder, you may have some rough spots. Overall score 9.1/10While exceedingly beautiful and excelling at exactly what it is, the game has a few faults for those not used to the idea of level grinding, and your finger might cramp a bit from using your firefly companion. However, I would reccomend this game to anyone willing to hear me out.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												This game is a lot of things... but in a word: Delightful.I went in to this game expecting it to be an easy, story-driven game. After all, the poetic dialogue and beautiful artwork do a lot to give the impression of a casual, almost-childish game.What I did not expect was a refreshingly new (and actually somewhat difficult) combat system. Of all the RPGs I've played, the battle system in Child of Light is one of my favorites. Admittedly, the remaining RPG elements are simplified: Stats are gained solely through levels and stat-pumping items, and each character has 3 armor "slots" for various gems. The customization is a little limited in that respect, but I think that to be appropriate given the semi-casual nature of the game.Of course, there's an easy mode (which I do NOT recommend) for those who just want the story.tl;dr - Good artwork, music, nice spin on RPG gameplay, 4.5/5. Would recommend.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												This Fairytale RPG is both beautiful and addictive!  The gameplay is relaxing and rewarding, and the soundtrack and gorgeous watercolour art style are so captivating that it's really easy to lose yourself for hours in this game!  I find the combat system to be really fun--it's a combination between turn-based and real time combat, and I really didn't think it would be possible to successfully combine those styles.  This game also has co-op gameplay available, if someone is playing with you.  The other player can control the firefly with the mouse (or extra controller on consoles) and help out during combat, exploration and puzzle solving.  I think the co-op would be a lot of fun, but I haven't been able to try that out yet.  I did pick up some DLC for this game after playing it for about 10 hours.  I found myself enjoying it enough to warrant picking up some bonus content, and even with the extras, the price of this game is very reasonable!  I highly recommend this game to anyone and everyone :)

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2016
												The TL;DR version - A good RPG, feels familiar with some new mechanics. Story is fun, art is nice, characters are good. Worth full price, DEFINITELY worth sale price. Get it. Good casual RPG.--I waited two years to purchase Child of Light, waiting for it to be on sale. Finally I got my hands on this highly praised game, not actually really knowing exactly what it was. I only knew it had a neat art style and only recently found out it was a turn based combat RPG.This game is surprisingly great. If you enjoy RPGs, I highly recommend it. Even at the full price of $14.99, it is well worth it. The mechanics are both familiar and new - a very refreshing touch. I don't want to give away too much, but it is a game that makes the turn based combat even more strategic than most games of the same genre. You can interrupt enemies or be interrupted yourself, and you can use your little Firefly companion to slow enemies or aid your allies in and out of fights. The music is fun, although for the most part you're listening to the same song over and over in different compositions. Thankfully the song is good, but I feel like I only walked away remembering the main song.Every character in your party serves a purpose. At first I felt like I was just playing favorites, but different characters are very good against different enemies and you'll have an opportunity to utilize all of them. The example I can best give is your healer - for the most part, you won't need one if you're playing strategically well enough. But when the boss battles come around and the fights are more drawn out, you best believe you'll need one. The characters are also all very diverse and interesting, and reasonably interesting. I wouldn't say they're terribly deep, but I have so far enjoyed them all. My only complaint is that you can only use two characters in a fight at a time, out of your roster of 5 or 6. What's nice is that everyone benefits from the experience, which is definitely a bummer in other RPGs. But I would definitely have enjoyed fighting with three characters out at once, even if the enemies were a little tougher. However, your team is easily rotatable during a fight (much like Final Fantasy X for those that are familiar). I would definitely give this game at least an 8 out of 10, maybe even a 9. I have yet to beat it, but wanted to give it a brief review part way through. I'll be sure to update this review once I finish the game.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												Storyline: 6/10It's interesting and evokes some feels, but it's not anything that would incite any intense emotions.Gameplay: 7/10The combat system is simplistic for those who don't want to think too much, but also quite in-depth for those who want to get down and dirty. Every character has his own niche and are all good in their own rights. They all have their individual skill trees that will increase their stats and unlock new abilities. There are also gems in the game that serve as equipment for your party members, and they can be combined into newer and stronger gems.Graphics: 7/10The background is pretty cool, drawn in a free flowing, paint brush style. There's nothing really super flashy or impressive in the characters and animations, but there are also very few eyesores.Content: 2/10This is the biggest selling point, or lack thereof. I personally finished the first playthrough of the game in about 15 hours, and this includes a moderate amount of grinding and looting (both can be skipped). The game is too easy; there are autosaves at literally everything you do, enter a door, beat an enemy, open a chest, etc etc. There are no penalties for death, if you can even manage that; one can heal up to full HP/MP at any point in the game with the help of Igniculus and wishes. There's also a new game+ option, but this is farily trivial, as it is easier than the first playthrough. XP gains are boosted, causing all characters to be fairly overleveled have most of the important skills when they are needed. After beating the second playthrough, the game doesn't get any harder, so trying to beat the game a third time will only result in one hitting most enemies along the way. I was pretty hyped to be able to max out all of the characters and gems (which is actually pretty time consuming), only to realize that there's nothing to use my powered up party members on.Overall, not recommended if you want a long term investment like an in-depth RPG. It was entertaining while it lasted though.

												I honestly really enjoy this game. The beginning is a little annoying when you are getting used to the controls and the timing (everything seems to move in slow motion due to "dream world") but after a while its no problem. There are a ton of really awesome mechanics that make the game more fun and not a run of the mill turn based game. Combat has a timing element, with a window for "casting" (basically when your preparing your attack) and you can interupt enemies while they are casting which essentially skips them. You can slow down your enemies with your firefly companion so you can skip ahead of them. There are also attack types like in pokemon with light being strong against dark, water against fire, etc. that adds to the mix. Overall, for the price, I would say this game is really good. Something that gets old is the constant rhyming in dialogue, but thats just my opinion. It does not ruin the game, it just gets on my nerves. I would say the depth of story and the cool mechanics more than compensates for annoying dialogue. Overall I'd give it 8.5/10

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												Child of Light is a family-friendly game that is written all in rhyme, designed to be played as 2-players side by side (so parents, maybe this is how you enjoy games with your kids rather than shooing them from the room so you can play Saint's Row - or worse, letting them stay in the room with you and play all your M-rated titles)At best, CoL is a beautiful combination of painting and poetry, which can teach young players some basic platforming and turn-based RPG elements, with a competent adult actually doing the playing, the little player 2 can enjoy the narrative and do a few things that are much needed, once they are shown the way. As an adult, playing it by yourself, will you enjoy it as much? Well, probably not, which isn't to say it's a bad game, after all, you will be able to see how much work has gone into making this game, and while it may be simple, well that's all the more credit to it, it's a smart design and it doesn't overcomplicate things.Just, do not, I repeat, do not, under any circumstances, buy oculi. I bought the entire bundle of them along with all the other micro-transacion DLC, but without really knowing why. I guess it's just something we're used to seeing from AAA game devs, and we've been letting them get away with it. (I bought the game and DLC on sale though, otherwise I wouldn't have had even a passing interest in this based on other peoples' reviews that all gripe about Uplay.)So what are oculi, then? Well, they are gems, that go into sockets on your weapons and armor, each having a small stat benefit, and they are craftable within 3 tiers. They drop in the game as well, so if you don't buy them, don't worry, you get them included in the game already, and for the price of a couple dollars for 3-4 of them, really, you can't let yourself get ripped off like that. It's not like you have to seek out the hardest difficulty setting, there is a casual mode, and really, that's the only way I think it should be played, so you can enjoy it for what it is, and put the evil "Corporate Commander" EA / Ubisoft, out of your mind.Pros:- Painted beautiful artifacts in the game, back to front - Simple, but logical puzzles and turn-based RPG combat- Gem crafting is straightforward (It's a good thing to have in the game, not a good thing to be nickle and dimed to death over)- The game's entirely written in poem, so while cheesy, it can produce entertainmentCons:- The Golem and other DLC are BEYOND DOUBT content that was supposed to already be in the game, but was gouged out to make more DLC microtransactions - Uplay can be invasive, especially if you don't have a bunch of Ubisoft games (I don't) and CoL will not launch from steam, so Uplay has to be running and you have to have an account - Some people reported bugs and lost save data from Uplay, I have not as yet had it happen to me.Final Verdict7/10 - The gameplay is solid, if simple. The creators of the game put a lot of time, effort and talent into producing this game, it's just such a shame that their work is tainted by the greedy actions of corporate cronies pulling at our pursestrings. TL:DRChild of Light good, Ubisoft bad.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												Graphics/artwork and music are all fantastic, and set the mood perfectly.  Unfortunately, the story is a bit too...plain?  You could argue that it was intended for a younger audience, but even then...the writers underestimate children's ability to understand more "mature" subject matter.  The result is a story that feels diluted, compared to the richness of the visuals.Gameplay starts off very slow & simple.  But once you get a couple chapters in, it picks up nicely.  The combat system is similar to Final Fantasy, but with two key twists thrown in.  First, if you attack a monster while it's in the red "Cast" portion of its timeline, you can interrupt it, setting it back to an earlier position.  And second, you (or a friend) can shine the firefly companion's light on one enemy to slow it down.  These two simple elements allow for a surprising amount of strategy, making it possible to chain-interrupt enemies rather than relying on passive defense.Over all, I'm having fun, and it's a nice change of pace from the many overly-shiny 3D games out there now.  It's not perfect, but I think it's definitely worth checking out.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												***Note: Negative review is for rpg turn-based mechanics lover. If you are just looking for a light rpg experience with platform elements with beautiful gfx, certainly this game is for you. Otherwise for deep turn based mechanics rpg, better look elsewhere ***I would like to give thumbs up for Child of Light, also because I was really looking forward to play it.But as big turn-based rpgs fan, I really can't upvote it.Before I get flamed for my negative reviews: the game itself is not that bad, the graphic is just so amazing, the soundtrack beuatiful and enchanting. The story was also good enough so far.But if after 6 hours I don't feel any kind of addiction of going on, something is wrong.And the problems are the mechanics. The platform elements are ok, but the turn-based ones are definitely not enough and too much repetitive. I am playing in "expert" mode and everything got after 2-3 hours too boring and repetitive. I've nothing abount grinding (thing that is not really required in this game) when the story keeps pushing you to continue because you want to know more, but this is not the case - too long intervals between exploration and story continues. I never used an item except on the third boss (and I was plenty of pots). The creatures are too similar and predictable (weakness to element). And party of 2 persons (even if you can switch them) is  limiting too much the field choices. So far the only thing I did was casting a spell, melee attack with the other, and replace with healer as needed. I'm very sorry but I am going to abandon it for now. It's really a shame and an hard decision because the graphic is such a pleasure for the eyes. Shame.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												This REALLY is that time you want a 'MAYBE' option - I'm going with "Not Recommended" because of just 1 aspect of the game but it's an important one I think.The combat is awful - truly and utterly awful.  It's killing the game for me - I'm actively avoiding it as much as I can but sooner or later you have to do it and it's just so BORING.Enemies have no health bars so you've little idea what's going on without staring at flying damage numbers/messages to judge efficacy.  The timing system gets truly unfollowable once there are multiple players on either side and specials etc. are scarce and often ineffective.Worst thing is it just doesn't fit the rest of the game at all - it's a curiously static and lifeless thing in a game otherwise packed with joy and sparkle.Everything else is fine - story, graphics, sound, controls are work well  (the rhyming gets a bit grating but you can skip it without losing the jist of what's going on) but the combat isn't easily avoided - you'll probably spend more time doing it than anything else - and it really is tiresome.Maybe play it on easy to get the atmosphere and story and then move along eh?p.s. I see much wailing about uPlay and whilst I don't like launchers in launchers, it works fine for me so I can't really complain about it.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 17, 2015
												I had heard pretty good things about Child of Light.  It looked pretty cool so I thought I'd give it a shot.  Well, the background artwork is quite nice, for sure, but the design and animation of the characters feels a bit sloppy (though I do like the flowing hair).  Besides that, I don't have much to complain about what it looks like.  The game itself, however, is not very interesting.  Even the puzzles are simple and somewhat repetitive, involving lighting up different objects in a pattern.  While flying around and collecting treasure and potions I forget to use can be mildly entertaining, the battles are a disappointment.  It works kind of like turn based strategy of sorts, where you can use your glowing firefly to slow down the opponents.  In other words, battles are about timing and luck.  Even though you get different characters and can work strategies out with the different styles, the main problem is that it is boring.  It is the same type of battle over and over and over again.  Fly around, fight new monsters, fly around, fight more monsters.  Also, I would have liked it if at least three characters could be placed in the battle at a time like the enemies are.  I want to like the game, but I really just can’t.  The fights are pretty long and simply a lot of repetition of trying to blast enemies with your most powerful spell while attempting to avoid becoming paralyzed.  It can take forever.  Lastly, this is more of a personal preference, but I did not like the dialog between characters that shows up quite often.  It does not add to the plot and the poetry feels hastily thrown together to find something, anything that rhymes.  It gets annoying, especially when a new character joins the team and then every single other character must introduce themselves to that one.  Overall, I think the game could have been much better if there were a few tweaks made to it, but as it stands, I’m not very impressed.  Also, Uplay is a hassle.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2014
												DISSAPOINTING. Excuse the caps, but I thought it might ask for a bit of attention amongst the floods of positive reviews. The combat in this game is extremely repetitious, and very limited in terms of play styles. Despite having many characters available, you are only able to fight with two at any given time. The skills and simple trees are relatively uninspired, or should I say, extremely inspired by what has frequently been used in past RPG's. The visuals -while aesthetically o.k- really don't go far enough considering the financial backing of ubisoft. Using items/healing/skilling up is tedious with a non-user friendly one at a time character view, and the whole craft your own gems (which add stats/buffs) is equally as limited. You end up making the same ~5 gems over and over again but in higher concentrations (and stat bonuses). This game will pleasantly waste some of your hours, but it is probably not worth the asking price. That being said, it may be a more enjoyable game for a very young audience. I'm 24.

number of helpful: 12 of 23 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												After playing it for a couple of hours more I cannot recommend Child of Light. It's very dull gameplay and almost cringeworthy dedication to making up rhymes for every single line of dialogue, which not only breaks the immersion but also makes me roll my eyes way too hard, makes it a very mediacore experience. I could ignore the terrible idea of rhyming if the gameplay made up for it, but neither the exploration of the world, which is reduced to some simple puzzles and really dodgy 'platforming' (more like dodging obstacles in air really), nor the RPG-esque fighting really qualify this game as 'fun'. The fights drag on for longer than necessary and even the 'weaknesses' become meaningless: you attack a fire looking monster so you equip oculi for water attack and fire defence. But you realize when you enter a fight that it also has an earth and air buddy. Also the game plain lies to you - defending is supposed to prevent you from being interrupted the game says, and then happily introduces enemies who ignore defence and knock you back despite defending. At the same time the AI is pretty dumb, often not 'finishing off' characters with low health and instead going for the full health party member, which means you can't really leave low HP people as decoy either.So the gameplay is dull, how about the story?The characters are varied sure but it's easy to see more effort went into finding rhymes than into actually making the characters memorable. I can berely say anything about the people in my party and it seems like they talk a lot - yet except for terrible rhymes the dialogues contain little to none information. It takes a lot of talent to convey a story through rhymes and the writer here just plain failed in most cases.Also you can tell how desperate he or she was for rhyming when a child uses words like 'commerce'. Aurora uses words that don't fit into child's mouth. So yes, rhymes make the game lose the immersion factor.Overall it's a pretty looking experiment of a game that failed in delivering whatever it was they tried to do.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												My wife and I selected this game,because it offered a co-op campaign.we loved the art, right from the start,'til the last monster was slain-------------------------------------------------------------I'm reviewing this from the perspective of someone who played as the secondary character while my wife controlled the main player through our 15 hour campaign. Right away I want to applaud the game developers for creating an interesting co-op mechanic. The main player in solo play could just control the secondary role themselves (in fact they still can while another person is plugged in), if you are able to multitask and be effective it pays off to control the sprite character during hard battles. Giving the second player the role of this sprite splits the responsibility so that you don't have to consider as many options during fights, but you will still want to coordinate with the other player to perfect your timing.It's obvious that this game is uniquely beautiful. Ubisoft came up with a graphics engine that does a great job representing the mythical storied universe that the game takes place in. It's like someone added a physics engine to a children's book watercolor drawing. The story is told in the form of a poem, which is fun in spirit, but it's not always executed as well as I would have hoped. Otherwise, this is a very solid RPG game with great controller and co-op support.4/5

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
												In terms of story and gameplay, Child of Light is simplistic when compared to most RPGs. The story is nice, but it isn't very deep. Gameplay -- linear, not open -- is roundly functional and the controls are straightforward and highly intuitive even though the menu-driven inventory system may leave a little something to be desired. The battle system is challenging and paced well, but also a touch formulaic (I suppose that's part of the genre; I have never been an enthusiast of turn-based combat, so perhaps I'm not the one to ask about that).Here the focus was clearly on art, and it paid off. For the price, it is worth getting this game just to see it. The art style, reminiscent of the fairy tale illustrations of Ivan Bilbin, is astounding in imagination and execution. It is *the prettiest* game I have ever seen, as far as that goes.  The only major drawback, annoying enough for me almost not to recommend it to the community, is the godforsaken U-Play DRM from Ubisoft which you must be connected to in order to play. I haven't had any technical problems with it, but I hate invasive DRM of that nature, and this feature seems to be the focus of an awful lot of negative reviews. I do wish the character dialogue were on par with the game art; clearly it is not. The characters speak in rhyming verse, which adds to the storybook flavor of the game, but it is...well...just not very *good* verse. The dialogue isn't bad, so to speak, it just matches neither the tone nor the quality of the art. They hired serious artists to craft the visuals; if they wanted to use poetry, why wouldn't they hire serious poets? I'm sure lots of great poets out there could use the income. Overall, though, this is a highly enjoyable gaming experience on the lighter side of the RPG niche, and I'd gladly recommend it to anyone who likes this sort of game flavor. Kudos on the female protagonist, too.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												Child of Light is a fairy tale about Aurora, the princess of Austria (?). Falled into a fantasy world, she lives an adventure to save her family and her people, and she also discovers her own marvellous destiny. The visual design reminds of old child book illustrations; it is beautiful, although sometimes silly and mushy (...why girls' hair are always horizontal, moved by an omnipresent wind lol?) ...the story and the character design (thanks to the quests she takes, Aurora meets many original characters) are well conceived, also some unexpected plot twists are present. Rpg features are reduced to quests and characters modification via trees of abilities, but do not expect visible customization or complex character study: you may choose random evolutions and they will equally functions. The turn-based combat system with the action timeline is generally easy, but also smart and it requires a good amount of reasoning and resources management. A positive note about the music, that will remain in your mind. Another curios aspect of the game are the dialogues and narration... all of them are in rhymes. That's cute but... at least in the italian version, no metrics are provided by the authors; for this reason, some sentences just sound contrived and stupid. Such as... not fairy/inspiring characters, but childish idiots who force their own speaking to put rhymes in it at any cost. The idea is cool Ubisoft, but if this is the goal... next time, please hire an experienced poet!vote 7.5/10

												A beautiful story portrayed through vivid poetry and an art style that oddly attracts, Child of Light is a great game. I don't know what compelled me to buy this game in the first place - I rarely buy steam games, but I have not a single regret about this. The main quest is lovely, the sidequests give you information that would make you crave more, and the confessions are amazing. Cunning language and a band of misfits that join your adventure as Aurora make for comedic relief, strong emotions, and an interesting backstory deploy more and more often. I would recommend this for anyone who likes a single player game with a strong sense of emotions and writing.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												It's pretty relaxing to play.  Nice writing, great music, and fantastic artwork.  The fighting is pretty good too and isn't something I've seen exactly done before.  It's turn based, but also relies on speed and the specific action you use on your turn.  That also changes if your opponent jumps in front of you on this meter that shows when you can use an action.  In the fighting scenes though, it's fixed and free flow.  You can still control your little light buddy to slow enemies speed on your cast bar on the bottom and to pick up HP and MP replenishers. There are skill trees which are pretty familiar, except that you kind of start in the middle and branch off in three different directions.  It really is a great game and I think it should have done a little better on the metascore.
