												This game, it is beautiful. The art, the sound, the music! It makes one's heart skip a beat. Challenging, it may not be, but a story it weaves with music to help guide the way. The writing is mostly solid and is delivered in rhymes. Almost all of it, but when it's not, it's done for good reason.If you enjoy RPGs and good stories told, I urge you to pick up Child of Light. I found it best played with a controller and solid headphones. Don't rush it, explore the world and enjoy. The game's not too difficult and you could beat it round 12 hours (or less). I don't recommend the DLC as it's cheating, at best. The Golem's Plight pack is the only one I'd advise, and even then, think about it before you decide.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
												One of the most beautiful games I've seen since Okami on the Playstation 2.  The watercolor environments remind me of the classic artwork found in old fairytale books.  This is more of a casual feel RPG in that, there isn't a need to rush through anything.  Unlike many other RPGs out there where the hero uncovers a plot of world domination by a dastardly villain, Child of Light doesn't have that feeling of impending doom.  Even the music, beautifully orchestrated (and sometimes feel super epic), doesn't have that urgency to get from point A to point B.The highlight of this game, as many people will tell you, is the combat system.  It's almost a throwback to the active time battles as in Final Fantasy VII.  Where the combat commands seem overly simplistic in the beginning, it gets more complex as the hero levels up.  Timing is everything.  Literally.  In later stages of the game, if one isn't careful, enemies might force the player to constantly be on the defense, which will deplete the store of potions.The skill up menu also reminds me of the sphere grid a la Final Fantasy X, which was one of my favorite skill up ideas. All in all, Child of Light is a gorgeous game and definitely worth a playthrough.  I have to thank my friend for gifting this to me as a birthday present.

												7/10The artwork does not let up. Consistently beautiful throughout the game.Game gets grindy at some point, which is really bleh, but what can ya do about it? Child of Light is basically a JRPG with a unique "overworld" and a rich and charming environment. One, I should add, that really does require you to take full advantage of elemental strengths, resistances, and elemental boosting items. It's got a unique battle timer, which should keep you thinking about your next move.The story drags on, which was surprising for a game that really seemed to rely on it. But eh, was satisfying in the end anyway. Not a good sign when you're thinking to yourself, "Glad to be finally over that damn hump."

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
"Child - tuck yourself in bed.Let me tell a story of Lemuria,The kingdom past,And a girl born for glory."If you aren't instantly captivated by the truely beautiful watercolour artwork; the wonderful, peaceful background music; or the soft motherly voice that narrates cutscenes throughout the game in just the trailer - then the carefully crafted and moving storyline behind a young princesss, Aurora, as she tries to reclaim her kingdom of Lemuria and return home to save her people from a disastrous flood certainly will.Gameplay:Two dimensional platformer with stunning parallax graphics. Easy to move around at a decent rate, especially once you unlock the ability to fly (which is fairly early on). All text within this game is in some form of poem, usually a rhyme. This game involves a little problem solving, many secret areas  and a ton of fun. The game uses powerful stones called Oculi to provide aditional effects to a characters health, defense and offense which are customisable for all party members at any time except during battle and cutscenes. There are eleven different oculi with their own individual effect depending on where they are applied; nine of which have four tiers of power at varying levels. (Eren's Stone can only be accessed through the purchase of a DLC and the Princess Stone is the most powerful of all and can be crafted with a Brilliant (tier 4) Diamond, Onyx and Spinel.) There are about 52 individual crafting recipies (most are repetitive among different tiers of oculi). One can also acquire and use Stardusts for permanent effects to a character's statistics. Local co-op and controller support.Combat:Combat is turn-based... with a twist. It involves a timeline. Depending on the character's speed, they move down the timeline at different rates (this can be effected by spells, potions or Igniculus - her first companion, controlled by mouse if you are using a keyboard; also known as 'Sir Firefly'). Upon reaching the begining of the casting region near the end, a spell, potion, defense or attack can be chosen (or you can switch party members) with a length of either instant, short, medium, long or very long casting time; which is cast if the character reaches the end of the timeline without being interrupted. Although it is fairly easy to guess based on the colour of the enemy: it doesn't actually tell you what you are fighting nor what element it is. Fire(red) magic/creatures are weak to Water(blue); Water to Lightning(green); Lightning to Fire; and Dark(Varies - usually black, occasionally white) to Light. Fairly easy to level up the same old classic RPG style with several different skill trees for each party member all leading to different  or more powerful abilities.Storyline:Although the storyline is good, it's not particulary in-depth. There are many mysterious clues that are seemingly never properly explained. It's a very straight storyline, with no user input and nothing to do after the game is completed. There are several sidequests, most very short and easy to do that lead to extra treasure. To be entirely honest though; although I like the freedom of choice, this game has been made with such precision and care that I don't even mind.I would definitely recommend this game. It has become one of my all-time-favourites. Sadly, I have finished it now however I enjoyed it so much that I will likely return to play it again several times over in the following years. Personally, the biggest disappointment for me is that there are no Steam cards, badges, achievements, emoticons or really awesome artwork that I can use as my Steam profile background (the latter being my biggest grievance)."Beware the night, Child of Light."

content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												Gamplay: Standard RPG combat with an addition of an interrupt and slow system that is easy to use but would take some time to master. Outside of combat is standard 2D rpg format that works well with the flight mechanics. Animations, espcially Aurora's, are very nice and well done. Each characters has there own skill tree that has some customization, but not very complicated.Controls:I used a keyboard & Mouse.  Controls were simple and easy to use. In battle they are simplified to an active battle system which is easy to navigate. Outside of combat is a very simplistic platformer that does not require much precision. To Control your firefly you use your mouse, this is designed for a mouse, it works very well. With all that said, I believe the standard controls would also work very well with a control & the firefly mechanic would work well with the second joystick on all controllers. Overall- Very Good. Sound:  Beautiful music that fits the mood all the time, and sound effects fit extremly well with all the Spell effects Graphics:Atmospheres are beautifully designed, some of them are downright stunning, from dark & scary forests to Lava filled Trees to underwater caves from beginning to end. Not hard to see what ubisoft focused on while creating this game.Wothey Notes: The writing is pretty atrocious, the rhymes seemed very forced and weren't thought to hard about, character deveolpment is lack luster as well but you get the basic points . Only really complaint about this 12 hour RPG. Well worth the money, 8.0 out of 10.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												Child Of Light is a beautiful game. Visuals:The art is in watercolours which is very calming to look at and this game is not demanding so I could play this on my laptop if I wanted to, Gameplay:The Gameplay requires thinking. I found the difficultly to be good. You can get multiple party members which you can switch out in combat. All enemies have a weakness to an element (light, lightening, fire, etc). There is a timeline at the bottom of the screen which determines whos turn it is, you can slow enemies down or even paralyze them from reaching their turn and they can do the same to you. Story: The story is quite simple and is told in rhymes. Not everyone will like this. I personally liked it, it made me feel like I was listening to a bedtime story or a fairy tale. Don't expect a deep story or a heavy impact and don't expect any deep character development. Like I said the story is simple. Audio:Simply lovely, especially when Aurora plays her flute. The music and the visual style is very calming in this game. I would certainly recommend  this game to any RPG and Turn-based fan or people that like fairy tales.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												I don't think there are words that can describe how I feel about this game. I have not made it very far into the game but they do so much to draw you in. The visuals and art design are breathtaking and mesmerizing. Ubi Art did an amazing job with this game  of pulling you in to the dark, mysterious yet beautiful landscape and environment. The music and sound design sends chills up and down my body. From the sound of Aurora's sword hitting an enemy to hearing a giant walk in the distance, you will always find something to be amazed at. The gameplay is very solid as well. Child of Light does a great job of combining RPG elements with little changes that make it both easy-to-understand yet challenging when it needs to be. I am playing on Hard and even simple skirmishes have me thinking about my next move. All in all, the real grab about this game is that it is only $15 at the time of this writing and it was DEFINITELY worth the money. RPG fans will not be disappointed and Adventure fans will find a new and enchanting world to explore with Aurora. I hope to see more amazing products like Child of Light in the future from Ubisoft. If I run into anything as I play more of the game that makes me change my review, I will update this accordingly.

												It's an amazing game. The overall flow is really great, the difficulty is perfect and the whole progression of the game feels really nice. I absolutely LOVE the soundtrack by Coeur de Pirate, it's definitely different from what she usually writes, but it still has the RPG feel in it. The graphics are really beautiful and breath-taking.The game only got one problem, though.And it's Uplay. You probably all saw that coming.Yet I love Ubisoft and I like their games since I'm a little kid, but come on. Ubisoft. Uplay again, really? I know you guys want your own DRM thing, but I just can't get over the fact that NOBODY likes Uplay! I even have some friends who pirated the game instead of buying it JUST BECAUSE OF UPLAY! And I understand them. It's really annoying when I have to have to wait 10 minutes everytime I want to play, just because of Uplay loading and saying:"Getting Proxy..."I just want to play the damn game.Anyhoo, great game. Would recommend to everybody who's looking for a good RPG.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												I absolutely recommend this game. I didn't know I needed a rhyming RPG, but now I do. This is a well-crafted, beautifully illustrated storybook wrapped in the guise of a game.Pro:Gorgeous presentation - like interacting with a paintingEngaging battle system - easy to grasp, but provides some challenge on harder levelsRhyming - brilliantly adds charm / whimsy and enhances the visual presentationCon:"Normal" is too easy. I played briefly on normal before restarting on "hard". I suggest doing this unless you're really after a casual experience.Sometimes the rhyming is a stretch. Personally, even when the rhymes stretched, they made me smile. This is not a big con for me.Meh:The crafting system did not impress me, nor did I hate it. I mostly used the gems to speed up my own characters or give elemental damage.Overall, a lovely game. Some people said it was short. That may be. I didn't rush through everything, and it lasted me around 18 hours. That's a pretty good deal for $15. The only better deals I've had are for giant open-world RPGs like Skyrim or 4x games like Civ (I, II, III, IV, V, yes, I've played them all except Call to Power and Alpha Centauri).

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												Just to say that I had never heard of this game until i saw it on steam and it pulled me in with the artwork alone. It's like an interactive pop-out story book. With all the characters, environments, and creatures as a normal rpg. but i started playing is where it really got good. 1) The characters talk like in ryhme, as if they are write a poem, and i don't know about you, but i love me some poetry. 2) The story is magnificent, its a well thought out and beautifully written masterpiece that pulls you in like a story you would be read to you by a parent as you fall asleep as a child, yet it is dark and intruiging like a story you would read and fall in love with now-a-days. 3) The characters are all dynamic and have their own strengths and faults laid out on the table for you to see. There aren't any characters that are "cookie cut" in my opinion, you connect and feel with all the characters (even some NPC's) even if you dont fight with all of them. and 4) The battle system is amazing! It's a timebar-type battle system THAT YOU CAN MANIPULATE. You use your mouse to slow down enemies or slowly heal allies, and to me adds a whole new level to the word "STRATEGY". The only cons i can see about this game is, 1) having to connect with uplay through steam is weird and a little inconvenient, but doesn't really bother after the inital set-up. and 2) although i do love the battle system, after awhile of fighting the same mobs over and over, it does get kind of tedious. But I mean all you have to do is skip monsters after awhile so it's easily avoidable.9.5/10 a great game for people of all ages

Posted: May 29, 2014
												7/10The artwork does not let up. Consistently beautiful throughout the game.Game gets grindy at some point, which is really bleh, but what can ya do about it? Child of Light is basically a JRPG with a unique "overworld" and a rich and charming environment. One, I should add, that really does require you to take full advantage of elemental strengths, resistances, and elemental boosting items. It's got a unique battle timer, which should keep you thinking about your next move.The story drags on, which was surprising for a game that really seemed to rely on it. But eh, was satisfying in the end anyway. Not a good sign when you're thinking to yourself, "Glad to be finally over that damn hump."

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
"Child - tuck yourself in bed.Let me tell a story of Lemuria,The kingdom past,And a girl born for glory."If you aren't instantly captivated by the truely beautiful watercolour artwork; the wonderful, peaceful background music; or the soft motherly voice that narrates cutscenes throughout the game in just the trailer - then the carefully crafted and moving storyline behind a young princesss, Aurora, as she tries to reclaim her kingdom of Lemuria and return home to save her people from a disastrous flood certainly will.Gameplay:Two dimensional platformer with stunning parallax graphics. Easy to move around at a decent rate, especially once you unlock the ability to fly (which is fairly early on). All text within this game is in some form of poem, usually a rhyme. This game involves a little problem solving, many secret areas  and a ton of fun. The game uses powerful stones called Oculi to provide aditional effects to a characters health, defense and offense which are customisable for all party members at any time except during battle and cutscenes. There are eleven different oculi with their own individual effect depending on where they are applied; nine of which have four tiers of power at varying levels. (Eren's Stone can only be accessed through the purchase of a DLC and the Princess Stone is the most powerful of all and can be crafted with a Brilliant (tier 4) Diamond, Onyx and Spinel.) There are about 52 individual crafting recipies (most are repetitive among different tiers of oculi). One can also acquire and use Stardusts for permanent effects to a character's statistics. Local co-op and controller support.Combat:Combat is turn-based... with a twist. It involves a timeline. Depending on the character's speed, they move down the timeline at different rates (this can be effected by spells, potions or Igniculus - her first companion, controlled by mouse if you are using a keyboard; also known as 'Sir Firefly'). Upon reaching the begining of the casting region near the end, a spell, potion, defense or attack can be chosen (or you can switch party members) with a length of either instant, short, medium, long or very long casting time; which is cast if the character reaches the end of the timeline without being interrupted. Although it is fairly easy to guess based on the colour of the enemy: it doesn't actually tell you what you are fighting nor what element it is. Fire(red) magic/creatures are weak to Water(blue); Water to Lightning(green); Lightning to Fire; and Dark(Varies - usually black, occasionally white) to Light. Fairly easy to level up the same old classic RPG style with several different skill trees for each party member all leading to different  or more powerful abilities.Storyline:Although the storyline is good, it's not particulary in-depth. There are many mysterious clues that are seemingly never properly explained. It's a very straight storyline, with no user input and nothing to do after the game is completed. There are several sidequests, most very short and easy to do that lead to extra treasure. To be entirely honest though; although I like the freedom of choice, this game has been made with such precision and care that I don't even mind.I would definitely recommend this game. It has become one of my all-time-favourites. Sadly, I have finished it now however I enjoyed it so much that I will likely return to play it again several times over in the following years. Personally, the biggest disappointment for me is that there are no Steam cards, badges, achievements, emoticons or really awesome artwork that I can use as my Steam profile background (the latter being my biggest grievance)."Beware the night, Child of Light."

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												First of all this is my first review and english is not my native language so sorry for either gramatical errors or typos and maybe bad format .TL;DR versionGraphics 10/10       Stunning . Even if they arent to your taste you cant deny how beautifull they areSound 8/10             Nice . it folows the game nothing extraordinary nothing annoyingMusic 10/10            Stunning . Just hear it Story 9/10               Nice . Simple fairy tale but that is the beauty of itCharacters 9/10      Nice . Every NPC has flaws , motivation and they are different persons with no stereotypesCombat 7/10           Good but can be boring fast Replayability 2/10  Unless you enjoy the game so much ,if you play it once and do all the quests or gather all confessions                                       .                                there is little reason to play it againOverall 9/10             A piece of art .Long version I saw this game when it first came out , and i said oh well lets fly the jolly roger. Then after i finished it , i just went and bought it . My experience was so good and felt those weird thingies called emotions that actually i shed a tear (meaning i had to literally wipe my eyes.. those onion-cutting ninjas). The selling points of this game are the atmosphere and the plot. But i will explain all of it belowChild of Light is tagged as a RPG , but offers you no choices in the plot element. But (and it is a big but) offers character customization (talents and occuli) and the most important thing character development . For me RPGs should be like that. You see as the time passes that Aurora and her companions grow up emotionally and stand up to the task . AtmosphereThe thing that made me play this game was the atmosphere . Graphics , dialogues , music are all so immersive that after 12 hours of playing i realized it was morning and i should tuck myself in bed and let the game and complete it later. Graphics arent realistic . Instead they follow a fantasy and are dreamlike , but that doesnt stop them for being stunning and once in a while you stop to enjoy the view . Music is a nice background which not only doesnt bother you but you like to hear it .. i cant find the words how well the soundtrack accompanies the game.Dialogues are in verse , meaning they are poems. They are fun , yet you understand the characters and their motivations and you want to help em .  I always like the dialogeus and read them through but at times speaking in verse can be overwhelming .Before  saying anything about the story i must say that this is a game which a child of 8 years can play . There is no blood , no cursing , a little jump scaring (you can always scout with the firefly) , and a simple plot(thougt simple doesnt mean not beautiful)Story . You are a princess of Austria and somehow you wake up in the middle of a dark scary forest away from your papa . Also you mist find the moon and the stars and defeat the evil queen umbra. How the hell a little child will do this ? . Of course with the help of the forest lady , Indignicus , and your companions ! each one has his/her own story and motivation and flaws . As the game goes on Aurora will grow up (changing her model) and finally will be an adult. Aurora is not either a warrior or a wizard... she is just a princess ... how you play is up to you. And that is another thing i love about this game.Playstyle Combat Well things are simple... you see the timebar , you see when everyone is going to take action and how fast they are gonna do it. Every character ( Aurora included) has strenghs and weaknesses , same goes for enemies. You can change chars by swapping them in battle. You dont get punished for changing a character . After a while you can indentify the enemies and know what to do . What should be mentioned is that you can avoid all battles except bosses . Also you can run from them.  Exploring Go see the screenshots . you fly up and high and the wind brushes your hair and you are free. You are almost always airbound (at least i did it) , and everything is within reach either by you or the shiny blue ball. Overall if you like fairy tales this game is just for you . Even if you dont, i think you can find a place in your heart for Lemuria and Aurora . This game is a piece or art in which you can actually play . the only bad thing i find is that the game is short and has little to no replay value .

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												At first glance, Child of Light looks like a children's nursry story with 2d platforming elements. However if you dig down a little bit further you find a story with a very dark tone to it, and a very rich battle system that will keep you engaged for hours. In fact, the battle system is the best part of the game.I recorded on a video reviewing the games battle system in-depth: 


Child of Light Battle System Review 
A Video of 
By: OpenWorldAddict

			In this video I go over the Child of Light battle system and what I like about it. This video is meant to go along side with my Child of Light review on Steam.		


It is very reminiscent of the battle system from the Grandia games. That battle system was my favorite of all jrpg's from the playstation 2 era. This game takes a unique twist on that system, and adds complexity through Oculi system.The story itself is interesting, but the constant rhyming can get it a little boring. There isn't much for character customization other than choosing which branch of the different skill trees your characters go down.Strategy Tip: Pick one branch of the skill tree for each character until you unlock all the major skills on that branch.Oh and don't think you'll find your normal inns and shops in the locals you encournter along the way. There is none. All the items that you will get will either be from chests or enemy drops.Nonetheless, it is the battle system that uplifts this game to a much higher rating than there would be without it.Graphics: Good 7.0Music: Mediocre 6.0Story (plot): Good 7.5Story (writing): Mediocre 6.0Gameplay (customization) Good 7.0Gameplay (Battle) Superb 9.0Overall: Great 8.0So if you are a fan of Japanese Roleplaying games, and want to try a new game with a interesting story and a wonderful, captivating and engaging battle system, I absolutely recommend that you get this game.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												This game is probably the closest thing an "indie" game can get to perfection. The music is a masterpiece, the gameplay is refreshing, the characters are interesting, the story is well written, the art is fantastic, and the difficulty curve perfectly keeps the game challenging but fair once you get used to the game mechanics. If a game ever truly deserves a 10/10 score, this would probably be it.Of course, this isn't truely an indie game, as Ubisoft is the one releasing it. In fact, every single negative of the game I can think of (with the exception of the game being somewhat short for an RPG with little replay value) is related to this. The equipment cash-grab DLC (seriously - don't buy those), Uplay, the terrible achievement system, and an unnecessary two-player oriented mechanic are all things that drag down the game. All in all though, if you can live with Uplay and like RPGs, this game is a must play.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												I’m going to start this review with something that sounds like a slam, though it isn't: I really wanted to love Child of Light. But I didn’t. The reason that I wanted to love it is that from the very first trailer I saw I was enchanted with the graphical styles of the game. This enchantment lasted well into my first playthrough; well past the point where I tired of some game elements I was still excited just to look at each new part of the world Child of Light laid out for me. Every bit of scenery and every sprite looks hand crafted. Winsome characters and sumptuous backgrounds have the look of ink and watercolor art from some gorgeous, moody storybook. Woods give way to craggy rocks give way to villages revealing one stunning tableau after another. Broken statues stare poignantly. Light shines through stained glass and down from treetops. Giants are visible in the hazy distance… There is beauty, often mixed with melancholy, everywhere—even the fights are suffused with it. The animation of Aurora, the protagonist, is also arresting. The attention paid to the movement of her long hair alone is worthy of mention, as are the animations of her wielding a sword clearly too heavy for her tiny body. All this is true, but my reaction to the game as a whole is more measured. As mentioned, you play as Aurora, an Austrian princess snatched into a fantasy land where she must lead a struggle against the Queen of Dark whose aim is to steal all natural light in the kingdom. You must recruit allies to your party and complete quests to defeat the Queen. Gameply is a mix of metroidvania, side-scroller environments with puzzles, and quasi-turn-based RPG battles. The integration of these two is interesting: encounters are not random. Monsters are visible in the over-world, and how you interact with them there determines who has the initiative at the beginning of a fight. Another interesting mechanic is that your cursor is a character, a glowing sprite, which moves independently of Aurora and interacts with the environment aiding her progress. Mousing over objects is often counted as the sprite interacting with them, so to some degree you are controlling two characters at once. In general, the over world elements of play are quite easy, though.Battles involve two party members squaring off against a squad of monsters. The action is driven by a timeline, with each character receiving actions at intervals. This differs from a turn-based system in that the intervals vary significantly between combatants, and can be further manipulated by player actions. Character progression, via a branching maze of unlockable nodes ala FF X, unlock new combat abilities. This simple mechanic generates a variety of interesting fights, though by the end of the game I felt the battles were becoming somewhat monotonous, as often happens with turn-based battle mechanics in simple games.The game is linier and story-driven. It is here that I had my major complaints. The game creators aimed for a moving coming of age story. (If you have seen it, the Neil Gaiman movie Mirrormask seems to be very much the sort of thing they were aiming for.) But this falls short in a number of ways. One reason is that story scenes are done in a kind of storybook mode with largely static images of the characters acompanied by text. Compared to the rest of the game these sequences are oddly uncharismatic. But a much more major shortcoming is the dialogue itself. The game sets all dialogue in verse. But it seems the writers did not have the skill to make this device actually work for them resulting in bad rhymes and perpetually stilted wording. This verbal lack of poise is oddly at odds with the stunning visual beauty of the game. Perhaps these factors alone are enough to explain my mixed feelings towards the story.In the final count Child of light still offers a wondrous world to explore and marvel at, it still casts a spell. It just didn’t quite live up to its potential. I was left feeling that if every aspect of the game showed the beauty and polish that the graphics do then Child of Light would be one of the greats. The gorgeous, well-built, casual RPG Child of Light actually is makes me badly wish I could play that game.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												Bought this game in a bundle of 3 games for $13.50 in total so I'll assume $4.50 was spent on this game.I enjoyed almost everything about this game. It is a platformer/puzzle/turn-based RPG game in which all three would fall in the "casual" category. The music, art, gameplay was all very good. Nothing about this game was complicated and the battle system was not intricate.Your gear was combining/upgrading gems that give different abilities or effects and it can be unequipped or changed without penalty. A lot of party members, to choose from but you can only use 2 at a time. You can switch them mid battle without penalty or losing a turn incase one is about to get knocked out. Each character has their own pro/cons. Other than that, it is a stright forward turned based battle system with a bar that lets you know who might be going next (stronger abilites take longer time to get ready).Some things in the story was never explained (i.e. *Spoiler Alert* *Spoiler Alert* the flooding I assumed was caused by the main villain, but it never stopped even after her defeat).The "confessions" which are hidden notes you find that pieces together a story was never explained. I have no idea who those people are that is mentioned in the confessions or what significane they play in the game at all. (None i guess since I beat the game and still don't know who they were.)The ending of the game seemed very rushed and a little online research suggests content was removed before release. *Spoiler Alert**Spoiler Alert* After I got my♥♥♥♥♥whooped and was revived and powered up I was excited to go through another dungeon etc etc fight the villain etc, but nothing.♥♥♥♥♥whooped - power up cut-scene and final boss. The end.I did enjoy the overall game though despite that end.--------------tl;drI estimated i spent $4.50 for this game.Light-hearted platformer, puzzle and rpg game with some exploring.Great visuals, music, story (for the most part).Straight forward turn based combat system.Lots of party members but only 2 can be active at a time.A few things never explained and show no connection with the game story.Rating 7.5/10 (+2 Story, +1Music, +2 Price, +1 Visuals, +1 Smooth Controlling, +2 Overall good game, -0.5 noticeably rushed final battle, -1 no connection with notes of "confessions" and the game I was playing besides finding them because they are hidden, and some elements never explained)

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												After playing through the entire game and doing most of the side content, I'm still torn. I can't recommend it in good conscience however.Gameplay: The combat feels like a classic JRPG but with some real-time elements that allow you to control a secondary character (or let someone else use the mouse to do so). This guy can collect healing objects for you, or even slow down your enemies on the timeline which is incredibly useful and adds a new dynamic to trying to interrupt your enemies. Overall I enjoyed the classic combat. My one major gripe is that you only ever can have 2 of your party members out at a time, which seems absurd to me. Especially since your enemies routinely have 3.Art: You can't say enough about the art style. It's got a brilliant storybook feel that is woven throughout the story as well. The color palette and style is bold and refreshing. Animation leaves a lot to be desired however, as they all look more like paper cutouts hanging from strings.Story/Writing: This is what ruins the game for me. The story is hopelessly childish and unoriginal, which leaves me wondering what the target audience is. I do realize that this matches the visual style, but there must be ways to achieve a story that is appealing to adults while maintaining the whimsical visuals. Things like Trine 2 or Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons did this wonderfully. Overall the story was sickeningly saccharine. In contrast, Brothers started out extremely fanciful, but quick got dark and serious in it's themes. They're both coming-of-age tales, but Brothers pulled it off in a much more brilliant and emotional way (and without words, yet!). In Child of Light, you'll never care about any of the characters. Speaking of words, I must say a few about the poetry. I feel as if the poetry could have saved the hokey story. However, the poetry was dreadful. The writers made no attempt to compose with any meter or rhythm, but instead stuck stubbornly to their A-B-A-B rhyme scheme regardless of the cadence of the sentences. Shakespeare is rolling in his grave. I love great poetry when it has a solid rhythm and bounce to it (See Penny Arcade's Twisp and Catsby stuff!), but this sounded more like a junior high student writing poetry for the first time. Even the rhymes were a stretch from time to time, and left you gagging or saying "oh come on, really?!".In conclusion, I give this a "NO" with a very heavy heart. I wanted to like it so bad. There were parts of it I really enjoyed. But I found myself rushing from battle to battle in order to enjoy the combat, while the story left me wanting. I don't mind a good kid's story. But this wasn't just a kid's story, it was downright childish and lame. If you think the beautiful art and great combat can redeem an ignorable story, then maybe give this a try. But for me, it wasn't worth the 10 hours.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												Hnnnnnng this GAME!Everything about this game from the art design to the music to the rhyming dialogue is just so gosh darn charming. The battle system utilizes a "time bar" that determines when your characters and your enemies act. As each unit's turn bubble moves from left to right on the time bar, there are two thresholds that they pass through: first, one where they determine what action they are about to take, and second, one where they take said action. If a unit is attacked while in between these two thresholds their turn is delayed, making for some pretty strategic and challenging battles.(Keep in mind I haven't beaten the game yet so the majority of the plot is still unknown to me) The story is about a little girl lost in a dream world and trying to find a way back home, but there seems to be an underlying story to it all that isn't told to us right away...! As your adventure unfolds you encounter several different party members to help you in battle, each one adding a different strategy and play style. These partners all have very distinct personalities and interact with each other outside of battle from time to time in fairly humorous exchanges. I have yet to find a character I DIDN'T like.The environments are beautiful and so far for me have ranged from a lush forest to dark and dangerous looking mines to heated lava caverns. The map could be described as "linear" but honestly there are tons of hidden treasures and even some optional mini bosses that you could easily miss if you didn't look hard enough. Overall I feel the environments are very well put together and at no point have they bored me.This game has scratched pretty much every itch that I have as a RPG lover: engaging battle system that makes me WANT to fight the next enemy, a beautifully told story that has just enough mystery to make me keep pushing forward, as well as a very likable and distinguished cast of characters. I could not recommend this game to other RPG lovers enough.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												This is one of the most fantastic RPG games I've ever played, and will appeal to both RPG and fans of the JRPG subgenre. With beautiful art work, character development, an immersive story, and humour, people will find themselves lost in this game, and coming to love the main character, perhaps without even realizing it.In addition to the art work, the battle system is active and rewarding. The game augments the traditonal turn based combat system of the turn based RPG, by creating the 'action bar', which is a time based system that shows how close a character is to being able to act, and the time it will take to complete an action. With the help of Igniculus, a character you meet right at the start of the game, you are able to influence the time it will take enemies to act, and if you're clever, you can interrupt an opponent in the middle of an action, potentially eliminating their ability to do anything throughout a battle. Beware though, because the same weakness applies to you!So with the fantastic and beautiful story, and simplistic but innovative battle system, the reasons to love this game are many, and even if it's something totally new to a would be buyer, it's something I recommend to everyone.*** I see a lot of concern over 'Uplay'. This is my only game I use through Uplay (and steam), and I can attest that Uplay isn't hard to use at all. You just start this game via steam, and it'll open through Uplay, it's not annoying at all (though I would add that you want Uplay to remember your log in information if you want to skip the several seconds it takes to log in!).

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												My wife and I selected this game,because it offered a co-op campaign.we loved the art, right from the start,'til the last monster was slain-------------------------------------------------------------I'm reviewing this from the perspective of someone who played as the secondary character while my wife controlled the main player through our 15 hour campaign. Right away I want to applaud the game developers for creating an interesting co-op mechanic. The main player in solo play could just control the secondary role themselves (in fact they still can while another person is plugged in), if you are able to multitask and be effective it pays off to control the sprite character during hard battles. Giving the second player the role of this sprite splits the responsibility so that you don't have to consider as many options during fights, but you will still want to coordinate with the other player to perfect your timing.It's obvious that this game is uniquely beautiful. Ubisoft came up with a graphics engine that does a great job representing the mythical storied universe that the game takes place in. It's like someone added a physics engine to a children's book watercolor drawing. The story is told in the form of a poem, which is fun in spirit, but it's not always executed as well as I would have hoped. Otherwise, this is a very solid RPG game with great controller and co-op support.4/5

content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
												I found this to be a solid and charming RPG.  Dont let the ubisoft brand fool you.  I played for a bit over 18 hrs and enjoyed this game quite a bit.The gameplay is, if anything, a bit too easy in the same way that Kingdom Hearts is.  If you are modestly competent almost every fight wont be challenging even at the harder difficulty setting, but it's still enjoyable to play.  Combat is similar to an ATB system with actions being queued up on a time bar before being performed.  Some actions can be interrupted, others affect a characters turn in some way, allowing for some finesse and control on the part of the player.  This comes along with an ATB-independent heal the player can perform with his mouse cursor that uses its own slowly recharging resource, and for some reason I found the balance between the two fairly enjoyable and engaging.  In the more tense fights, healing characters at the right moments was crucial along with timing when you would be able to heal again after expending all of your resource was fairly important.  Characters are diverse and can fit varied roles in combat, enough that I didnt feel like I should stick to just a few that I might like.  Outside of combat puzzles are fairly easy and nothing too complex or ingenious comes up, and there is some light exploration and backtracking for rewards you can do as well.  Exploration does kind of fall flat a little because they give you complete exploration powers very shortly into the game, but its also not a metroidvania title so calling it a 'missed opportunity' or like doesn't quite fit.  Jamming RPG, light crafting mechanics, skill trees, exploration, etc all into a game is a lot and eventually you'd end up with feature bloat.The story has a kind of light fairytail whimsy to it, in the way that some aspects are obscured or ambiguous or mean to be accepted prima facie.  It works out for the most part, and the way they presented the world and characters was satisfying.  and had some nice twists too. Some people dont like the rhyming dialogue, but I did.  I liked most all of the characters too, even a few I expected not to on first glance like Rubella.  I think if anything one of the problems they had was the sin of taking away a character from the player whom one might have expended permanent stat upgrade consumables on, and also in introducing one character too late and letting a few others kind of flounder a bit.  Still, the ones that did get time in the story were nice.I'd highly recommend it, it's not a top 5 title but it definitely went into my favorites.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine Child of Light is a beautiful RPG game developed and published by Ubisoft. From start to finish it shows a solid gameplay, a vibrant world, and a quite interesting story with more than a few twists.Sound design is amazing, and graphically speaking, the game looks magnificent, and everytime you reach a new place, you find yourself looking at every place of the screen, mindblowing designs and drawings that are taken out of a fairy tale, beautiful. The magic of the game is greatly resembled too, and it's one of the strongest points in the game.The amount of hours might look short for an RPG, but it's not really short clocking in at around 10-11 hours in total. The game doesn't drag on, some battles are indeed hard but can be overtaken by strategy, the story from start to finish feels good, like reading a book. It's all fun from start to finish, and at the end you feel realized and full because it doesn't leave you wanting for more like some other gamesThe gameplay is a turn-based fighting RPG, which is fast, there's no long animations and it's really fun thanks to constantly being in motion, you will be using characters in the fight that you can swap at any time, there are quite a few characters. They of course level up, and you'll have to see what's the best course of action regarding their skills. I want to mention that it's very fun to move as the protagonist too, specially with the amount of secrets that are everywhere! Nothing falls short in the gameplay portion of the game!I love the fact that the story is told in rhyme which adds a lovely touch to the game. Overall, Child of Light is a game that offers a great time guaranteed for RPG players, you can't really go wrong with this game. Shame about the forced DRM of Uplay but it's Ubisoft, what do you expect? RECOMMENDED :)  Also, best to play with a controller

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												I’m going to start this review with something that sounds like a slam, though it isn't: I really wanted to love Child of Light. But I didn’t. The reason that I wanted to love it is that from the very first trailer I saw I was enchanted with the graphical styles of the game. This enchantment lasted well into my first playthrough; well past the point where I tired of some game elements I was still excited just to look at each new part of the world Child of Light laid out for me. Every bit of scenery and every sprite looks hand crafted. Winsome characters and sumptuous backgrounds have the look of ink and watercolor art from some gorgeous, moody storybook. Woods give way to craggy rocks give way to villages revealing one stunning tableau after another. Broken statues stare poignantly. Light shines through stained glass and down from treetops. Giants are visible in the hazy distance… There is beauty, often mixed with melancholy, everywhere—even the fights are suffused with it. The animation of Aurora, the protagonist, is also arresting. The attention paid to the movement of her long hair alone is worthy of mention, as are the animations of her wielding a sword clearly too heavy for her tiny body. All this is true, but my reaction to the game as a whole is more measured. As mentioned, you play as Aurora, an Austrian princess snatched into a fantasy land where she must lead a struggle against the Queen of Dark whose aim is to steal all natural light in the kingdom. You must recruit allies to your party and complete quests to defeat the Queen. Gameply is a mix of metroidvania, side-scroller environments with puzzles, and quasi-turn-based RPG battles. The integration of these two is interesting: encounters are not random. Monsters are visible in the over-world, and how you interact with them there determines who has the initiative at the beginning of a fight. Another interesting mechanic is that your cursor is a character, a glowing sprite, which moves independently of Aurora and interacts with the environment aiding her progress. Mousing over objects is often counted as the sprite interacting with them, so to some degree you are controlling two characters at once. In general, the over world elements of play are quite easy, though.Battles involve two party members squaring off against a squad of monsters. The action is driven by a timeline, with each character receiving actions at intervals. This differs from a turn-based system in that the intervals vary significantly between combatants, and can be further manipulated by player actions. Character progression, via a branching maze of unlockable nodes ala FF X, unlock new combat abilities. This simple mechanic generates a variety of interesting fights, though by the end of the game I felt the battles were becoming somewhat monotonous, as often happens with turn-based battle mechanics in simple games.The game is linier and story-driven. It is here that I had my major complaints. The game creators aimed for a moving coming of age story. (If you have seen it, the Neil Gaiman movie Mirrormask seems to be very much the sort of thing they were aiming for.) But this falls short in a number of ways. One reason is that story scenes are done in a kind of storybook mode with largely static images of the characters acompanied by text. Compared to the rest of the game these sequences are oddly uncharismatic. But a much more major shortcoming is the dialogue itself. The game sets all dialogue in verse. But it seems the writers did not have the skill to make this device actually work for them resulting in bad rhymes and perpetually stilted wording. This verbal lack of poise is oddly at odds with the stunning visual beauty of the game. Perhaps these factors alone are enough to explain my mixed feelings towards the story.In the final count Child of light still offers a wondrous world to explore and marvel at, it still casts a spell. It just didn’t quite live up to its potential. I was left feeling that if every aspect of the game showed the beauty and polish that the graphics do then Child of Light would be one of the greats. The gorgeous, well-built, casual RPG Child of Light actually is makes me badly wish I could play that game.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												Bought this game in a bundle of 3 games for $13.50 in total so I'll assume $4.50 was spent on this game.I enjoyed almost everything about this game. It is a platformer/puzzle/turn-based RPG game in which all three would fall in the "casual" category. The music, art, gameplay was all very good. Nothing about this game was complicated and the battle system was not intricate.Your gear was combining/upgrading gems that give different abilities or effects and it can be unequipped or changed without penalty. A lot of party members, to choose from but you can only use 2 at a time. You can switch them mid battle without penalty or losing a turn incase one is about to get knocked out. Each character has their own pro/cons. Other than that, it is a stright forward turned based battle system with a bar that lets you know who might be going next (stronger abilites take longer time to get ready).Some things in the story was never explained (i.e. *Spoiler Alert* *Spoiler Alert* the flooding I assumed was caused by the main villain, but it never stopped even after her defeat).The "confessions" which are hidden notes you find that pieces together a story was never explained. I have no idea who those people are that is mentioned in the confessions or what significane they play in the game at all. (None i guess since I beat the game and still don't know who they were.)The ending of the game seemed very rushed and a little online research suggests content was removed before release. *Spoiler Alert**Spoiler Alert* After I got my♥♥♥♥♥whooped and was revived and powered up I was excited to go through another dungeon etc etc fight the villain etc, but nothing.♥♥♥♥♥whooped - power up cut-scene and final boss. The end.I did enjoy the overall game though despite that end.--------------tl;drI estimated i spent $4.50 for this game.Light-hearted platformer, puzzle and rpg game with some exploring.Great visuals, music, story (for the most part).Straight forward turn based combat system.Lots of party members but only 2 can be active at a time.A few things never explained and show no connection with the game story.Rating 7.5/10 (+2 Story, +1Music, +2 Price, +1 Visuals, +1 Smooth Controlling, +2 Overall good game, -0.5 noticeably rushed final battle, -1 no connection with notes of "confessions" and the game I was playing besides finding them because they are hidden, and some elements never explained)

												Thanks goodness, I chose to play Child of Light after my embarrassing gameplay of L4D2. I knew this was my cup of tea because I always love role-playing games (RPG). I'm a huge fan of beautiful artwork and captivating storytelling. Child of Light brings me back to the time of exploration and the freedom of feeling like a child again, even though it's in a game. However I love that this is a good introduction to players who are first time to RPG and those like me who want to enjoy the ambience of the world rather than being stressed out by upgrading your characters.I also like it that the story is kept at a good pace. and boss fights are manageable with a degree of challenge.Games are created for entertainment and Child of Light has swept off my feet long enough to finish the whole game. It has done very well. As for those still on the fence about Child of Light because of UPlay, please give it a try with the demo version. UPlay might not suck as much as you'd think it is.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												I finished this game and that's really saying something.  I usually lose interest eventually and don't finish.  This one has that perfect balance to where it kept me entertained and interested enough to continue playing, but didn't make me dedicate too much as far as time and patience.  I recommend it for gamers like myself who prefer less depth on occasion for the sake of being able to jump in and play it for an hour or two after work.  Here are a few pros and cons because I'm not much of a composer.+Beautiful artwork+Fast paced yet turn based combat that's entertaining enough to make you want more+Lots of secret loot to find+Crafting is very simple but effective+Character progression is well-balanced+Diverse characters with lots of different skills+Ease of travel+Shallow story for shallow folks+Short and sweet+Reasonably priced, especially at the 60% off discount-Poetic dialogue is pretty cheesy, but I get it-Potions are a bit useless unless you're in a dire situation-Could have used a little more difficulty in combat, just a littleI give it an 8/10, if they ever make a second one, I will insta-buy.P.S.  I should also say that Uplay is not a big deal in any shape or form.  I see a lot of people freaking out over it, but they're just being dramatic pansies.  In the 24 hours it took me to beat this, I saw the Uplay screen a total of about 60 seconds. It never once interfered with anything at all.  Also, if it prevents piracy, I'm all for it.  Get a job and buy your games, people work hard on them.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												TL;DR: Pleasantly surprising RPG reminiscent of JRPGs like Final Fantasy with good artwork, music, and a fun combat systemAlright,So I don't know exactly what prompted me to buy this game other than the nice artstyle that was presented. Day of release and a couple hours in I actually found myself recommending it to my friends.Artstyle-wise: I absolutely loved it. Throughout the entire game I found myself just paused at some of the scenes wondering if I should be taking a screenshot. Dialogue wise there were moments where I found myself chuckling at the humor.Gameplay-wise: I played on hard difficulty which wasn't quite apparent until maybe halfway into the game where counter-interrupts and status effects started plaguing me, but I quickly adapted to using ailment protection so that wasn't too bad. There wasn't much need for grinding so to say, which made the RPG aspect much more enjoyable as I could just plow straight through the story. The combat aspect takes up a majority of the gameplay with a touch of exploration, especially looking for stardusts (permanent power up bonuses). Combat is a lot of fun with a timeline based combat that tells you "who goes next" while still remaining intuitive. The kicker however is the fireflly, where you can use him to slow enemies JUST ENOUGH so that you can interrupt them.Story-wise: The game gives me a JRPG type of feel which I am completely okay withOverall: I had an enjoyable time exploring everything. I think it's at least worth a look at if your into RPGs

content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												I highly recommend this game; it is lovely.  The music and art design enchant and the gameplay reminds me of an old school JRPG with improvements.  It lacks difficulty unless you play on hard.  The rest of this is slightly spoiler-ish.Combat: Turned based with a timer.  Each combatant appears on the timer bar so you can track the order and the bar is divided into two parts.  The first part is "wait" in which the combatants do not act; the second part is "cast" which is when the combatants prepare to act.  While the combat is turn based, the addition of the "cast" part of the timer bar allows for actions to be interrupted which adds greater complexity.  Additionally, different combatants traverse the timer bar at different speeds and different actions do as well.  An action that takes more time to perform may be interrupted by a slower enemy because that enemy used a faster attack.  Overall, this is a major improvement over classic turn based combat.Adventuring: At first, the game appears to be a platformer.  However, once Aurora gains the ability to fly, the areas become much more open and free with no more platforming.  She can fly over the obstacles, after all.  A little firefly accompanies Aurora as well and interacts with chests, blinds enemies, and collects "wishes" which replenish the party's HP/MP.  Blinding the enemies allows Aurora to bypass them or get behind them for a surprise attack.  I should mention, that most enemies can be avoided; in other words, there are no random encounters.  The experience is almost therapeutic when combined with the music and art.  There are very few load screens because the areas are quite expansive.Graphics: It looks like a hand-drawn storybook.  While it is a sidescroller, the environments incorporate a foreground and background providing the illusion of depth and extra details such as wild animals and the occasional giant in the background.  The world does not seem as desolate as it does in most sidescrollers.  The animations are smooth and fluid.Story: I have not experienced enough of the story to adequately judge it, but it does seem quite good thus far.  If the occasional interruptions are canonical, the story is being told by a mother as a bedtime story.  In conjunction with the graphics, it maintains grants tremendous character to the game as a whole.  The dialogue consists of a ABCB rhyme scheme (except for one comical character) to replicate an epic poem of old.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												Child of Light is great. The environments and lighting are gorgeous, the dialogue is fun (and rhyming!), the pacing seems pretty good, it lets you explore a lot and the difficulty curve is well done. Skill progression is simple and well thought-out. The music is your basic piano pieces with orchestral music during combat scenes, but it works really well and adds a lot to the atmosphere. Plus it's composed by a really good French Canadian singer!The story is fairly simplistic, but there's a lot of room for it to become more complex, and if my first party member is representative of the rest, the game will have very interesting side-characters.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												CoL has a very enjoyable story for all ages. From Aurora's flowing hair to the pitter patter of her running around barefoot the graphics and sound are very detailed. The dialogue and story isn't overly complex and allowing your kids to play with you is a Plus. The turn-based battle system is interactive and keeps you alert unlike others you may have experienced. The skill system is deep enough to add variation to your prefered playstyle.   Concerning Uplay: There is nothing wrong with Uplay. It has a rewards and achievements system that actually makes it worth it. I personally don't see what the fuss is about.  I feel once you get the hang of the battle system and immerse yourself into the story you will have one of the most pleasant RPG experiences this year.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												After playing through the entire game and doing most of the side content, I'm still torn. I can't recommend it in good conscience however.Gameplay: The combat feels like a classic JRPG but with some real-time elements that allow you to control a secondary character (or let someone else use the mouse to do so). This guy can collect healing objects for you, or even slow down your enemies on the timeline which is incredibly useful and adds a new dynamic to trying to interrupt your enemies. Overall I enjoyed the classic combat. My one major gripe is that you only ever can have 2 of your party members out at a time, which seems absurd to me. Especially since your enemies routinely have 3.Art: You can't say enough about the art style. It's got a brilliant storybook feel that is woven throughout the story as well. The color palette and style is bold and refreshing. Animation leaves a lot to be desired however, as they all look more like paper cutouts hanging from strings.Story/Writing: This is what ruins the game for me. The story is hopelessly childish and unoriginal, which leaves me wondering what the target audience is. I do realize that this matches the visual style, but there must be ways to achieve a story that is appealing to adults while maintaining the whimsical visuals. Things like Trine 2 or Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons did this wonderfully. Overall the story was sickeningly saccharine. In contrast, Brothers started out extremely fanciful, but quick got dark and serious in it's themes. They're both coming-of-age tales, but Brothers pulled it off in a much more brilliant and emotional way (and without words, yet!). In Child of Light, you'll never care about any of the characters. Speaking of words, I must say a few about the poetry. I feel as if the poetry could have saved the hokey story. However, the poetry was dreadful. The writers made no attempt to compose with any meter or rhythm, but instead stuck stubbornly to their A-B-A-B rhyme scheme regardless of the cadence of the sentences. Shakespeare is rolling in his grave. I love great poetry when it has a solid rhythm and bounce to it (See Penny Arcade's Twisp and Catsby stuff!), but this sounded more like a junior high student writing poetry for the first time. Even the rhymes were a stretch from time to time, and left you gagging or saying "oh come on, really?!".In conclusion, I give this a "NO" with a very heavy heart. I wanted to like it so bad. There were parts of it I really enjoyed. But I found myself rushing from battle to battle in order to enjoy the combat, while the story left me wanting. I don't mind a good kid's story. But this wasn't just a kid's story, it was downright childish and lame. If you think the beautiful art and great combat can redeem an ignorable story, then maybe give this a try. But for me, it wasn't worth the 10 hours.

number of helpful: 9 of 19 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												Child of Light is a basic 2D adventure through the fantasy land of Lemuria. The princess, Aurora, has died and her papa has lost hope, but with the help of unusual friends there is no time to mope. Aurora battles darkness with friends anew, hoping to see this spiritual adventure through. Magicians, jesters and warriors unite to give the princess one last chance. With each battle won, Aurora makes her advance.The attractive world of Lemura is rendered with Ubi-Art Framework, but the lack of noteworthy gameplay starts to hurt. Aurora walks or flies across colorful landscapes, stumbling upon treasures and wishes.  Wishes ignite your friendly orb of light and treasures prevent you sleeping with the fishes. The orb stuns foes left and right, but minimal exploration makes the adventure slight.  As you collide with foes, you are thrust into a contrived battle pose. Battles have your friends taking turns to eliminate foes counting three. But the nature of the combat propels enjoyment far out to sea. You jostle to deal elemental damage to susceptible foes, yet constant interrupts keep you on your toes. Once you become a master tactician, bosses turn interrupts into a war of attrition. Some bosses succumb after half an hour, making boss battles repetitive and sour. Combat is tolerable at best - how much you can endure is the true test. Just as the world lacks excitement, the un-voiced dialogue becomes an indictment. Exactly as this review is written before you, the authors were smitten with rhyming too. Some might think it funny or clever, but it becomes like persistent bad weather. If instead you find this readable, then you’ll likely find the narrative tolerable. Know that there is little that proves enlightening, even as you battle forces most frightening. If Lemuria is the land we are sent to after death, try to avoid the reaper long after your last breath. If you insist on buying Child of Light to get your arty platforming hit, don’t complain when you discover it’s quite sh…

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 17, 2016
												It’s an unfortunate thing when one can see the amount of effort that has been put into a game and to come away from it feeling so unsatisfied. Sadly, that is the case with regards to my experience with Child of Light.Using the UbiArt Framework to create a watercolor world of wonder, Child of Light definitely succeeds in being something lovely to look at; indeed, this is what first drew me to the game. The music is very lovely as well (even touching at times) and adds to the child-like, fairy-tale theming of the game and story. However, it is in this fairy-tale presentation that I believe the game makes its biggest misstep: rhyming.Bear with me and allow me to elaborate: I know it seems silly that something so innocuous could mar a good game. When first beginning my journey through Lemuria the rhyming came off as quite charming. The spoken narration for the cut-scenes, all written in rhyme, made it feel like a tale being told to a sleepy-eyed child and was not unwelcome in the slightest. As the game wore on, though, and the repeated reading of rhymes continued (some conversations turning bizarre just to tag a rhyme on the end), I found myself completely apathetic towards Aurora and her friends. Every line of dialogue attempts to rhyme with no consistent rhyming scheme throughout, which resulted in all interactions becoming a sort of poetic muddle, preventing any sort of personalities for the characters to shine through past their singular motivations. It’s possible that if each character spoke in a different rhyming scheme then making all dialogue rhyme in some way or another would have been successful; there’s plenty of great literature written entirely in rhyme. As it stands, though, the inconsistent schemes just make the dialogue a chore to read, as one dialogue set will rhyme one way but the next will buck the previous set’s scheme for something else. Near the game’s end, I found myself avoiding side-quests, ignoring potential new party members, and just trying to get to the game’s conclusion so that I could be done with it.All of which is incredibly disappointing because the game is perfectly functional. The combat is a decent, turn-based affair with a few little tweaks to the long-standing formula that provides additional interest and strategy: nothing to write home about but completely adequate. The same can be said of the Oculi crafting system, which allows you to create additional stat-boosting accessories for your party. These coupled with the aforementioned charming visuals and lovely music could have created a perfectly enjoyable experience but without engaging dialogue to breathe personality into the characters, world, and story, these factors all end up becoming window-dressing to an unfortunately bland experience.I really wanted to like Child of Light, too, but in the end I don’t feel that I can recommend it. For all its charms it ends up feeling without its own voice or personality, which left me feeling regrettably unfulfilled.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												After playing Child of Light for 2 hours, i have to say its a refreshing change from a lot of the JRPG style games that have come out recently. Artistically this game is about as gorram whimsical as you can get. It reminds me a lot of older stories and fairy tales that i was told as a kid. Gameplay-wise, this is what you'd get if you crossed an indie developed puzzle-platformer like Limbo, with a game like (the old and good) final fantasy games. The combat feels great and the interupt mechanic is a nice touch.The game's music is understated and adds a great childlike atmosphere to the environment.Overall i'd say i'm going to enjoy the rest of the game if it continues along this same path.I could comment on the same day DLC, which is obviously a ubisoft cashgrab and takes away a bit of the magic of this game if you think about it too much. So i don't think about it too much! Its pretty simple.Recommended for everyone who enjoys games like FFIV-VII, Limbo, Braid or any other game in those 2 veins.Play more games!

content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												I hate it when I regret buying a game, but unfortunately, that is the case with Child of Light. The trailer looked *amazing* and the reviews looked positive too. I was hoping this would be a beautiful game I could lose myself in. Unfortunately that was not the case.The story of the game is about a princess who falls into a dream-world which she must explore and escape. Accordingly, the movements of the character are very dream-like and slow...contrary to the trailer, which showed her moving at a "normal" video game pace. Thus, trying to play this game was almost painful...it's like one of those dreams where you're trying to run but your feet are bogged down like you're trying to swim in a pool full of syrup. Not a pleasant gameplay experience at all.I still tried to stick it out though, until I got to the combat part. I guess I'm just not used to puzzle-related combat styles in games, but, it just wasn't very fun to try to figure out. If you're used to games like that, then this won't be a problem. But it wasn't enjoyable for me at all.The good parts about this game are the music and the graphics. The music is haunting and beautiful, and the graphics are styled to look like a moving watercolor painting you can explore...which is an awesome concept that is stunningly executed in this game. So since that part of the game is so awesome, I really wish the gameplay for this game hadn't been so hard to use. Because if you can't play the game, it doesn't matter how pretty it is to look at and listen to. Unless you just watch playthroughs of it on YouTube. Which is a possibility I guess.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												Child of Light is a very, very pretty game. I adore the art style, the character designs, and how the environments make it feel like I'm traveling through the pages of a beautifully illustrated fairytale similar to the ones I used to read when I was a child.The combat in the game was alright, but I found myself wanting to avoid as much as possible as I progressed. I didn't find it all that fun, probably because I never felt like my character was progressing in any significant way. The skill tree wasn't very exciting (I would always forget to assign points because I didn't care), and using oculi in place of traditional equipment was disappointing, especially when having to switch them around frequently depending on what I was fighting.My biggest complaint with Child of Light, however, was the dialogue. I appreciate what they were trying to do, but I found it very difficult to invest myself in the characters or the story because the rhyming made it hard for me to follow what was going on. It was far too distracting, and eventually I stopped trying to decipher the silliness and button mashed through all the talking.I wanted to love this game and there are things I do love about it. The soundtrack is wonderful, and obviously it's a joy to look at and explore. I just feel that the most important aspects of this game were the ones that let me down the most.Also, the Uplay requirement to play is lame.

												Bah.... in this age of technology, I shouldn't need to carefully study my system specs to make sure my system will support the game.   What is this, 1995?   Steam should  automagically verify my specs against game requirements before I click the "BUY" button... or even before I add a game to my cart.I'm sure this is a fine game, but not playable on a PC with a Dual Core AMD 2.3 GHZ processor... no matter how powerful your video card is... the game won't even attempt to launch.   A  "CPU does not meet requirements" popup kills it.There's also a Uplay connection/account verification you have to go through before the game will even attempt to load. Yuck. Shame on Ubisoft for that.I got it on sale, so I'll keep it for when I upgrade my PC (in a couple years), but come on Steam, seems like a straighforward feature to add (storing systems credentials and then verifying against game requirements before purchase.)

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												There's not enough good things to say about this gameFirst off, yes it needs uplay. But for a game like this, they could force me to run uplay, steam, origin, whatever they wanted and I'd still buy it. The story is beautiful in a way that very few other games have come close to. The watercolor art style fits well with the 2D viewpoint. The characters are interesting, the story is fantastic, the controls work well. The fight system is fun to use and requires actual strategy instead of random button mashing or luck. I have honestly no negative things to say about this game. For 15 bucks, I clocked in a playtime of over 7 hours and I've only finished the main story. There's still loads of sidequests and areas to explore. If you haven't played it yet, do it now. Of my entire library, I'm normally critical of most games, but this game falls into the category of 1 in 4 that I actually loved enough to write a positive review of.

												I wasn't a big fan of this game, though I've heard that it gets better so I might try playing farther in the future.  In the time I played, I didn't like the gameplay and I didn't like the writing, so there was really nothing there that made me want to continue.  It was really the writing that was the bigger problem for me.  The rhyming dialogue was kind of forced and awkward, imo it would've worked better if they had not tried to rhyme at all.The gameplay wasn't a huge problem, but it was just uninteresting to me.  I'm not a huge fan of turn-based combat to begin with, and it was more tedious than usual in this game.  Also, I tried the local co-op and the second player's role was pretty lame (if you've played Mario Galaxy, it's like the co-op in that game).The positives were the art style and the atmosphere, they were the things that originally drew me to the game.  I love the way the game looks, just didn't love the way it plays.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												Aside from the rhyming becoming cliche after a little while into it, this game is phenominal. The story is fantastic, the characters feel lively in this, to me at least they were actual characters you cared about through their backgrounds. Some allies are timid and fearful while others are strong, yet outcasted. The story really blends everything together well and made me want keep going just so I could see what would happen next. The art style is beautiful, all the characters are flawlessly designed for the setting they're placed within like paintings on a canvas. A lot went behind this game, and I personally believe it paid off. The story's like a page-turner. Sometimes it gets a little slow, sometimes it speeds through and puts the characters in a terrible perdicament, and there're those moments where it's just right-those moments where you lose sense of that fact that it's a game, it feels more like a work of art (totally not referring to the combat, referring to a scene later in the game.). All in all it's worth 15 bucks.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												This game is simply awesome, Great visuals, dialogue that has a certain charm to it, strategic turn-based combat and plenty of rewards for exploration. If you like RPG's with turn-based combat, this is a no-brainer, and for $15, damn good value.The day 1 DLC and UPlay will be a turn-off for some people, but they're a non-issue for me personally, the DLC's are mostly aesthetics and just more of the oculi (think of them as sockets as in other RPG's, things you can put on equipment to add attributes to them) that you find plenty of in-game anyway (and get even more of with the UPlay rewards). As for UPlay itself, I've never had an issue with it, but I know some people have, so if UPlay concerns you, you might want to err on the side of caution.Overall, I definitely don't regret buying this, and again, for $15, it really is a steal.
