number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2014
Outline, Story/Plot, Conclusiveness:Basic, not too special good/light vs evil/dark story.Rather ordinary plot devices and "messages". Like a girl growing up on the hardships of her adventure and taking more and more responsibility and that family, friendship and faith can overcome all - ideas I cannot particularily relate to. I believe they are overused in fictional media, and with this lose their appeal and meaningfulness to me. They probably make up some of the most fundamental aspects of life and I can respect if writers actually believe in this, but sometimes this stuff feels pretentious and a bit uninspiring to me. The ending felt a bit rushed. I didn't expect the game to end as early as it did, even though the rough outline and the "goal" was foreseeable and the story found a conclusive, logical ending.Voice Acting, Narration, Writing, Music, Sounds:Almost no voice acting. Only a neutral narrator once in a while. The characters in the game only speak via text. Most narration and text is in verses and rhymes. Sometimes it felt a bit forceful, in other instances it helped to give weight to some of the statements Aurora or her companions were giving. All in all I think they did a great job with this and that it helps to create the ambiance of playing a fairytale. It surely wasn't easy to write all this, I suppose, and still have it make sense. I didn't understand it all, as English isn't my main language and I'm not used to poetry of this kind in any of the languages I speak.Nice music and some interesting sound design (Aurora walks on her bare feet, and you can hear this when she touches the ground; I thought the flapping of her wings sounded nice too).Art/Visual Design, Animation:Beautiful level art (resembling watercolor paintings/aquarelle).Somewhat underwhelming character portrait art (looks a bit like something a nonprofessional would put up on deviantART).Nicely animated protagonist. Aurora moves very smoothly, from what I've seen she is a mix of 2D and 3D. Just as some other main characters. Most other people and creatures look entirely 2D to me, and appear less "plastic" as a result. It's not easy to explain but best to look at in trailers or the likes. Combat, Difficulty, Skilling, Platforming/Puzzling, Local Co-Op:Turn-based combat. Very unusual for Western games, it's what you see in Japanese RPGs usually. But even Japanese RPGs often appear overly strategic to me with dozens of units to control on a big grid field, or they put you under stress with real-time elements. Child of Light sticks to more traditional RPGs. You control two characters in combat, and fight a maximum of three enemies in turns. There is a turn priority, and there are means to slow down/speed up combatants to get them make their turns more quickly/slowly. You can exchange your fighters freely once it's their turn, and time your attacks to interrupt your enemies' actions.Normal difficulty was pretty easy. If you handle the turn priority system right you can keep your enemies interrupted most of the time, or you kill them quickly enough before they start dealing more damage. Also, there are three ways of healing people (too many, perhaps): Simultaneously to moving Aurora around in the world and choosing fighting orders in combat you control a firefly spirit. This firefly has an energy bar he can exhaust to light up his surrounding area and by that either heal your fighters or blind/slow down enemies. Most damage I was able to heal with this firefly. I almost never used any consumables (healing potions and the likes), and healing spells rarely when the energy bar of the firefly was exhausted. Was someone still hurt too much I exchanged him or her with another fighter. Towards the end of the game you have like 3-5 fighters to choose from, and I rarely saw the health of any of them turn dangerously low.The game is advertised with "200 skills" on one of the trailers. But this is a bit eye-washing. There are many skills, but a significant part of them are passive skills which merely increase the attributes of your fighters and not actually give you something to alter your combat experience with. There is not a particulary lack of active skills - there are numerous fighters, and they all have specific, unique and fitting skills designed towards their character profiles and backgrounds, but there is little freedom in developing the characters as there are only two, at best three "paths" to move on the skill trees with no way of branching out. You go path A, path B or path C. Inbetween you may stop going one and walk some you previously ignored, and vice versa, but that's about it. Ultimatively they could have given you two or three perfectly flattened left-to-right skill lines for each character instead of the winded ones you find in this game.There is some platforming and puzzling, but it's not really worth mentioning. Spikes coming out of the walls, a few boxes to push on some buttons to open doors. What is interesting is that you can use the already mentioned firefly to pick up items and open chests. It's glowing light is used in several places to activate buttons, solve riddles based on shadowplay and to get past obstacles. It is a form of "singleplayer co-op" as I believe this is called, and interestingly strongens the ties between Aurora and the firefly as her constant companion in an active way really feelable by the player. Apparently a second local human player can control the firefly, which may help feel this tie even more so. There sure is a lot of to do with the firefly, so this local 2-player co-op may be a lot of fun (I didn't try it myself).

												Child of Light is simply beautiful.It has a detailed and rich 2D visuals with unique artstyle, with smooth animations.The active-time based strategy allows a variation of strategy and timing, since, aside from just selecting actions, you are able to manipulate your enemies' timer. It was nice and refreshing to play an old-school system with a new twist.The music does the job nicely. It's soothing, dreamy, and fantasy-like. I have to say it reminds me of a mobile rhythm game, Deemo.The story uses the troupe of light vs darkness, it does work on RPGs, and I feel Child of Light hit it quite well.Overall Child of Light is beautiful to watch, fun to play, and it feels like playing a classic RPG.

												This game is a masterpiece. There is so much detail put into the game in regards to art and gameplay. Even in the very beginning, I noticed various hidden locations that can expound on the gameplay or lore as a whole. Although I've only played this for a solid hour, I can assure you that this game is wonderful. I fully recommend it.The gameplay is very simple from the beginning, and the turn-based battle system is flawless. I enjoy the various strategies I can take in order to attack my opponents faster, defend myself, prevent myself from being interrupted, and etcetera.The artistic side of the game is perhaps the reason why I first took a look at this game. I don't think I can say much about the artwork other than 'Just check it out. This game is beautiful'.Finally, the lore. My God, if you love poetry and a beautiful, enthralling, story-telling game, you are probably in heaven now. The story, so far, is amazing. I anticipate great things when I continue to play it.Child of Light is a 2.5D sidescrolling RPG adventure that follows the story of Aurora when she awakens in the land of Lemuria. The game is beautiful, the gameplay is simple and functional, and the story is fascinating. From the looks of things, this game is a MUST GET. For jut $14.99... there shouldn't be much of a reason why you wouldn't be able to buy Child of Light.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												Wow. Just wow. This is the first review I've ever written, and I've played alot of steam games. But this one was so moving that I just had to write one.The first thing that comes to mind is how polished the game is, good on the technical designers for making sure that the controls are intuitive and respond well. I know alot of people overlook how well the UI works in a game, but it responds so well, eliminates unnecessary clicking, and just overall isn't cumbersome.The gameplay and story are a 10/10 for me. Story was great, and I'll leave it at that as to not spoil anything, but I like how all of the dialog consists of rhymes. As for gameplay, I love how the battle system is dependant on your skill as a player, if you learn how to use the system well, which doesn't take much, you can almost do boss battles without taking damage.Music could have been a bit more dramatic, but it was still great.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												What an enchanting game. It feels like a fairy tale with rpg elements. Like a well illustrated children's storybook come to life in video game form. RPG combat system is classic with a few updates. A lot of the tactical element of the game centers around altering how quickly you or your enemies can attack. If you can attack your enemy when their initiative meter gets into the red zone, you can interrupt them potentially setting them back an entire turn. And you have multiple options for affecting that timing. While your attacks are turn based, you have a fairy companion controlled separately by the mouse who can heal you, or slow down your enemies and operates in real time.  Out of combat this same companion can interact with objects on the map that Aurora can't reach in a variety of ways allowing two people to play, one operating Aurora with the keyboard and the other controlling the fairy with the mouse The trailers do a pretty good job of letting you know what you're in for and the beauty and grandeur of it all holds up throughout the game. Its proof that you can have a beautiful game without demanding that your video card spit out the maximum number of polygons and photorealistic textures and next gen lighting effects. As shown here, with some actual art direction, you can do so much more with so much less. The story is a basic coming of age tale combined with a heroes journey. Young Princess Aurora seemingly dies in bed only to wake up in a strange new land. Able to see haunting visions of her own father falling ill from grief as he mourns her passing, she must explore her new world and try to find her way home while making friends and enemies along the way. One annoying thing was the decision to write the game in rhyming couplets. I know that this was done to hold with the storybook fairy tale conceit but it started to wear thin for me rather quickly and had me wishing that they'd just speak plainly. But I am a childless 35 year old man (what are you looking at me for? Maybe I want a change of pace from the high octane AAA experience every now and then), so your mileage may vary. I've seen plenty of comments both ways from other people. I will say that if you find the dialog annoying, its usually not terribly essential to read all of it apart from getting side quests and there's not a huge amount of it anyway. The soundtrack and the art still make for a plenty beautiful experience even if the dialog doesn't work for you and the gameplay should be plenty fun for any fan of classic rpg gameplay. But other than that, everything about this game was great. Nice change of pace too. And again speaking as a childless 35 year old man, I found that it didn't get to "twee" for me, so if that was a concern for you, don't worry. Its also a short game for those of you who have lives.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												**CANNOT RECOMMEND DUE TO UPLAY REQUIREMENTS**This game is gorgeous, and I was quite attracted to the artistic style of the game and the themes of its story.  However, the turn-based RPG combat felt trite and out of place given the rest of the game experience.  It was also disappointing that grinding through these combat encounters was frequently the only means of story progression.  The artistry of the world is no mean feat, but the game play was not particularly unique or innovative and the story lost much of its thematic power through experience grinds and interruptions announcing Uplay unlock/ achievement events.Had I noticed this required a continuously-connected Uplay account, I simply would not have made the purchase.  I like the game, but I just don't play it because of the hassle involved.  Logging into both Steam and Uplay back to back, and being unable to access a single-player game for which I have already paid whenever the internet is wonky, is absolute rubbish.  I am disappointed that Steam is offering games with this type of DRM and promoting them with sales.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												This is likely my GOTY of 2014. One of the best RPGs I've ever played! The battle system is so addicting and fun. The game makes it very easy to avoid enemy encounters, but you'll find yourself wanting to intentionally confront enemies all the time, because the battles are just that fun. The characters are all really unique and charming, especially your party members. The game doesn't rehash or copy beaten-to-death cliches from RPGs of the past. It really goes out of its way to forge its own identity, making it feel really fresh and new. The visuals and music are absolutely stunning and incredibly memorable. I applaud Ubisoft for giving us this masterpiece!

content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												HOLY MACORNI. I am SO glad I went with my gut feeling to get a hold of this game. This game is ABSOLUTE perfection. I cannot find a SINGLE thing I hate or even dislike about this game. The story is grounded and easy to follow, the artwork is something that me personally as an artist is envious of, the musical score is to DIE FOR, the characters are loveable, there was SO MUCH exploration to be done and the game ALWAYS rewarded you for going off track and exploring. Also-- As someone who is TERRIBLE at figuring out puzzles I was not stuck on a single puzzle for more than....10 minutes or so? This game is SO badass without having to be straight-out brutish or throw in an AK-47 or anything. This is just a game that deserves every fan and dollar it makes, it pays such amazing attention to detail that theirs no way I can praise it enough without just saying to get a copy yourself and see what I'm talking about.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Child of Light is a touching story that builds a quick attachment to the protagonist, a young girl named, Aurora.  A faux princess, so she thinks, Aurora gains comapnions who quickly become friends through battle and snippets of interaction between scenes that include Aurora and the companions but also conversation between the others themselves that will make you laugh.  The game at it's core is medium paced and though the battle is turn based, the interupt tactics and skill builds quickly make battle fun and engaging.  Storyline is phenominal if only because it pulls at your heartstrings; especially if you are a female gamer, like myself, who can identify with her relationship with her father.  Every little girl who has a good Dada will find this game a tear jerker if only due to the fact Aurora never gives up solely because her father needs her and as the story progresses, the confidence with which she uses to move forward to get home to her father begins to coalesce with the needs of the people of this world consumed by the night.  Aurora is a wonderful lead and in hand with the game mechanics (flying being one of my favorite aspects), the companions that keep you laughing and the relatable paternal relationship make Child of Light a thoroughly enjoyable game that I suggest everyone give a try!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												One of the most endearing game I have played in the last year, Child of Light brings you into a fairytale world with its unique look inspired by watercolor paintings of the 19th century, and its funny dialogue, all in rhyme. The characters are unique and interesting, with their own personality.The music, always an important part of a game for me, is sad and heroic at the same time; I enjoyed it so much I actually bought the soundtrack.Aurora, the heroine, is an endearing character, a child who grows as you guide her through the story. I loved just watching her hair flow around in the wind as you fly around looking for hidden chests or monsters. She's kind, courageous, and grows as the story progresses.I love stories and games with female protagonists, and this does not disappoint, an excellent example that games featuring strong women in leading roles can be great. Aurora is a very good role-model for young gamers.The gameplay was a bit easy and rather simple, but then I'm a veteran of this kind of game for 30 years. Still I found the combat system enjoyable overall. The real gems in this game are the exploration, the dialogue and the story.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												A fun title that could have been more. First, the positives: the art work is beautiful; really stunning watercolour design. Second, the music, whilst the tunes get very familiar, they're also pretty easy on the ears too. You'll find yourself humming along before long. The gameplay is surprisingly challenging. I reccommend playing on 'gamer' mode to properly experience Child of Light. There's a nice skill tree available to each character and the AI does not play nice. I'll readily admit I died a few times in this game.On the 'less' positive side is the story. It's very simplistic, unfortunately so. The real meat of the story is hidden away in difficult to locate 'diary entries'. There's a lot that could have been done to flesh out characters. The game script gets a little tedious also. The nusery rhyme style, whilst cute to a point, can make reading a little frustrating, especially when trying to decipher the aforementioned diary entries. 3 1/2 stars.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
												"The path home, tragic and fate.  Beware the night.   Child of Light." A game full of adventure and mystery, set out for you to write its history. Storytelling told, never to forget. Characters with memorable expressions and souls. Let Lemuria be a place to remember now and then. For you have a role, that must unfold. This is poetry inspired by the game itself. You see what beauty it can bring? Ideas that spring, from a game of pure beauty. I am not the one making the choice to buy the game, A story must be told. . .but that depends on who looks at it which way. I have an adventure to continue back in the kingdom of Lemuria where characters, music, and battles are never forgotten. So I will leave this up to you, whether or not it stays. Take this recommendation, but not forcefully. . .for this is a matter of opinion, and an enjoyable thing to write for me.Child of Light, a game for some, and a journey. Awaiting without refuge some say.

												Really astonishing how they mashed up a storybook like art style in a fantasy rpg game.  I really really love the art concept and the plot! <3It's like reliving your childhood during bed time story but this time you control it and interact with it making a full blown experience.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2014
												Ok so I just finished playing Child of Light!!! I enjoyed it tremendously. The aesthetics are magnificient (not to mention the poetry, seriously), the music gorgeous, the battle system, the oculi and the whole mechanics using Igniculus are just wonderful, I had not seen something like that before, I think it was very creative. Oh, and a felame protagonist. I must always mention that. Now, about the difficulty: I played in normal, and didn't find it difficult in the least. It wasn't a breeze, but with a bit of grinding I found the pace great, letting you relax through the game without becoming bored. Just a thing more, all this is coming from someone who suffers fybromialgia, and I must say that this game was a blessing, since because of the fog that comes with the illness I have been less and less able to play any kind of game, and being able to thorougly enjoy this one was a more than welcome change. I can't stress enough how happy I am for being able to play something as awesome as this again, but maybe I am a bit biased because of that.I was a bit worried after buying it because all the hate on Uplay, but honestly, I don't see it as bad, it didn't bother me at all, didn't disconect once (and let it be known that my internet competes for the worst internet in the world), and it had the Uplay win thing, that had some rad things. I'm off to play the NG+ now! ;)

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												One of the most endearing game I have played in the last year, Child of Light brings you into a fairytale world with its unique look inspired by watercolor paintings of the 19th century, and its funny dialogue, all in rhyme. The characters are unique and interesting, with their own personality.The music, always an important part of a game for me, is sad and heroic at the same time; I enjoyed it so much I actually bought the soundtrack.Aurora, the heroine, is an endearing character, a child who grows as you guide her through the story. I loved just watching her hair flow around in the wind as you fly around looking for hidden chests or monsters. She's kind, courageous, and grows as the story progresses.I love stories and games with female protagonists, and this does not disappoint, an excellent example that games featuring strong women in leading roles can be great. Aurora is a very good role-model for young gamers.The gameplay was a bit easy and rather simple, but then I'm a veteran of this kind of game for 30 years. Still I found the combat system enjoyable overall. The real gems in this game are the exploration, the dialogue and the story.

Overall for the price of the game you would regret passing this if anything above intrigued you. 7/10

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												The turned-based style of battle makes this game's battles a bit long, but each second matters. As the story progresses, you come to love each one of them. Aurora is such a fun girl to get to play as and to get to see her go from child, to teenager, to princess, it made me love her even more. Each side-character has a certain style of fighting. Some of them heal, others cure status ailments, some are much stronger than Aurora. The oculi and Igniclus' glow can drastically change the outcome of the fight. It's very slow going though until you get your wings, as Aurora is a little girl and runs in little strides. Other than that it's an amazing game! I suggest playing it!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												A deep, in-depth experience for lovers of both turn based RPGs and metroid-vania style exploration games.  Designed in a such a way, however, that its very accessible to people who have trouble getting into games.  Case in point, my non-gamer girlfriend is in love with this game.  And with the co-op light (not a true co-op experience) the second player (me) can help the first player by healing, blinding enemies, and more.  It's a really interesting mechanic to adjust the difficulty without physically asking the game to be easy.Its rare to see a 2D platforming turn based RPG and this game pulls it off really well.  Also with the same engine as Rayman Origins and Legends, the game is beautiful and runs very well.  You definitely get your money's worth at full price, I hope this isn't the last we hear from this series.  Or, at least this style of game.

content:

												Simply a wonderful and beautiful game. Great story, great main character, great combat system, great art, dialogues and ending. The music is simply beautiful. It's been a long time since I played a game that captivated me with its story and characters. The combat system is pretty fun and dynamic, it's not just about choosing the right attacks and knowing what to do, but you can interact real-time between turns to turn the tides to your favor. This game is a 10/10 and anyone who likes RPGs should play it. And the rhymes just make the meaning of the characters' words' more powerful.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												Never would I have thought that steam could tell bedtime stories. If nothing else, the visuals are enough to take your breath away. the watercolor painting inspired artwork and fanatstical setting really sets the fairytale spirit of the game. However, you cant make a god narritive with pretty visuals alone, there has to be a gripping story and well one telling of it. The story is reminiscent of the classic fairy tale stories we heard as kids; it has a princess, a witch, magic, strange creatures, and a hero. Luckily it has enough original ideas to be far from cliche. The gameplay is very well done too. It's combat system is second to none and the puzzles will keep your brain working throughout the game without feeling like its just solvig the same simple puzzle over and over.  For the icing on the cake, we have the music. Written by Candian artist, Coeur de Pirate, it really sets the mood of the game. the dreamy piano gives it that bedtime story feeling, and the orchestral parts really emphasize the fantastic landscape and intense battle. If I could just sum this up, I would say it's a simple and intelligent game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												They said they were inspired by Chrono Trigger and Finaly Fantasy 6, two of my favorite games, and it shows. The battle system is simple but fun, and it forces you to pay attention. I love the idea of being able to fly anywhere too. I really enjoyed it. However, the dialogue is terrible. The idea is to have every single line rhyme, which is ok in theory, but it is written really badly. After every single battle most of your party levels up, which detracts from the feeling of accomplishment. I was level 47 when I realized that I didn't level up after a battle. The animation and art style is beautiful, but I didn't really like the character artwork at all. The music is really nice, but relies heavily on one theme. It's a charming little RPG with a lot of flaws, but if you overlook them, it is a lot of fun and captures the sort of imaginative world feel that video games used to have.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												CoL is innocative and interesting. In a genre that has some puzzle solving one would normally see real time combat CoL chooses to use an interesting twist on turn based RPG combat. There are still stats that decided damage, weakness, and resistance like one would assume, but there is also manipulation of attack order and the ability to time attacks correctly to interrupt an enemy attack.The art is inspiring and colorful, and the characters are unique and compelling. There is enough action between the dialouge that is doesn't feel heavy, but there is enough dialouge to guide an interesting story that fits the genre of bed time fairy tales. "A little girl chosen as a child of light to fight a queen of darkness and reclaim a lost land", that sort of thing.As for UPlay its not a perfect system, its annoying to have to run there program in addition to steam, in addition to the game itself, but I hadn't used my account with them since playing Far Cry 3 on PS3 about two years ago, and I had no trouble recovering my account and playing the game.Great game, reasonable price, you won't be disappointed with this addition to your steam library.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
												I am really enjoying this game. I had to buy it for my PS3 because my PC is a little old, but it was worth buying twice. The environments are amazing and I enjoy the poetry aspect of the dialog. If you are a fan of JRPGs then there is a good bet you will like Child of Light. I do recommend getting the Golem's Plight pack. Golem is a great addition to the team, and his quest is in the beginning of the game, so it is best to get that DLC when you start the game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												Just started out and love it. This game is clearly some dev's love-child not just some assembly line product like Ubi's AC series. Something unique and personal like a bedtime-tale told to you as a youngling.Dark and melancholic atmosphere feels like kids-friendly Dark Souls with some similarities story-wise -lol. Maps looks light-metroidvania but I'm not too far in to judge. Some riddles though easy so far. Reached the first boss - cool design. Difficulty on hard setting is decent, very easy on normal setting. Dual-stick-controller highly recommended.Pretty graphics look hand-painted and fit the mood, some won't like it but the majority probably will.The same with the soundtrack, very memorable. Deep story so far, I'm really anxious for the ending.Battles play out as cross between Final Fantasy-ATB and Grandia. When the time bar is full you can act with some delay. If you're hit within the action-delay the action gets cancelled. And if the enemy is about to attack you should probably block which also fills your next gauge faster. Definitely buy if you like j-RPGs, pretty stuff and melancholy.I really don't agree with the day 1-DLCs, Uplay or the Ubi-staff posting like us gamers on the forum anon but will not go in detail here as the discussion is already been held elsewhere. Just saying: if it gets games like this gettjng made for 15 bucks it excuses a lot of things and if you don't like Ubi, just get this game then boycott the next 50$/€ AC next time to ease your consciousness. :)Also the DLCs don't seem essential to enjoy the game, it's just to extract some more coins from the rich kiddies.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												I love this game!The art style of this game is amazing. The colors are beautiful.A lot of the detail in your surroundings and backgrounds are simply gorgeous and breathtaking.I feel like I'm reading a children's story book, it's fantastic! The music is very nice as well, it gives you a more emotional tie with Aurora.(At least that's how it makes me feel :P) You can definitely feel for Aurora and her desperation.Pretty intense combat and boss fights, especially fighting multiple foes. I love the effects of a lot of the abilities for Aurora and her companions.You have the Oculi system as well where you can craft your gems to equipt with you and your party to boost your stats or add elemental effects to your attacks.Plus you have the help of an adorable Firefly named Igniculus who aids ingiving you mana/health and collecting items for you as well as slowing your enemies in battleand he is in your control!This game has a very nice story line and its well worth the price. *thumbs up*

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												A side-scrolling RPG, Child of Light combines elements of everything from Limbo to Final Fantasy into a gorgeously drawn, well executed fairytale.It's a peaceful game, and enjoyable to play through, withy lots fo goodies to hunt down.I did find that on standard difficulty it was too easy, but once you get to New Game+ the stakes raise a little, which makes some of the abttles more challenging.A good game for the more novice gamer, and those more interested in the story than the battle system, though I don't at all regret putting the time in to play through. It's not intended to be hardcore gaming, it's intended to be poignant and heartfelt - and it really, really is.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												The art is beautiful, the verse is easy to read and makes the dialog entertaining by itself. The characters, spells, monsters, and story are well thought out and you love all your characters immediately. The combat system is a good blend of turn-based and real-time. It's difficult without making me curse...too often. There are chances to skip on battles but I fought all of them that I found and never had the need to grind levels. The only criticism I have is that you can only use two of your amazing characters at a time, but since you only face a maximum of three enemies it is understandable.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												Child of Light is a great story with BEAUTIFUL graphics and artwork!There ..... i just summed it up in one sentence ..... but if that wasn't enough to convince you, I'll go ahead and go into a little more detail.Story: As i said it's an awesome story.  You play as a "princess" who has been poisoned and wakes up in another world.  You're main gold is to return to YOUR world to save your father who has become deathly ill with grief over your "death".  One thing that is very different but i thought was nice was that all the dialogue between the characters and the narrator were done in poem/balad type format.  So yes, it all rhymed lol.  I suppose you could say it added to the "Immersion" factor in the sense that people don't really TALK like that anymore.Graphics: Lovely hand-drawn backgrounds and characters.Gameplay: Child of Light is built upon the framework of a classic turn-based RPG, but also uses the often seen "Move bar", making combat slightly more dynamic and interactive than just "pick move, use move".  Using your little firefly elemental you can slow down enemies to make your moves go first or fall in just the right place on the move bar to be most effective.The skill trees for all the characters are EXPANSIVE but simplistic at the same time.  You can look ahead and see where you are going so you can plan out exactly what you want the character to do for your group, whether more damage focused or control or healing.  Each character (and there are several you will unlock during your journey) has primarily 3 skill trees that expand after you recover the moon in the game.  Most skills cost only one skill point which you get each time you gain a level and once you get the expansion some of the advance skills cost 2 points.  You gain levels fairly quickly and even if you don't use a character in battle it still levels up with the whole party.  I finished with most of my characters being low to high 40s.After the initial "tutorial" area, and you unlock your flight ability, navigating the world becomes a breeze.  The controls to fly and control that flight are simple and intuitive.  You really get the sense of freedom as you explore every nook and cranny for hidden secrets and chests.I think I've said enough.  If i haven't convinced you to give this game a play by now then nothing more i say is going to make a difference.This game is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!Happy Gaming Guys...

content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
												This is quite the good game. The art style is fantastic, the story line is interesting, and the combat system is amazing. While this game does suffer a bit from its some what forced rhyming dialouge and a short and somewhat choppy story, that shouldn't stop you from trying it out. If you like old style RPG's this is definately the game for you. With a good difficulty level and fantastic visuals, this game is worth a try.I completeded the main story in around 12-13 hours total while doing the majority of the side quests, and I have also started my new game+ file which is a great addition as it allows you to carry over all of your levels, equipment, stats, and skills while amping up the difficulty enough to still be challenging.I highly recommended this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Child of Light is a visually stunning game. Ubisoft pulled out all the stops creating this adorable turn-based RPG. The entire game looks painted onto the screen and the music and immersive story help you fully engage in the story. Although it doesn't look like it, you can fully explore the world around you. The side-quests are fun and challenging, the characters are rich in personality and life, and gaining more party members, skills,and crafting occuli creates an immense sense of accomplishment within the game. Being up to change party members during battle and use them immediately to attack is extremely helpful! Slowing down enemies is also a neat trick to do if one of your moves takes a longer time to "charge up". Anyone who enjoys a good story and turn based combat will love Child of Light!

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												I love this game!The art style of this game is amazing. The colors are beautiful.A lot of the detail in your surroundings and backgrounds are simply gorgeous and breathtaking.I feel like I'm reading a children's story book, it's fantastic! The music is very nice as well, it gives you a more emotional tie with Aurora.(At least that's how it makes me feel :P) You can definitely feel for Aurora and her desperation.Pretty intense combat and boss fights, especially fighting multiple foes. I love the effects of a lot of the abilities for Aurora and her companions.You have the Oculi system as well where you can craft your gems to equipt with you and your party to boost your stats or add elemental effects to your attacks.Plus you have the help of an adorable Firefly named Igniculus who aids ingiving you mana/health and collecting items for you as well as slowing your enemies in battleand he is in your control!This game has a very nice story line and its well worth the price. *thumbs up*

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												A side-scrolling RPG, Child of Light combines elements of everything from Limbo to Final Fantasy into a gorgeously drawn, well executed fairytale.It's a peaceful game, and enjoyable to play through, withy lots fo goodies to hunt down.I did find that on standard difficulty it was too easy, but once you get to New Game+ the stakes raise a little, which makes some of the abttles more challenging.A good game for the more novice gamer, and those more interested in the story than the battle system, though I don't at all regret putting the time in to play through. It's not intended to be hardcore gaming, it's intended to be poignant and heartfelt - and it really, really is.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												Child of Light was a pretty good game on an aesthetic level. (I’d actually go as far as to say that it was a very aesthetic experience).It had great sound design, pleasant music, and wonderful art.Probably the only thing it fell short on for me was the story, which was intriguing but became a little disjointed and didn’t pay off in the end. And the characters, who all had potential but got no real development.Well also, I could have done without the horrible rhyming. It actually made it really hard to understand some of the dialogue. (Although I have to admit for a while when it was making fun of a characters inability to rhyme , it was rather amusing)I hope to see some more games like this in the future, it was pretty refreshing in many ways. And oddly gratifying that it had so many different female characters. I don’t generally care about or notice gender, but in this case I did, and it was actually rather empowering.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												Cute. Fun. Simple. Elegant. This sums up Child of Light. If you are looking for a deep. drawn out, lavish and dark RPG - go play Dark Souls.  If you are looking for something that will just make you smile a little and you can appreciate a good parable - play this game. Aurora is an adorable red headed princess lost in a magical with giant spiders, ghosts and hosts of other creatures. In her journey to save her father, she makes new friends and matures at first mentally- then physically. This game has a lot of great elements to it and more work was put into presentation than mechanics. This is by no means an insult- the creators made a simple but elegant combat and ambience in a game is not something that should ever be neglected.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												This game deserves a much higher meta score than it got, especially for just being a small side project.It is one of the few Turn based RPG's that you will actually see out there.  That in itself gives it a lot of props.The gaming industry has all but completely shunned turned based rpgs and it is a shame, they are what built the industry initially and they are still amazingly fun games to play.This is a fairy tail game.  It's cute, slightly dark at times, and reminds me of a deep nursery rhyme.  It's fantastic.  The music is simply amazing and the artistic design is to be commended.  It is a great play through with a lot of replay value.I highly suggest this game.  For any classic RPG lover, this satisfies what you've been missing this last decade since the great Suikodens and FF's before their downfall.  Give it a chance, you won't find the modern day square enix movie games, but you'll actually get fun gameplay and a heart warming story...more than they are capable of offering anymore.

The characters, spells, monsters, and story are well thought out and you love all your characters immediately. The combat system is a good blend of turn-based and real-time. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Child of Light is a visually stunning game. Ubisoft pulled out all the stops creating this adorable turn-based RPG. The entire game looks painted onto the screen and the music and immersive story help you fully engage in the story. Although it doesn't look like it, you can fully explore the world around you. The side-quests are fun and challenging, the characters are rich in personality and life, and gaining more party members, skills,and crafting occuli creates an immense sense of accomplishment within the game. Being up to change party members during battle and use them immediately to attack is extremely helpful! Slowing down enemies is also a neat trick to do if one of your moves takes a longer time to "charge up". Anyone who enjoys a good story and turn based combat will love Child of Light!

content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												I did enjoy playing this game, the story was good although for all the hype i excepted it to great. the combat was actually fairly enjoyable as well, however it really has a damage vs health issue where in boss fights the main character could die in one round. the crafting system is super simplistic as uses the closest thing this game has to an inventory system. you craft gems that increase your stats or damage however to get upgrades it take 3x as many gems to upgrade, hence i didnt see a way to give all of my characters upper tier gems. i found that your main character is much better with just magic, so i found myself ignoring melee near the end. So the four main things wrong with this game are that the crafting system seems pretty pointless as you will never have enough gems to do any real meaningful beyond the main character, the combat system has a damage vs health issue, and mana doesnt really need to be managed that well after the first half of them game as the skill costs dont really increase at the same rate as increased in mana, and you have to run the game through uplay(which stopped giving me achievements randomly so to unlock them again i would have to play though again and hope that it didnt happen again, but whatever achievements dont matter).

content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												It's a good game in the JRPG style without the Japenese elements to it (anime, hyperbole, etc.).  Though the ending felt a bit rushed, the game was enjoyable throughout.  There are a lot of ways to approach battles, many different tactics depending on which characters to want to use, so there may be some replayability for those endeavoring to experiment.  Character progression relies on players making choices of which stats to boost and which abilities to learn, which I think is a great mechanic that many modern JRPGs have gotten away from.  You can level these characters to suit your style, and you're not just filling spheres on a skill tree without branches.The rhyming dialogue is interesting, bouncing between clever and annoying at times, but overall I think it's a success.  I'd recommend for anyone who enjoys RPGs with turn-based battles.  It's not a very difficult game, and there's plenty of side stuff to do if you go looking for it.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2016
												DaRevieweD #3My First RPG to Speak My Mind About!! Ok, Here Goes. A Foreword, I Am Experienced With A Ton of RPGS; Final Fantasy, Suikoden, Persona, You Name It. There Are Just So Much Variations In Gaining EXP, Fighting, Storylines. Without Further Ado, I Present to Thee!!"A Kingdom of Greatness."[+] PROS;(a) Beautiful Artstyle, Uniquely Detailed.(b) Addictive Battle System. With Only Two Playable at a Time and Need Constant Switching.(c) Side Quests That Were Pretty Overwhelming.(d) Co-op- If You Play Two Player. The Other Controlling Igniculus.(e) Soundtrack That Give One The Feels, The Emotions.....(f) Challenging- The Difficulty Curve Is Interesting.[-] CONS; (i) Gameplay Gets Rather Repetitive.(ii) The Old-Fashioned, Timey English Language Does Bore (I'm Sorry to Say) (Although, If Listened Intently, One's Vocabulary Would Certainly Prevail!) (iii) Lack of Customization- Unlike Other RPGs- Changing Equipments.I Enchant To This,8/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												A fun title that could have been more. First, the positives: the art work is beautiful; really stunning watercolour design. Second, the music, whilst the tunes get very familiar, they're also pretty easy on the ears too. You'll find yourself humming along before long. The gameplay is surprisingly challenging. I reccommend playing on 'gamer' mode to properly experience Child of Light. There's a nice skill tree available to each character and the AI does not play nice. I'll readily admit I died a few times in this game.On the 'less' positive side is the story. It's very simplistic, unfortunately so. The real meat of the story is hidden away in difficult to locate 'diary entries'. There's a lot that could have been done to flesh out characters. The game script gets a little tedious also. The nusery rhyme style, whilst cute to a point, can make reading a little frustrating, especially when trying to decipher the aforementioned diary entries. 3 1/2 stars.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2014
												Ok so I just finished playing Child of Light!!! I enjoyed it tremendously. The aesthetics are magnificient (not to mention the poetry, seriously), the music gorgeous, the battle system, the oculi and the whole mechanics using Igniculus are just wonderful, I had not seen something like that before, I think it was very creative. Oh, and a felame protagonist. I must always mention that. Now, about the difficulty: I played in normal, and didn't find it difficult in the least. It wasn't a breeze, but with a bit of grinding I found the pace great, letting you relax through the game without becoming bored. Just a thing more, all this is coming from someone who suffers fybromialgia, and I must say that this game was a blessing, since because of the fog that comes with the illness I have been less and less able to play any kind of game, and being able to thorougly enjoy this one was a more than welcome change. I can't stress enough how happy I am for being able to play something as awesome as this again, but maybe I am a bit biased because of that.I was a bit worried after buying it because all the hate on Uplay, but honestly, I don't see it as bad, it didn't bother me at all, didn't disconect once (and let it be known that my internet competes for the worst internet in the world), and it had the Uplay win thing, that had some rad things. I'm off to play the NG+ now! ;)

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												One of the most endearing game I have played in the last year, Child of Light brings you into a fairytale world with its unique look inspired by watercolor paintings of the 19th century, and its funny dialogue, all in rhyme. The characters are unique and interesting, with their own personality.The music, always an important part of a game for me, is sad and heroic at the same time; I enjoyed it so much I actually bought the soundtrack.Aurora, the heroine, is an endearing character, a child who grows as you guide her through the story. I loved just watching her hair flow around in the wind as you fly around looking for hidden chests or monsters. She's kind, courageous, and grows as the story progresses.I love stories and games with female protagonists, and this does not disappoint, an excellent example that games featuring strong women in leading roles can be great. Aurora is a very good role-model for young gamers.The gameplay was a bit easy and rather simple, but then I'm a veteran of this kind of game for 30 years. Still I found the combat system enjoyable overall. The real gems in this game are the exploration, the dialogue and the story.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												I'm really enjoying this game. It's seriously beatiful to look at and to listen to. The battle system is a throwback in a nice way to a nostalgic age (for me, anyway). I have a small rant here about the writing: the game is billed as poetry; it's not. The lines rhyme (poorly), but that doesn't make it poetry. The writer has no sense of rhythm nor measure, and a great many of the 'rhymes' reach so far they dislocate their shoulders. If you call the writing poetry, it's complete crap. But as a story told nursery-rhyme style, it's not bad. It's a coming of age story, and I like those.I highly recommend the game. I've missed having real RPGs in the current age of FPS/RPG/MMO/Puzzle/anything-else-we-can-shoe-horn-in-to-maybe-get-another-market games. This definitely qualifies.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												Pros: pretty, centered around girls and women, musicCons: white white white, awful writing, poor pacingGorgeous Watercolor SceneryChild of Light by Ubisoft is the prettiest game I’ve ever played. Every frame of every environment looks like it could be hung in a gallery. Seriously, just look at this:The environments and backgrounds were simply breathtaking. The artwork and the squid-like hair movement made the game for me.Girls Girls GirlsLet’s talk about how many women and girls there are throughout the entire game! SO MANY WOMEN AND GIRLS. It starts and ends with girls, which is how it should be. Aurora, the main character. The Lady of the Forest, who is the Queen of Light. Rubella, the first addition to the party. The Capilli leader. Norah, the sister. Magna, the giant. Cordelia, another sister. Gen, an orphan.  Umbra, the queen. The story’s premise and narrative also reveals a very matrilineal focus as the struggle for the throne involves primarily a feud between two queens, and their daughters are the ones who inherit that pain and burden. The narrator also reveals herself to be a mother and even a queen (perhaps Aurora herself), as the game wraps up with “Soon it will be your turn, princess, to leave on an adventure.”I do not believe that they make up a majority of the named characters in the game (based on my quick tallying of all the characters I ran into), but I’m honestly just excited that there are this many at all. It’s so refreshing to see a game spotlight young girls for this coming of age story.Not-Princess in a TowerChild of Light puts a flip on the typical princess in a tower trope. This time, it’s the dad wasting away in his tower as the princess journeys to save him. He ends up getting “fridged,” or killed off just to move the plot along and provide the main character motivation to exact revenge, a role typically reserved for hot girlfriends or beautiful damsels. It’s refreshing to see this role reversal, if the trope must exist in some form.Religious ImageryI get so excited talking about this. Child of Light is just drenched in religious imagery, heavily reminiscent of Christian arts and biblical stories, and it’s beautiful. From the moment Aurora wakes up on the altar, there’s something not just magical but spiritual about the world.  The game opens with a cinematic of long, narrow stained glass windows as the narrator introduces us to the plight of the Austrian dukedom. Already, it’s like we’re walking around a brilliant, illuminated cathedral in the moonlight.In the image above, the Queen of Light is depicted with her head surrounded by a large sunburst. It’s easily recognized as a parallel to the radiant halos in religious imagery used to indicate holiness. The Queen of Light proves to have power over life itself and various other miracles (granting Aurora flight, for instance). Her title and this halo serve as an early indication that she is more than mortal and holds not only kindness in her heart but also divinity.All of the story’s major cut scenes, which narrate the plot of the game, similarly feature stained glass cinematics, styled in a way that clearly reflects the stylistic features of the popular storytelling medium found in Christian churches. The story features resurrection, a flood, and a new beginning in a new world—all significant themes of major events in biblical narratives (the resurrection of Jesus and the Genesis flood).Yet, unlike actual Christianity, the world and story of Child of Light is entirely centered around women and girls. Aurora is the savior. She is resurrected—twice. The wise woman, the Lady of the Forest, is a mother. It’s revealed later that she is actually the Queen of Light, living on after her mortal death. Even though the Queen only shows up in the game a couple of times, her presence is felt throughout it all, through the flute song that Aurora and many others recognize as the Queen’s melody as well as the repeated mention of her memory as a beloved figure and leader among the people.On the other side, darkness is also represented by a woman and her daughters. Child of Light brilliantly tells its story in a way that feels so familiar and sacred while at the same time refusing to put any spotlight on men, who traditionally dominate Christian and other religious spaces.The Not-Magic FluteI absolutely loved the role of the flute in the game and story. It’s not magic. You can’t use it as an item in battle. Instead, Aurora uses it when there’s nothing else. It’s a coping skill. Nothing changes, but you feel better, and so do those around you. And that’s important, especially in circumstances of loss, grief, isolation, and chaos. A lot of video games champion a do-it-all strongman hero who just loves saving the world and wins rewards through direct actions against evil. But here, our characters have emotions, feel sad, feel lost, and need help. Yes, they slay dozens of evil creatures and save little villages, one at a time, but it’s hard, and sometimes they make mistakes, and sometimes they don’t know what to do. The flute and its song gives them peace, reminds them of home, and renews their hope. The music in this whole game is beautiful all around, but the flute song is particularly special and really touching because of the way Aurora uses it to ground herself and practice self care. Coping skills are so crucial to every journey, and I’m so happy it was included in this game in such a significant way.Okay, lets get into the dirt.So, this game is far from perfect. Here are my complaints. ♥♥♥♥ You, RobertRobert is a piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ honestly, and he never gets put in his place. His story arc is 1000% the overdone trope of “If I just try hard enough, gain enough money and hero status, I’ll get the girl.” Why anyone thought this story belonged in this game that is otherwise about awesome and genuine love for family and community… I have no idea. Margaret, Robert’s love interest, is super awesome and totally tells him off with a sweet “Boy, you don’t know me!” in her first appearance, but, unfortunately, she is forced as a trophy into Robert’s life during the ending round of story arc wrap-ups.Why do all the royal girls look the same?I get that they’re sisters, but they’re not blood sisters, and why would you pass up the opportunity to draw and create several unique and individual female characters. It just felt so cookie cutter to me, like “We just have 1 model of a girl and we’re gonna copy paste that for all the girls in this game—maybe change their hair color." I’m used to seeing this happening in gritty action games, where there are no playable female characters and women are used either as decoration to "set the scene” or as disposable but sexy bodies. So it is weird to see this practice repeated here in this game centered around female characters. And the rest of our party is so diverse in the way they look; I don’t know why they decided not to carry that over to the main character and villains.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												It's a good game in the JRPG style without the Japenese elements to it (anime, hyperbole, etc.).  Though the ending felt a bit rushed, the game was enjoyable throughout.  There are a lot of ways to approach battles, many different tactics depending on which characters to want to use, so there may be some replayability for those endeavoring to experiment.  Character progression relies on players making choices of which stats to boost and which abilities to learn, which I think is a great mechanic that many modern JRPGs have gotten away from.  You can level these characters to suit your style, and you're not just filling spheres on a skill tree without branches.The rhyming dialogue is interesting, bouncing between clever and annoying at times, but overall I think it's a success.  I'd recommend for anyone who enjoys RPGs with turn-based battles.  It's not a very difficult game, and there's plenty of side stuff to do if you go looking for it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
												Incredibly fun battle system.  You control a fairy like creature that you can use to heal your team or slow the speed of enemies.  As the battle goes on theres a bar at the bottom of the screen that has icons of your party and the enemies go past.  Near the end if you manage to hit an enemy during the last moments before their attack, the attack is cancelled and they get pushed back in the time line.  However!  The same can happen to you.  The combat becomes a super in depth game of planning and timing thats really REALLY fun.  The only complaint I have about it is that some attacks that enemis do have longer or shorter times when it hits the attack animation so you can plan ahead to be in front and interrupt their attack but they decided to use a much faster attack and knock you back.  Really wish they would have implemented a little pop up showing how fast the spell/attack animation is for combat.But yeah legit 9.5/10 RPG.  Also the game is adorable as ♥♥♥♥ yo

Norah, the sister. Magna, the giant. Cordelia, another sister. Gen, an orphan.  Umbra, the queen. The story’s premise and narrative also reveals a very matrilineal focus as the struggle for the throne involves primarily a feud between two queens, and their daughters are the ones who inherit that pain and burden. The narrator also reveals herself to be a mother and even a queen (perhaps Aurora herself), as the game wraps up with “Soon it will be your turn, princess, to leave on an adventure.”I do not believe that they make up a majority of the named characters in the game (based on my quick tallying of all the characters I ran into), but I’m honestly just excited that there are this many at all. It’s so refreshing to see a game spotlight young girls for this coming of age story.Not-Princess in a TowerChild of Light puts a flip on the typical princess in a tower trope. This time, it’s the dad wasting away in his tower as the princess journeys to save him. He ends up getting “fridged,” or killed off just to move the plot along and provide the main character motivation to exact revenge, a role typically reserved for hot girlfriends or beautiful damsels. It’s refreshing to see this role reversal, if the trope must exist in some form.Religious ImageryI get so excited talking about this. Child of Light is just drenched in religious imagery, heavily reminiscent of Christian arts and biblical stories, and it’s beautiful. From the moment Aurora wakes up on the altar, there’s something not just magical but spiritual about the world.  The game opens with a cinematic of long, narrow stained glass windows as the narrator introduces us to the plight of the Austrian dukedom. Already, it’s like we’re walking around a brilliant, illuminated cathedral in the moonlight.In the image above, the Queen of Light is depicted with her head surrounded by a large sunburst. It’s easily recognized as a parallel to the radiant halos in religious imagery used to indicate holiness. The Queen of Light proves to have power over life itself and various other miracles (granting Aurora flight, for instance). Her title and this halo serve as an early indication that she is more than mortal and holds not only kindness in her heart but also divinity.All of the story’s major cut scenes, which narrate the plot of the game, similarly feature stained glass cinematics, styled in a way that clearly reflects the stylistic features of the popular storytelling medium found in Christian churches. The story features resurrection, a flood, and a new beginning in a new world—all significant themes of major events in biblical narratives (the resurrection of Jesus and the Genesis flood).Yet, unlike actual Christianity, the world and story of Child of Light is entirely centered around women and girls. Aurora is the savior. She is resurrected—twice. The wise woman, the Lady of the Forest, is a mother. It’s revealed later that she is actually the Queen of Light, living on after her mortal death. Even though the Queen only shows up in the game a couple of times, her presence is felt throughout it all, through the flute song that Aurora and many others recognize as the Queen’s melody as well as the repeated mention of her memory as a beloved figure and leader among the people.On the other side, darkness is also represented by a woman and her daughters. Child of Light brilliantly tells its story in a way that feels so familiar and sacred while at the same time refusing to put any spotlight on men, who traditionally dominate Christian and other religious spaces.The Not-Magic FluteI absolutely loved the role of the flute in the game and story. It’s not magic. You can’t use it as an item in battle. Instead, Aurora uses it when there’s nothing else. It’s a coping skill. Nothing changes, but you feel better, and so do those around you. And that’s important, especially in circumstances of loss, grief, isolation, and chaos. A lot of video games champion a do-it-all strongman hero who just loves saving the world and wins rewards through direct actions against evil. But here, our characters have emotions, feel sad, feel lost, and need help. Yes, they slay dozens of evil creatures and save little villages, one at a time, but it’s hard, and sometimes they make mistakes, and sometimes they don’t know what to do. The flute and its song gives them peace, reminds them of home, and renews their hope. The music in this whole game is beautiful all around, but the flute song is particularly special and really touching because of the way Aurora uses it to ground herself and practice self care. Coping skills are so crucial to every journey, and I’m so happy it was included in this game in such a significant way.Okay, lets get into the dirt.So, this game is far from perfect. Here are my complaints. ♥♥♥♥ You, RobertRobert is a piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ honestly, and he never gets put in his place. His story arc is 1000% the overdone trope of “If I just try hard enough, gain enough money and hero status, I’ll get the girl.” Why anyone thought this story belonged in this game that is otherwise about awesome and genuine love for family and community… I have no idea. Margaret, Robert’s love interest, is super awesome and totally tells him off with a sweet “Boy, you don’t know me!” in her first appearance, but, unfortunately, she is forced as a trophy into Robert’s life during the ending round of story arc wrap-ups.Why do all the royal girls look the same?I get that they’re sisters, but they’re not blood sisters, and why would you pass up the opportunity to draw and create several unique and individual female characters. It just felt so cookie cutter to me, like “We just have 1 model of a girl and we’re gonna copy paste that for all the girls in this game—maybe change their hair color." I’m used to seeing this happening in gritty action games, where there are no playable female characters and women are used either as decoration to "set the scene” or as disposable but sexy bodies. So it is weird to see this practice repeated here in this game centered around female characters. And the rest of our party is so diverse in the way they look; I don’t know why they decided not to carry that over to the main character and villains.

												This was a nice ride through a cute lil world. It was more than I exptected. I didn't thought that there would be so many party members for your group. It's a shame that only 2 play at a time but it's easy to change between the fights. Nice characters, nice graphic-style. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												Despite some of the reviews claiming Uplay to be the cause of a lot of issues... I have, thus far, had no problems with it.While I have not yet beaten the game, I shall still recommend it simply based on the art style, atmosphere, and the amusing rhyming/poetic aspect of everything spoken in game.The are a few little puzzles here and there, but nothing much aside from box pushing and moving your mouse just right.The combat is unique as well.You can see enemies in the area as you are traveling. When going to fight one it brings up a turn based encounter event. Some encounters simply require the old style method of mindlessly mashing your basic attack button. Other's require a bit of strategy. A uniqute aspect to encounters is using your mouse (and your little buddy that you control with it) to slow the enemies actions, heal yourself, and collect 'wishes' during the encounters. This incorporates a bit of timing and determining which enemy to target first. If timed right and you have a touch of luck, you can make it through some encounters without taking any damage at all.I suppose I should mention a downside to the game.The main story is, thus far, rather enjoyable. But the little side quests you find from various NPC's are not so much. They do give you some nice rewards... but tend to be rather vague with how to go about doing them. Or just rather annoying by having you backtrack several areas to find something that has now spawned there only to grab it and travel all the way back.Very time consuming and sometimes the rewards don't quite match up to the effort put into them.Overall it is well worth getting. If you like RPG style games, exploring in a 2d environment, and the general oddities of what you might find... it is worth it.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2016
												the whole game i was thinking its such an awesome game, looks nice, its like a mix of rayman, paper mario and trine. but then only with a female character.. graphics look like art and are real nice, gameplay also battlesystem and skill/crafting is addictive, in this game the crafting works with gems only, and there is this best gem to craft thats the princess stone, you have to mix up certain types of gems to get it...... but before i had enough gems to do so i allready made it to the end boss. i have to admit i skipped 2 quests and one of these quests gave me enough gems i would have been able to use to make the princess stone.. so it maybe was my own fault for skipping a side quest, but i did not expect a ubisoft game like this to end so fast.but thats the only minor thing i can mention about it.. you could have more playtime offcourse if you do all the quests and search for every loot i just finished this game in 16 hours, just one weekend. i have to say, for what i expected from the game i'm glad i didnt pay the full price, got it on 75% sale for 3,74 euro's and that made me buy it (by the way i almost never buy games when they are full price, mostly because i dont have an high end pc anyway). i would give it 10 euros but not 15 compared to other games availble on steam.but again i say i would not pay the full price for it because im more of a quantity then quality type of gamer, rather have more playtime than good graphics, anyway, if you are more into graphics then its worth your money! its a real jewel and it gives you more fun than going to the cinema so why not :) and its a game you have to play for sure tho

number of helpful: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2014
												I was excited for this one and even pre ordered it. I would say buy it on sale for the visuals alone because it is a beautiful game. I was ecxited to get involved with an old school type rpg gamem but this game is terribly dissapointing to be honest. I loike the wat the battle system works, using an extra character with your mouse to shed light on enemies to slow them down, or recover your hp slowly. But how did this get put out this way. I have 5 peaople in my party and can only use two at a time, granted when a characters turn somes up you can swap out characters right away with no time consequence but its just pain silly. I have three enimies to fight on one side and only two one my side? Comeon. The skill trees are absolutely boring with only upgrades to hp/mp as well as upgrades on magical/defense abilites that the characters just come with. They can only be upgraded very little with some getting a "use/attack on option. No shops, no new weapons. You can upgrade your weaopn, defense, and time by setting gems in them for fire, water , lightning etc but again, boring as all get out. They could have done so much on this game that would have made it an almost household name but it just falls way short. Pros: Art and MusicCons:Everything elseI am not one to be critical or mean but this was so dissapointing, especially after promoting this on my facebook, twitter, tumblr on release day only to find that I have reccomended a bad game. I am around level 30 and have not finished the game but no new interesting things have happened outside of some more characters and to be honest some stunning artwork. Lets either update this, or make a better part 2 with purchasable weapons, actuall good spells, and a skill tree that was not made by someone who must have never played an rpg in there life. And for goodness sakes the mosy angering part, let us have more than two characters on screen especially if you are going to spend the time to allow more than two on the enemie side.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												Great artwork, great music, unfortunately that's all this game has going for it. While the game has great scenery, everything else is rather linear or lack luster.When first watching the trailer, I was excited to see how many abilities the game offered and a customization in making better gear/equipment. What I was not aware of is they counted even passive abilities and "higher level versions" of said ability to the count, when in reality the game only offered a handful of tools you can use during combat. The customization is extremely linear, filling your items with left over gems, only giving the option of making stronger gems for your character (which, there isn't many types create from).The gameplay itself is very simple even on the hardest difficulty. The game relies heavily on the time management system, making it easy to interrupt enemy attacks. So much so, that it may be possible to complete the game without taking damage (can't say for sure, but I was able to defeat the end game bosses all without getting hit thanks to such exploits in the design).What I expected was an old school style RPG game, sharing elements from such games like Chrono Trigger and Grandia. Instead, what I got was a developer that tried to mimic such elements but didn't fully understand how or why they worked.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												Giving a negative review due to UPlay. Two layers of DRM is unacceptable.Edit: Since many people have been unhappy with the above line being all of my review, let me add that I found the game itself very pretty, and the dialogue and the characters are quite charming in an old fairy tale kind of way. In the mood, I sensed a kind of mixture between cheerfulness, hope, and melancholy. The game works reasonably well, although sometimes the combats feel too long and too repetitive. The combat is turn-based and can take a while each time. You need to fight though to make your party stronger in order to be able to pass some mandatory enemies. I think the game would have been better with less combat.If you can stand UPlay and having to log in to many platforms to play a game, the game itself is nice. I do understand the developers of the game have probably been entirely helpless against Ubisofts politics with UPlay. Oh well.

												I wanted to like this game... but I can'tThe Good:-This game is beautiful in spite of a consistant bug where the protagonist's hair wouldn't render in combat, I cannot recommend the art enough, it is amazing.-Gameplay is fun and interesting.  I got to interact with systems that I haven't seen before and they were well executed.  The only problem is the game never really seems to get all that hard.The Bad:-Ubisoft's extra layer of DRM 'nuff said-The writing is aweful.  Like I don't care about any of the characters they're just healer, phyisical damage dealer, caster, buffer/debuffer ect.  There is no connection to what I am doing and I really don't care about the world.  Conclusion:I'm almost done the game and won't bother finishing it because it overstays it's welcome.  It's beautiful, but the developer's choice to write the whole game in rhyme was a complete disaster.  It's worth it on a sale for the time, but full price?  pass

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												The game is undeniably beautiful, with the excellent score as accompaniment. The story is rhymed and whimsical to match, an ease and joy to read. The backgrounds are lovingly detailed, and the eagle-eyed would easily spot hidden treasures scattered across the land of Lemuria, and exploration is encouraged in side quests, opening up new sections of an area. The combat system may take some time to get used to, with certain elements of timing and luck required to get your skills or interrupts off, and learning it would make battles a breeze. While on the whole I would recommend this game, thus far there is a certain linearity; I had wandered ahead before returning to complete a quest, and later triggered a new story cutscene in a place I had already been to. The 2-member party size might seem very limiting as well, one assumes to encourage more active swapping. Edit on game completion: The replayability would come from collecting all the items, unlocking the skills, but if you're not one to do that, then leaving this game for a sale would be alright. One thing I should warn is that there is no brief break betwen the second last and the last boss, and I got a nasty shock from the transition. I myself would like to read all the dialogue all over again, but this is subjective.

Nine out of ten.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2016
												once in a while an actual good game shows up, a game thats actually orignal and fun, then once in a while a work of art shows up. wtf why isn't ubisoft publishing more games like this, it is actually one of the best games. and why the dafuq can ubisoft montreal make bad games, thenout of no where make this game. how does ubisoft even work, what is ubisoft, is there life after death, why do i get banned so much from club penguin these are the real questions. this game is perfect in every way, from gameplay, to art style, to story. 10/10, the art work is top notch. everything is painted in a light whispy water color style, and turns out that simple water color can make really detialed enviroments. the music is also a striaght jam alert. soft paino and sollum cello, then when you get into a battle♥♥♥♥♥♥gets lit. you really feel like your life is on the line, just perfect music. now the gameplay is a good mixture of turn based and an orginal little twist. its skillful enough that you feel like you are in control and your getting better, but its not so hard and punishing to learn or complex so that you never get the hang of it. the diffuculty is on point too, you have two choices and they hit home pretty well. on casual or normal its pretty chill. the game puts you in an inch of your life sometimes, but it never really kills you that much. then the harder diffuculty will make you want to crawl into your bathtub and kill yourself. then aside from all of that the story is really great, cute almost ,but in a good fun way. you got roofied by your evil♥♥♥♥♥step mom, and now your like in a dream or something, then like boom betrayal, then like dang. its real good. THEN on top of that you have this large open world, where you can find stuff, do missions, a true rpg. a true soviet game, did the soviets even have video games. call of lenin, that would be a good game. yeah this is one of the good games, the only thing that makes it a pain is that you have to log into uplay. uplay is actually the worst thing ever invented. everytime i open it up i contemplate if it would be easier to just crawl into my bathtub and kill myself, but its kinda worth it to play this game.

THEN on top of that you have this large open world, where you can find stuff, do missions, a true rpg. a true soviet game, did the soviets even have video games. call of lenin, that would be a good game. yeah this is one of the good games, the only thing that makes it a pain is that you have to log into uplay. uplay is actually the worst thing ever invented. everytime i open it up i contemplate if it would be easier to just crawl into my bathtub and kill myself, but its kinda worth it to play this game.
