content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												Let me start of with this: I'm not a fan of 2D platform games. After 20minutes with Child of Light - I'm still not one. But this game, has never felt more user-friendly than any other I tried. It does not feel like 2D at all. Storyline as basic as it may be, had few very nostalgic moments which truly captured the mind. This is a mix of art, fantasy, fairytale and FF turn-based action, which will guarantee long hours of gameplay. Once the music starts, you will not want to turn the volume down. From melancholic violins and flutes, to the strong tubas and dramatic pianos accompanied by choir, Child of Light's OST is definitely a rich one, for such genre. Even after turning the game off, you can still hear the sound of Boss Battles.As for gameplay itself, it really kept me going. The graphics are such eye catchers, one does not want to end a level without fully exploring it. Physics done on Princess' hair is simply fantastic, just for the hair itself you let the character float around up and down, doing twirls and jumps. Despite same scenarios to all battles, the varieties of enemies were definitely satysfying and even on Normal Game Mode - I've had some troubles sometimes managing my health.Characters all all different with their own personalities, but not to spoil anything - I'll stop right there.Child of Light is a game for audiences of various ages, definitely worth anyone's while, time and money. It is with pleasure I can recomment the game to anyone, who thought the same as me (and not only) after watching the trailer: This looks cute, I might give it a shot.Do it. You will not regret a single moment :)

content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												Child of Light is a short, simplistic, visually striking turn based RPG/platformer.  The main draw of the game is its distinct art style which is a joy to behold.  The backgrounds have a very authentic hand drawn style that makes playing the game feel like walking through the pages of a childhood picture book come to life.  The locations you visit are varied and never long enough that they become tired or repetitive.  The animation and physics for Aurora are excellent and really help breath life into her character both in and out of combat.  If you want something that's enjoyable just to look at then Child of Light is a strong contender.With that said, the game doesn't really stand out on its gameplay merits.  The platforming aspects and puzzles aren't challenging and the main character's ability to fly makes navigation straightforward in most cases.  The ability to control Ignatius is a novel feature but never really evolves beyond using the mouse to click a button or shine a light on an object.  The battle sequences are standard turn based RPG fare for anyone who grew up in the 8 or 16 bit eras.  Again it adds a twist onto that with Ignacious who you can use to slow enemies and this does add a bit of skill to the game where you can put your foes in a position to be constantly interrupted if you manage it properly.  But even so the battle mechanics aren't particularly deep so there's not any need to micromanage enemy turns and I found I was more likely to throw away Ignatious' hope bar for free heals rather than pestering my enemies.The leveling, talent, and crafting systems are equally simple and don't do much to engage the player.  One annoyance is that your characters level up so often it becomes tedious having to acknowledge it after every 2nd or 3rd fight.  And the fact that battle experience is shared between your entire group means that even if you use just two characters throughout the whole game you'll constantly be dealing with skill points for all of your party members.  The talent trees are fairly boring and pretty much boil down to a lot of filler between marginally increasing your direct damage and group damage abilities.  Having long skill trees with things like, '+5 health', '+5 defense', '+1 dodge', for every character doesn't grab the imagination the way the visuals do.  The crafting system is equally simple with 3 primary, 3 secondary, and 3 special combinations of gems.  None of the combinations except the last one - which you won't be able to do until far into the game - feel very powerful which makes the tedium of combinations unrewarding.The sound and music are great but lack the variation that is apparent in the environments.  As good as the main theme and battle music are they're pretty much all you hear with a few flourishes in between marking certain events.  There are a lot of variations on the main theme throughout the game but by the time you're done it's hard to look back and not feel like it was all very samey.  I love the music, but I wish there was more of it.  And as good as the instrumentation for the game is the same cannot be said of the narrator who begins and ends our time with the game.  In the English version her delivery of the prologue and epilogue feel very unnatural.The writing for the game leaves something to be desired as well.  The game tries to render every interaction in a sing-songy faux-meter that you would expect in a fairy tale but often times this doesn't work out well.  The majority of the lines have wildly different meter but will end with a rhyme.  Other times they have a steady meter but don't rhyme.  Yet other times you can see that they've used some bizarre word order just to end a line with a rhyme.  It feels very inconsistent and I would assume is the result of localization.  Because the majority of the dialogue was shoehorned into this not-quite-poetry style it makes a lot of the back and forth between the characters a chore to read and parse.  I can appreciate that the developer had the vision to make a game using sylized prose but as beautiful as the graphics are I must say the writing is not.The game has excellent pacing and runs just about 8 hours long to complete on your first run through.  For me this is the perfect length as I finished the game just as the battle system was starting to feel repetitive which means the game held my interest for exactly the amount of time it needed to.  If you're a completionist then it also offers collection achievements, side quests, and the option to play through the game again on 'New Game+' using your saved character data.When I look at the game as a whole it's hard not to notice a lot of the shortcomings that prevent it from being a masterpiece.  Heck, from a pure gameplay perspective it's hard for me to say the game is even above average as much of its implementation skews towards being overly simplistic.  Notwithstanding the criticisms, the artistic charm of this game won me over.  The graphics and music of the platforming sections evoked memories of Trine while the battle system felt comfortably like stepping back into Final Fantasy VI - both of those are happy places to be.  For me Child of Light put a beautiful new face onto game structures I'm nostalgic for.I had a very pleasant time with this game.  Recommended.

												This game is magical, pure and simple. From the audio, design, to the music, you'll be entranced by the story of the lost little girl in the strange land. The characters are charming, the combat is fun and thoughtful without being tedious, and the collecting of items (mainly confessions) doesn't feel like a chore. The story though, is where this game really shines.If you like an RPG with charm, heart, and a dash of a traditional fairy tale, get Child of Light.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												One of the most amazing games I've played in a long time. The story is endearing, the characters are adorable, there's a strong female protagonist (for once!) and I loved the music so much I'm eyeing the OST. Visually, the game is stunning. The backgrounds look hand-painted, but have a level of interactibility I didn't expect, and the game has a charming 2D kind of look to it that still manages to have so much depth. I could look at the backgrounds all day. The battles are turn based, but unike anything I've experienced before. At the bottom of the battle screen a "timeline" appears, segmented in two (waiting and casting) and your placement on the timeline, as well as your enemy's place determines who attacks first, but if you manage to attack them before they attack you and while they're in the casting section, you can actualy knock them back on the timeline, delaying their attack, It makes you have to think ahead, so that when you finally beat the bad guys, you feel like a tactical genius.The Skill trees are pretty simple, as there aren't a whole lot of flashy moves, but a lot of opportunity to strengthen the ones you do have, which I actually find more satisfying than having a bunch of different, yet low-power options. Throughout the game you can collect gemstones of various types called Oculi, which you can then combine to make bigger ones, or different ones, or bigger different ones, with each type of gemstone offering a certain perk or strength that, when equipped to one of 3 slots that your character and anyone in her party has, can give you that advantage in battle, or extra XP gain that can sometimes mean life or death.The dialogue is exclusively in rhyme (I want to say iambic pentameter but I haven't been keeping track) and although at times it seems like they're really scambling to make it rhyme, it doesn't diminish the story.   Some reviewers have said that this game takes 12 hours to get through, but I've been playing it for more than that, and not only am I nowhere near finished, I haven't been bored for even a minute, despite taking my sweet time. I can't reccomend this game enough. I really can't. Chances are if I know you, I wil make you play it.P.S. Explore! Look everywhere. You might be surprised at what you find.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2014
												A intressting take from UBIsoft on a more Final fantasy remminisent style, infused with a art style simmilar to many Indi-games. (Rendered models with artwork backgrounds). The soundtrack is intressting, however lacks diversity when you feel it is needed (Boss music in particular).The games artwork brings across the soft style it needs to brings across well telling the story. However, my only flaw with this game is the obsessive need to Rhyme. It tries to hard to Rhyme, and sometimes is a-bit, nail biting to say the least. The Story, is beautiful, slow paced, but almost obvious from the start, However, this diddn't stop me from completing it in 8 hours flat, (breaks included). Infact, this pushed me to finish, as i wanted to see how it would play out, and it was worth it with the support of beautiful, Final Fantasy styled concept art, (Suggest looking up Yoshitaka Amano) which adds to the soft and warmth provided in the game. It's a intressting take, on a style which has since been laking somewhat recently, and i recommend it if you have played transistor, if you would like a see on something more softer and just as heartfelt.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												I am really into turn based RPGs that probably greatly helped in my appreciation of this game. This game is great. Although no one part stands apart as truly amazing. It is overall a great experience. Combat is a bit lacking in early parts of the game, but the enjoyment it provides picks up speed an hour or two in. The dialog is not deep or life changing, but amusing at times and the story as a whole is enjoyable. I do recommend playing on hard if you want to have to actually pay attention to what your characters are doing. Exploration is also rewarded. Although there is not much variance in the items to find, trying to collect them all is a worthy goal. Uplay will turn some off, but it is handled well, was complication free for me and even worked offline. None of the DLC is remotely required and only one bit of it is actually worth wile. If the game interests you, I doubt you will be disappointed with your purchase. That said you are not missing out if you wait for a sale. I urge you to keep it on your wishlist and play at some point.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												It's truly a beautiful piece.A few words on the aesthetics:The artstyle has a nice oil painting feel to it which is pleasing to the eyes.The soundtrack is really melancholic invoking true empathy for the characters as well as helping the immersion significantly.The dialogue is very poetic and is not afraid to plunge into the olden English which gives the whole story a classical fairytail story feeling to it.A few thoughts on gameplay:While the combat system is the game's main mechanic, I don't believe that it is the true focus of the game.I believe that the game's main focus is exploration and discovery, to explore this new and unfamiliar world, to find hidden nooks and crannies filled with treasure chests and lore.However the game can be played in both ways:If you prefer the RPG elements and combat over exploration lore and discovery, I'd recommend setting the difficulty to HARD so combat plays a more deeper role in the game and you'll need to focus more on gaining levels as you progress.If you prefer to explore this 2D open world, looking for treasure chests, exploring seemingly abandoned houses and whatnot, I'd recommend setting the difficulty to NORMAL for maximum pleasure, this way dealing with the occasional monsters along the way as you continue to explore should be sufficient for you to advance through the game in an enjoyable pace.

												If you enjoy`d the early final fantasy games this is definitely a must, not as fast paced story wise, but the combat tends to be fairly quick if not quicker than those in the FF series leading you back to it's mind taking atmosphere ^_^

content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												It's truly a beautiful piece.A few words on the aesthetics:The artstyle has a nice oil painting feel to it which is pleasing to the eyes.The soundtrack is really melancholic invoking true empathy for the characters as well as helping the immersion significantly.The dialogue is very poetic and is not afraid to plunge into the olden English which gives the whole story a classical fairytail story feeling to it.A few thoughts on gameplay:While the combat system is the game's main mechanic, I don't believe that it is the true focus of the game.I believe that the game's main focus is exploration and discovery, to explore this new and unfamiliar world, to find hidden nooks and crannies filled with treasure chests and lore.However the game can be played in both ways:If you prefer the RPG elements and combat over exploration lore and discovery, I'd recommend setting the difficulty to HARD so combat plays a more deeper role in the game and you'll need to focus more on gaining levels as you progress.If you prefer to explore this 2D open world, looking for treasure chests, exploring seemingly abandoned houses and whatnot, I'd recommend setting the difficulty to NORMAL for maximum pleasure, this way dealing with the occasional monsters along the way as you continue to explore should be sufficient for you to advance through the game in an enjoyable pace.
